PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Elector-Initiated Referenda
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. the right of the people of a country to make law independent of politicians should be a basic and independent fight;
2. consequently there is an urgent need for constitutional reforms.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
support the Constitution Alteration (Electors Initiative) 1987 Bill to alter the constitution so as to vest in the electors power to propose laws and to approve or disapprove such proposed laws.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Commission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That the Constitution of the Commonwealth has served Australia well, is not out of date, has proved to be flexible and should not be radically altered.

2. Our deep concern that the recommendations of the Constitutional Commission and its advisory committees which propose radical changes to the Constitution are threatening to reduce our rights as citizens of the Commonwealth.

3. Our strongest opposition to any referendum proposals of the Hawke Government which gives more power to the Government and less to the people and which concentrates that power in Canberra at the expense of the States and weakens the role of the Senate.

PETITION.TITLE: Elector-Initiated Referenda
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:

That we are strongly supportive of proposals for the establishment of electors' initiated referenda for the making of laws and alteration of the Constitution, in a form somewhat similar to that proposed in a Bill presented by Senator Macklin on 23rd September 1987.

That electors' initiative proposals have widespread support within our community, and in every major political party, being an established aim of the Democrat Party, fifty-five years as endorsed Labor Party policy, recommended by the Queensland branch of the National Party, and raised recently in the Liberal Party's Law and Justice policy.
That the evidence of their great value and popularity as a superior development of democratic government, by and for the people, has been amply demonstrated in several advanced democracies overseas.
That the proposed legislation would be the greatest Bicentennial gift our Legislature could give to our people, the recognition that we have come of age.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-Rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned,

note that a majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material has strongly opposed the pro- position that a new NVE category will contain that material as defined in the current `X' classification

call upon the Senate to request the Government immediately to implement the recommendation of the majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material by introducing substantive legislation to ensure that X rated video material (and its R rated equivalent) is refused classification for the purpose of Commonwealth laws.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled. The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia, respectfully showeth:
that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide, independent radio and television service.
that the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia.
that the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation:Funding for Orchestras
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
The A.B.C. orchestras currently underfunded now find themselves under further threat due to proposals contained in the current position paper relative to the A.B.C.
Your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
Exercise its powers to ensure that current funding is increased sufficiently to ensure the maintenance and growth of these fine cultural bodies by including the orchestras as a charter area.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Notice of Intention to Withdraw Notice of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 109a, I give notice that, immediately after Question Time this day, I shall withdraw Business of the Senate Notice of Motion No. 1 standing in my name for this day of sitting for disallowance of the Schools Authority (Amendment) Ordinance 1987. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short explanation of the scrutiny by the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and the Committee's brief correspondence with the Minister for Arts and Territories.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
Statement

The Committee sought and obtained an assurance from the Minister for the Arts and Territories, the Honourable Gary Punch, M.P., that fee determinations under the Schools Authority Ordinance were legally subject to tabling and disallowance in Parliament. The Committee also sought the Minister's advice about the absence of rights to seek review of the Minister's discretionary powers under the Ordinance to exempt individuals or classes of individuals from the requirement to pay fees. Having reconsidered the Ordinance, the Minister has agreed to make an amendment so that objective criteria for exemption decisions will be specified and to provide for AAT review of any allegedly unfair refusal to exempt. The Committee thanks the Minister for his agreement to make these changes which will underwrite the quality of the administration of the scheme and protect the rights of individuals.
8 March 1988
The Hon. Gary Punch, MP
Minister for the Arts and Territories
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister,

At its meeting on 25 February 1988 the Committee considered the Schools Authority (Amendment) Ordinance 1988 (being ACT Ordinance No. 2 of 1988, tabled in the Senate on 23 February 1988). There are two points on which the Committee seeks your advice concerning parliamentary tabling requirements and Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) review rights.

Firstly, can you give the Committee your assurance that the Determinations of fees described in new subsection 7b (1) of the Ordinance will be legally subject to parliamentary supervision through tabling and disallowance? In earlier letters to you the Committee has set out its concern regarding the drafting of similar fee determination provisions in the Canberra Institute of the Arts Ordinance 1988 and the ACT Institute of Technical and Further Education Ordinance 1987. The same point arises here. Subsection 7b (1) provides that ``The Minister may, by notice published in the Gazette, determine fees in respect of the attendance by persons at pre-schools.''. This provision does not follow the language used in subsection 12 (10) of the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910 (the Act) which may be interpreted as requiring that a disallowable determination is only one made by a Minister ``pursuant to a provision of an Ordinance'', which provision is to be expressed in empowering terms identical to those used in subsection 12 (10) of the Act namely ``to determine, by notice in writing published in the Gazette, fees [or charges] for the purposes of the Ordinance.''. Certainly for many years until now this precise formula appears to have been adopted in the provisions of a great many Ordinances conferring power to determine disallowable fees. Your clarification and assurance would be welcomed by the Committee.
Secondly, section 7c of the Ordinance provides that:
The Minister may, by instrument, exempt a specified person or a person included in a specified class of persons from the requirement to pay a fee determined under subsection 7b (1).

This is an inherently problematic provision. If an instrument of exemption is legislative in nature the question arises of the need to provide for parliamentary control over such a species of subordinate lawmaking.

On the other hand, if exemption decisions are administrative in character the question arises of the need to guarantee fairness through review of the exercise of what would amount to delegable discretionary powers to exempt. The Committee acknowledges that in its Eighth Annual Report, 1983-84 at page 13, the Administrative Review Council suggested that ``a discretion to grant exemption from normal administrative practice, e.g. the power to exempt from registration under the Aliens Act 1947 (Fourth Annual Report, para. 67)'' was not a decision appropriate for Administrative Appeals Tribunal review. The particular case study from which this suggestion was drawn by the Council was not perhaps sufficiently representative of exemption discretions for it to be regarded as a principle of general application in considering whether to create particular review rights. Neither the Committee nor the then Minister for Aviation, the Hon. Peter Morris, MP, thought so in October 1986 when the Committee was given the Minister's undertaking to amend regulation 2b of the Air Navigation (Charges) Regulations (appearing in Statutory Rules 1986, No. 169) to provide for AAT review of ministerial discretions to remit penalties or charges.

In the case of section 7c of the Schools Authority (Amendment) Ordinance 1988 the absence of review rights or any kind of legislative criteria for granting exemptions may do little to reduce a sense of grievance among persons not exempted.
The Committee would very much appreciate having your views and advice on both of the questions raised in this letter.
Yours sincerely,
Bob Collins
Chairman
Senator Bob Collins
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee
on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
Canberra, ACT 2600
Dear Senator Collins
I refer to your letter received on 8 March 1988 concerning the Schools Authority (Amendment) Ordinance 1988 in which you sought my views and advice on two points of concern to the Committee.

Firstly, the Committee has expressed concern regarding the Parliamentary tabling requirements of fee determinations made pursuant to subsection 7b (1) of the Ordinance. I am advised that determinations made under subsection 7b (1) fall within the definition of `determination' contained in subsection 12 (10) of the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910, notwithstanding that the phrasing of subsection 7b (1) is different from that used in other legislation. Accordingly, I consider that determinations made under subsection 7b (1) are subject to subsection 12 (9b) of the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910.
I have requested that henceforth drafters adhere to a form of language which follows the words previously adopted when conferring power to determine disallowable fees.

Secondly, in respect of section 7c of the Ordinance (as presently drafted) which provides that the Minister may exempt persons from the requirement to pay a fee determined by the Minister, it was originally intended that an exemption be made having regard to objective criteria only. In this case a decision to exempt would be taken on the facts of each case, and not on merits, which would make an appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal unnecessary.

However, in the interests of fairness, I have now decided that there should be a discretion to exempt so that `borderline cases' may be considered for exemption. I therefore undertake to amend the Ordinance to set out the criteria for exercising the discretion to exempt, and to provide for appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal from a decision not to exempt.
I trust that these points are of assistance to the Committee.
Yours sincerely
GARY PUNCH

DEBATE.TITLE: BLOOD DONATION (ACQUIRED IMMUNE DEFICIENCY SYNDROME) ORDINANCE 1985

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement concerning the scrutiny by the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances of the Blood Donation (Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome) Ordinance 1985.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Blood Donation Ordinance originally gave the Red Cross Society a statutory defence if sued by a person who was infected with the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) as a result of a blood transfusion using donated blood that had been specially tested. At the request of the Committee the then Minister for Health, the Honourable Dr Neal Blewett, M.P., agreed to amend the Ordinance so that this statutory defence would not be available in an action by an AIDS victim for alleged negligence in the testing or transfusion of blood. Because the Committee regarded the Ordinance as being potentially very significant as far as the rights of individuals were concerned, the Minister also undertook to limit the operation of the Ordinance by means of a 12-month sunset clause so that a new instrument would be needed to keep the main provision in force. The intention was that the new Ordinance would enable Parliament to exercise some future continuing oversight of this sensitive matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister also agreed to supply the Committee with documents for tabling in the Senate, explaining legal, compensation and medical developments with AIDS. There has been some reluctance to carry out this undertaking in full. The Minister for the Arts and Territories, the Hon. Gary Punch, has now requested the Committee that he be released from the undertaking which he inherited from his predecessors. The Committee has agreed to this request in view of the fact that the Government will shortly table a Green Paper on AIDS which will address some of the legal and compensation issues which were of concern to the Committee when it scrutinised the original Blood Donation Ordinance. The Committee has agreed to release the Minister because it is satisfied that this Green Paper will preserve the focus of parliamentary attention on those aspects of medically acquired AIDS which were of concern to the Committee. The Committee's interest throughout its scrutiny of the Ordinance has been to ensure that Parliament and the public were kept informed of legal, compensation and medical developments regarding AIDS. Ministerial undertakings to sunset the Ordinance and supply the Committee with information for tabling in the Senate have not achieved these goals as effectively as the Committee had hoped they would. Part of the reason for this may have been inertia in the ACT Health Authority, which appears to have failed to assist Ministers to implement the undertaking the Committee had been given by two successive Ministers.

The Committee is currently looking at ways in which ministerial undertakings will in future be closely monitored to ensure that they are implemented as soon as practicable. In any event, the imminence of the Government's Green Paper on AIDS now enables the Committee to finalise the scrutiny of this important Ordinance. As the Committee understands it, that paper will, among other things, address the question of how best to compensate and protect the rights of individuals with medically acquired AIDS. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a statement which describes the history of this matter.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
Blood Donation (Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome) Ordinance 1985

The Ordinance originally provided that the Red Cross Society, doctors and hospitals could plead a statutory defence if they were sued by a person who had contracted AIDS from an infected blood donation. The Society would not be liable provided it had tested the donated and transfused blood in accordance with approved methods of testing for AIDS. At the time of its original scrutiny in 1985 and 1986 the Committee was concerned that this defence might have been so wide that it removed a right of action even for negligence in the testing or transfusing of donated blood. The then Minister for Health, the Hon. Dr Neal Blewett, M.P., agreed to amend the Ordinance expressly to exclude negligence from the scope of the defence. The Committee also asked, and the Minister agreed, that a sunset clause be placed in the Ordinance to terminate it within 12 months so that another Ordinance would be made and tabled to continue its operation. The Committee was concerned that Parliament should be kept informed of legal and medical developments with AIDS and the Ordinance was the major legislative point of contact which would have provided a vehicle in this regard. The sunsetting and remaking of the Ordinance would therefore have provided Parliament with a proper mechanism for periodic scrutiny of the matter, particularly in the light of information on legal rights, compensation schemes and medical developments, which the Minister agreed should be tabled regularly in the Senate.

A sunset clause was put into the Ordinance in 1986, but in December 1986 this was repealed without consultations with the Committee. The then newly responsible Minister for Territories, the Hon. Gordon Scholes, M.P., agreed in May 1987 to renew the undertaking and place another sunset clause in the Ordinance and supply periodic tabling information for Senators on legal, compensation and medical developments. This undertaking has not been implemented. In its Eighty-third Report in April 1988 the Committee stated that it would report on this matter to the Senate and that is the purpose of this statement.

The Committee has now received a letter from the new Minister for the Arts and Territories, the Hon. Gary Punch, M.P., seeking to be released from the undertaking to sunset the Ordinance, in view of the fact that the government's Green Paper on AIDS will soon be tabled and it will provide a new point of focus for parliamentary consideration of the AIDS problem including the question of the legal and compensation rights of medically acquired AIDS victims. The Committee has agreed to release the Minister from the undertaking he inherited but it has also asked him to continue periodically to supply Parliament with documentary information for tabling, by the Committee if necessary, on legal, compensation and medical developments.

Up to this point the Committee has been seeking the agreement of successive Ministers to place repeating sunset clauses in the Ordinance to ensure that progress in looking at legal and compensation issues was expedited and to enable Parliament to exercise the option of being involved in that process by having available to it tabled information about legal and compensation rights, and by having a newly tabled Ordinance each year on which to base some measure of parliamentary scrutiny. The imminence of the government's Green Paper relieves the Committee of the need to continue to press for that as the means of directly involving the Parliament.

However, it should be noted that a written undertaking to amend the Ordinance was given in May 1986 and was not honoured. The situation has now changed because of the expected Green Paper. The Committee is content therefore first, to release the new Minister, Mr Punch, from his inherited undertaking and second, to recognise that the unsatisfactory way in which the Committee's concerns have been addressed is not a matter for which he is deserving of criticism since he has only recently taken up the reins of a complex portfolio.

Nevertheless responsibility for not bringing this matter to the attention of successive Ministers lies somewhere. Some officials within the A.C.T. Administration or the A.C.T. Health Authority are responsible for not acting promptly to ensure that a busy Minister's attention was drawn to the need to implement a written undertaking which had been given to a parliamentary committee in May 1987. The Committee hopes that any responsible officials can be properly counselled about the need to assist Ministers to implement undertakings to Parliament as quickly as practicable.

Acting solely in the context of the Blood Donation Ordinance, the Committee's bipartisan concern has been that the rights of medically acquired AIDS victims should be carefully and quickly assessed and reasonably and humanely protected, and that the rights of Parliament to be involved in that process in order to underwrite an agreed outcome should be respected. As far as the Blood Donation Ordinance is concerned neither of these ends have been met as quickly or effectively as the Committee would have expected. As it relieves the Committee of its continuing obligations it is to be hoped that the Green Paper will, among other things, help to achieve these two vital aims.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also seek leave to table, for the information of honourable senators and others, the Committee's correspondence, including documents which the Minister has sent to the Committee describing legal, compensation and medical developments regarding AIDS. This is important information of great significance to all who are concerned about the problems of AIDS generally and medically acquired AIDS in particular.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to deal with Notices of Motion Nos 2 and 3 together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the World Heritage Properties Conservation Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1988 No. 47 and made under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983, be disallowed.

That the Declaration in the Proclamation, made by the Governor-General under subsection 6 (3) of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 and published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette No. S95 of 31 March 1988, be disapproved.

The motions for disallowance and disapproval of certain proclamations and declarations made in relation to the World Heritage listed areas of north Queensland give the Government a last opportunity to reconsider what it is doing to the fabric of part of our nation and to the integrity of our polity. The Opposition is at one with the Government and indeed with all thinking Australians in wanting to preserve our environment and, in particular, our unique tropical rainforests. But in doing so this Government has reduced communities of decent hard-working Australians to a state of fear, uncertainty and hatred and has sought to promote political divisions and disharmony where none existed nor needed to exist. It has sought to use a conflict with a politically opposed State in order to advance its own political fortunes in Sydney and Melbourne and to make one section, one region and one small group of people pay more than their fair share of the genuine community cost of environment protection. In so doing this Government has lied about its purposes. It has lied about its methods. It has lied about its solutions, and it has lied about the very area which it claims to be seeking to preserve. Most reprehensibly of all, it has devalued the very concept of a World Heritage listing by using it not as a legitimate tool to protect the environment but as an illegitimate tool to subvert the Constitution, not to advance the cause and public support for environment protection but to set back that cause and in the process to put the fragile Australian environment at even greater risk.

I want to deal first with the question of this Government's dishonesty in the way in which it deals with the States and to indicate the extent to which the word of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), conveyed in writing to the Premier of Queensland, is absolutely worthless. Let me start, however, with the agreement entered into between the Government of Queensland and the Commonwealth, through the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers (CONCOM), in July 1984. At that CONCOM meeting an agreement was reached between the Commonwealth and the State which said in part:
The Commonwealth Government has indicated that it will not take unilateral action to nominate areas for World Heritage Listing without the agreement of the State or Territory concerned.

In other words, the Commonwealth agreed formally at a meeting of Commonwealth and State Ministers not to nominate areas without the consent of the State concerned. That undertaking has been dishonoured. Mr Cohen, the then Minister, in an address to open the National Conference on Conservation and the Economy in September 1984 said:
. . . that . . . would consult with the relevant state before it nominated new areas for inclusion on the World Heritage List.

That consultation did not take place. This nomination proceeded in defiance of the Minister's clear assurance. On 12 September 1984, the Prime Minister wrote to the Premier of Queensland. I quote from the Prime Minister's letter:
It is not the intention of my Government to take unilateral action to nominate the region for World Heritage Listing.
That unequivocal commitment in writing from the Prime Minister was dishonoured.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unless he did it unintentionally.

—Yes, but as I propose to demonstrate, I believe it was done because it was never the intention of Senator Richardson to honour the commitment given by Mr Cohen on two occasions, or the commitment given by the Prime Minister. Again, Senator Ryan replied on notice to a question in this place on 11 February 1986. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has made it clear that the wet tropic rainforests of north-east Queensland will only be nominated for inclusion on the World Heritage List with the agreement of the Queensland Government.

Finally, on 12 November 1987 at a meeting of the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers in Perth at which Senator Richardson was present, a resolution was adopted which said in part that the Council resolved to:

Reaffirm the procedures established in Resolution 198 (1984 meeting of Council) that as a matter of principle nominations by the Commonwealth for World Heritage listing should be undertaken in consultation with the States and Territories.

Here we have quite clearly set out a formal agreement between the Commonwealth and the States at the CONCOM meeting of 1984; a formal commitment given by the then Minister, Mr Cohen; a letter written by the Prime Minister to the Premier of Queensland; an answer given on notice by Senator Ryan in this chamber; and a resolution of November 1987. Each of these has been systematically dishonoured, repudiated, denied and lied about by this Government in its dealings on this matter. It is clear that the word of the Prime Minister, given in writing to the Government of Queensland, the resolutions of Commonwealth and State Ministers, the words of a Minister of the environment, the words of a senior Cabinet Minister in this chamber in relation to the way this Government would proceed, are meaningless. The Prime Minister's assurance in writing to a Premier of a State is not worth the paper it is written on, as far as this Government is concerned.

It is interesting to see exactly the way this Government treats not just the governments of Australia, but other people in Australia. Senator Burns is, I believe, a senator representing the State of Queensland. In terms of what he has to say about people in that area working in the timber industry, let me quote what he said in this place on 17 February 1988:

I would challenge anybody in this chamber or elsewhere to suggest that timber-getters and loggers in the past 100 years have given a damn about our environment or about the trees and conservation of any part of this country. All they were concerned about was cutting down logs and making a quid. They were not concerned about future generations or if there would be anything left.

In other words, the timber workers, the hard-working people who depend for their livelihood on the preservation of the forest resources of Australia, are subject to the sort of abuse that we get from Senator Richardson, Senator Burns and representatives of the Australian Labor Party. It is no wonder that in Queensland Mr Peter Beattie, the Secretary of the Labor Party in that State, is reduced to making attacks upon Senator Richardson, saying that he has handled this whole matter in a crude way, that this is something more than a factional brawl in Sydney and that when it comes to dealing with peoples' livelihoods he is prepared to describe Senator Richardson, as he did in the AM transcript of 4 December 1987, as `a political coward'. That is precisely correct because as I have said, the assurances given by Prime Ministers, by Ministers and by Commonwealth-State agreements are worthless to this Government and it is left to somebody like Mr Peter Beattie in Queensland to have to try to stand up for people in the Labor Party in that State against Senator Richardson and his lackies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I call your attention to standing order 438, which has to do with disorderly conduct. Senator Puplick habitually puts his feet on the furniture in this place. I think that is disorderly conduct. I hope that you will reprimand him for this act.
—There is no point of order. I ask Senator Puplick to respect the furniture.
—Madam Acting Deputy President--
—Madam Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: He is defying your ruling.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, you ruled that there was no point of order. I suggest that if Senator Sanders continues to disrupt the proceedings of this chamber by indicating that he challenges the ruling that you have given as to this particular matter it is he who ought to be dealt with.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, the representatives of people in that particular part of Australia have made it clear that they do not go along with the way in which this Minister has acted in this matter. It is of great interest to know that just at the moment this Government is promoting a referendum to secure the recognition of local government, presumably because it believes that local government has some particular role to play in our legal and constitutional structures. Yet clearly the advice of local government in that part of Queensland is set against the course of action which this Minister has undertaken. The submission by the Douglas Shire Council on World Heritage nomination of the area for which it is responsible says, in part:
The Council wishes to record its strong objection to the intransigent attitude of the Federal Government on this issue.

If honourable senators look at the submission of October 1987, from the Shire of Hinchinbrook on this particular matter, they will see that it criticises Senator Richardson for his lack of consultation in the matter. It says of Senator Richardson's behaviour:
This is not consultation but rather an overbearing dispassionate approach to the problem.

The people affected are entitled to be heard but when questions asked of the Senator as was done at his `consultation' with local authorities in Cairns on 6th October 1987, the Senator was unable properly to appreciate the degree of affection the people and North Queensland would experience from the proposed listing and restricted himself to dogmatic assertions on behalf of his government.

In other words, not only do we now see that ministerial assurances are worthless, but all of this nonsense that the Minister and his Government are going on with about the role and importance of local government is turned on its head when he does not get from local government the sort of advice that he wants to hear on this particular matter. This whole exercise has been undertaken by the Government, not for the protection of the rainforest resources of north Queensland but for the protection of certain marginal seats held by the Labor Party in Sydney and Melbourne. This has been quite clear. It goes back a long way. An article in the Sydney Morning Herald of March 1986 headed `The greening of the ALP' indicated that Mr, now Senator, McMullan had been known to have put the point about that. The article states:
. . . in a series of briefings with Ministers last month he stressed that the three major issues the Government should be tackling this year were improving the export position of farmers-
what a laugh that is-
youth unemployment-
which goes backwards under this Government-
and environmental issues.
An article on 25 March 1987, headed `ALP cultivates the joys of nature in order to capture the green vote', states:

The right-wing factional power broker, Senator Graham Richardson, is particularly concerned to head off any moves to form a green party in Australia, which he believes would be particularly damaging to the ALP support base.

In June 1987 Senator McMullan, Mr McMullan as he then was, was quoted in Time magazine to exactly the same purport. In the end, of course, even that tactic will not save the Labor Party as far as this is concerned. By the time we had come to February 1988 we had the headings, `Richardson Betrayed Greenies' and `Wilderness Chief Warns Government'. Of course he did. We find that Mr Snow, the honourable member for Eden-Monaro, Mr Kerin, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, and Senator Button, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, are all concerned about the lack of balance which Senator Richardson has brought to its environmental policies.

We see constant stories about the extent to which this Minister is having to defend his position from his own Party colleagues, because they realise that the proper demands of balance in terms of environment protection and the protection of jobs are simply being ignored by Senator Richardson. We see situations developing in which Dr Klugman, the honourable member for Prospect in the House of Representatives, describes the various claims by the Wilderness Society on this matter as being claims from people whom he characterises as `absolute liars'. We have Mr Kerin saying that the Government should stop pandering to the greenie vote. We see him quoted as saying that in the newspapers and we hear him saying it in radio interviews. We hear Mr Carr, the unlamented former Minister for the Environment in New South Wales, saying that the environment movement was ungrateful for what that Government supposedly had done for it.

In other words, a large part of this debate turns simply upon the Labor Party's political strategy directed towards Sydney and Melbourne, not something which is properly directed towards the preservation of the environment, so much so that we get a statement that this Government has now had to establish a series of interdepartmental committees on forest resource management and on conservation and land use policies in order to try to resolve the difficulties within this Government in terms of the extent to which Senator Richardson clearly does not have the support of senior Cabinet colleagues for the policy which he is putting forward. In putting forward that policy for his own particular factional preservation there are a large number of areas of the environment which he is putting particularly at risk.

If one turns to the consultants' reports, which this Minister has made so much of in relation to north Queensland, one can get an idea of some of the problems which have been engendered for people in that region as a result of the Government's activities. If one looks at the report entitled World Heritage Listing of Queensland's Wet Tropical Rainforest: Assessment of Social Impact, undertaken by Dr Gibson and his colleagues, one will see these comments:

The advent of World Heritage Listing has produced an environment of economic and financial uncertainty. This negative atmosphere has resulted in a number of quite concrete effects. For example, in the financial sphere, banks are discouraging investment in the area, advising against capital improvements and/or further business expansion and withdrawing monies from on-going business transactions that are deemed (by the bank) to be financially insecure.

It seems that World Heritage listing has created not only specific impacts but also a tense atmosphere in which residents are fearful of becoming unemployed, perhaps being dependent upon welfare, and not being able to meet financial commitments, for example, mortgage repayments. The report continues:
Since the advent of World Heritage Listing, however, community and family relations have become strained.

So it goes on. I can fully understand why Senator Sanders is not in the least concerned about this. In the whole of his period in this chamber, Senator Sanders has never once demonstrated the slightest degree of concern about the rights and livelihoods of individual Australians. He has never once expressed in this chamber the slightest degree of concern for the welfare of individual Australians. It is, therefore, absolutely no surprise that he finds himself at one with Senator Richardson on this matter, and that the Minister and his Government have displayed the same degree of cavalier disregard for the rights and welfare of individual Australians in north Queensland.

The whole of the area which has been nominated for World Heritage listing is, in itself, an interesting area to examine. It is not as if the whole area constitutes wet tropical rainforest. In fact, in an answer given to me at the Senate Estimates inquiry the other day, it was demonstrated that the rainforest proper comprised less than 80 per cent of the areas that are actually within the indicative boundaries. Within that 80 per cent, it is clear that there are enormous variations in areas which are of real sensitivity and quality, such as those at Bloomfield, Cape Tribulation and in the immediate Daintree region, and those which are environmentally, scientifically and aesthetically of far less worth.

Anyone who is familiar with that part of the world knows from travelling through it that we are not talking about one area of uniform integrity and uniform values. In an area stretching, as it does, the same sort of distance as between this capital city and the city of Melbourne, it would be unrealistic if that were to be expected to be the case. Nevertheless, the land grab that the Government has undertaken with this listing pays no attention and no regard to those significant variations.
Honourable senators interjecting-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Patterson

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President: I draw your attention to standing order 422, which states:

INTERJECT.PARA: No Senator shall interrupt another Senator whilst speaking, unless (1.) to request that his words be taken down; (2.) to call attention to a Point of Order or Privilege suddenly arising, or (3.) to call attention to the want of a Quorum.
I ask that you draw the chamber to order since Senator Puplick has been interrupted on far too many occasions during his speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Puplick has been interrupted from both sides of the House. I ask that senators moderate their interjections.

—I hope that you, Madam Acting Deputy President, will not characterise the Australian Democrats as `both sides of the House'. As the fourth organised faction of the Australian Labor Party, there is no reason they should be characterised as being on anything other than one side of the House.
—Organised? You have to be joking.

—On the basis of Senator Collins's valid interjection, I withdraw the word `organised'. A number of responsible commentators, scientists and experts have made it quite clear that there are alternate ways in which this particular problem could have been addressed and in which the preservation of the most important parts of the tropical rainforests could have been secured. Of those, one of the most significant is the submission from the Institute of Foresters of Australia. That is a responsible group of people, who made a submission entitled `A case for practical ``wet tropics'' World Heritage listing', in which it was stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Institute of Foresters supports a World Heritage listing of North East Queensland tropical rainforests based on a practical land use plan which protects virgin rainforest while providing for limited resource utilisation, (eg recreation, mining, selective logging and forest plantations on relatively small zoned areas.

Is Senator Schacht still laughing his fool head off about that comment? It is interesting that when one raises the name `Institute of Foresters', automatically those who know nothing, care about nothing and have been part of this Labor regime start laughing. If one were to ask about the quality of forest management in Senator Schacht's State of South Australia, one would get a series of odd answers. Once one says that here is a responsible group associated with the industry comprised of people with skill, ability and a long term commitment to preserving the forest resources, Senator Schacht starts laughing and carrying on because he is not prepared to listen to good scientific advice when it is put before him. His political prejudice will not allow him to be swayed by fact, evidence, science or argument. That is what this debate is all about; it is about the failure of the Government to be swayed by the evidence put clearly before it. One could continue to deal with a large number of matters relating to the cavalier approach of the Government to the whole problem in north Queensland. The Opposition has made abundantly clear its commitment to the protection of areas that are genuinely sensitive and genuinely worthy of protection. That is not in dispute.

At pages 752 and 753 of Hansard of 15 March in this place the alternate approach the Opposition would have taken to this matter is set out in detail based upon the discussions that were held between Premier Ahern, Senator Stone, Mr Peacock and me. At that meeting we were able to put together a package which clearly would have achieved the objectives of environmental protection of those areas genuinely worthy of support.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what you said last year.
—That is precisely what I said last year because in a Press statement I issued last year I said:

SPEECH.PARA: I have expressed the belief that the Queensland wet tropical forests are worthy of inclusion on the World Heritage list: they are unique; they are of international significance; they contain one of the greatest and scientifically most significant concentrations of unique flora and fauna in the world. Australia is the only industrialised country with remaining tropical rainforests and we have a responsibility to protect them.

Last Friday I stated that `the ideal and proper solution would be for the Government of Queensland and the Commonwealth to support the World Heritage listing of agreed upon areas of significance'. I reject the Labor Party's unilateralist approach.
I repeat that view today and I stress the word `agreed'. In my speech on 15 March I set out clearly and in detail exactly what the Opposition's alternative plan provided for.

Perhaps having started the debate by quoting what Mr Cohen originally said, it would be only right and proper to come back to his views at the end of the debate. Writing in the Bulletin of 24 May 1988, Mr Cohen said the following about World Heritage listing:
I was even more vigorously opposed to its misuse-
that is, World Heritage listing-
by adding areas as a means of blocking state governments' environmental vandalism. Those battles had to be fought through other methods.
He concluded that article by saying:
If the World Heritage Act falls into disrepute, it will have destroyed the most effective weapon we have to protect Australians' and some of the world's outstanding natural and cultural treasures.
Senator Richardson is dragging the World Heritage Act into political disrepute in Queensland, Tasmania and throughout this country.

The Opposition parties have made it clear that they are fully in support of the proper use of the World Heritage listing of areas of this country. Indeed, under the Fraser Government, significant parts of this country were entered on the World Heritage List without rancour and without acrimony. They were entered on that list, including the Great Barrier Reef, in consultation with the State governments concerned, together with plans of management and financial arrangements being devised which were appropriate in the circumstances. They included areas in Tasmania, New South Wales, the Northern Territory and Queensland and we, in government, made effective use of World Heritage listing for those unique areas without rancour, without public discord and without disregard for the rights of either the States, local government or the affected individuals. It is only under this Government that World Heritage listing has ceased to be a tool of environmental management and has become a tool of political weaponry, as far as this Government is concerned, in relation to States with whom it has disagreements. It will not do it when it comes to Shark Bay, for example, because the Minister has already made a deal with the Western Australian Government not to cause them political aggravation as far as that listing is concerned.

That is the attitude that this Minister takes. He will do deals with his political friends and use World Heritage listing as an instrument against his political opponents. That is what the Opposition parties are primarily opposed to and it is the primary reason for moving for the disallowance of both the proclamation made by the Governor-General and the regulations made in relation to the wet tropical rainforests of north-east Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Puplick, before I call the next speaker I seek some clarification. In seeking leave for the two motions to be dealt with together did you intend that they be voted on together?
—I would be perfectly happy to do that.
—I call Senator Sanders.
—I bow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank my colleague on the other side of the Senate for his enthusiastic welcome. We have just heard half an hour of the greatest hypocrisy that has ever besmirched the beautiful timbers of this chamber.
—Do you have a passport?

—Is that an ethnic slur? We who are here by choice, rather than by accident of birth, take great pride in the Australian environment. I am afraid that the spokesperson for the environment for the Liberal Party of Australia, Senator Puplick, has no feeling at all for the environment. He talks pure politics. Senator Puplick has blown once and for all any chance that the Liberals have ever had of convincing anyone in this country that they have any environmental concern. If Senator Stone had made this speech I would have understood it. I would have understood where he was coming from and what he was on about and it would have been in line with his Opposition Party's policies. But Senator Puplick is the man who is supposed to re-establish the credentials of the Opposition in the environmental area. He has a long way to go. He may have convinced the mining companies of his loyalty, he may have pledged his fealty to the woodchippers and anyone else who would despoil the environment, but I am afraid that he will not win any sensible votes from people concerned about the future of Australia with that speech.

SPEECH.PARA: Basically, what he is doing is what we have learned to recognise in Tasmania over the last 10 years as sheer demagoguery. He is doing the same as Robin Gray has done. He is using the people of northern Queensland as Robin Gray used the people of South West Tasmania, and Tasmania in general, as pawns in a purely political game-a cynical political ploy. The people in north Queensland and in Tasmania have nothing to fear from World Heritage listings. World Heritage listings are eagerly sought in the rest of the world. Why? Because a World Heritage listing is the key to prosperity in terms of tourism.

Being on the World Heritage route means that people are aware of the area. They come to see it. North Queensland had no future in the timber industry. Everyone in north Queensland knows that. The timber industry was dying. Senator Richardson nods in agreement. If the Queensland Government, the Queensland National Party and people such as Senator Puplick had not continually stirred up the local people, and harped on the negative aspects of the World Heritage listing, but instead had talked about the positive aspects, there would be no disagreement now. The disagreement was not caused by the Federal Government. It was not caused by the World Heritage listing. It was caused by those who wanted to make political gain out of what they could stir up in the area.

This happened in Tasmania. Robin Gray came to power on just such tactics and used them ever since. But what happened in Tasmania once the World Heritage listing was made and the system was in operation? Places like Strahan in Tasmania had been stirred into a fever pitch of hatred against the greenies. People were beaten up. Bob Brown was beaten up. Numbers of people were assaulted by the local people because Robin Gray had stirred them into such a fever pitch. What has happened now? They say that it is the best thing that ever happened to the place. It has caused a tourist industry to develop, which is employing far more people than any of the hydro projects ever could. This will happen in north Queensland, in spite of what Senator Puplick has said. It will happen because the Government is sticking to its guns and will not back down in the face of the threats of political violence and physical violence that come from north Queensland and from people like Senator Boswell, who will follow me in this debate and who, I am sure, will tell us the same-

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. I have been accused of inciting political and physical violence. I have never, at any stage, promoted violence. I ask the honourable senator to withdraw those words. I find them offensive and untrue.

—Certainly, I withdraw `physical violence'. I have never encountered Senator Boswell in the field. I do not know whether he has been threatening physical violence. I sincerely hope that he has not. I have no proof of that.
—I ask the honourable senator to withdraw.
—I withdraw the term `physical violence', but `political violence' perhaps should stand. Political violence is a different matter.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I take another point of order. I have never incited political violence, either. I have merely pointed out the injustices of this World Heritage listing. I ask you to call for a complete withdrawal. I ask that both the terms `physical violence' and `political violence' be withdrawn from Senator Sanders's contribution.
—Senator Sanders, are you prepared to withdraw?

—I think it could be argued that we engage in political violence every time we stand up in this chamber. I feel that political violence is any violence done to the political system. Any time an opposition, for instance, wants to unseat a government, it would be political violence. Unless the Chair rules that `political violence' is an offensive term, I wish that it would stand.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I call another point of order. I ask for your ruling on the words `political violence'. I do not accept that I have ever incited political violence.
—It is a form of words which has no strict definition. As Senator Boswell finds it offensive, I ask Senator Sanders to withdraw it.

—In the interests of senatorial camaraderie, and in the hope that all of us are working in the best interests of the people of Australia, I withdraw the comment, as the honourable senator finds it offensive.

SPEECH.PARA: We have been listening to Senator Puplick saying, `Aha! This dreaded Government has been listening to the people, has been reacting to the voices of the people, and thus has gone ahead with this World Heritage listing'. What a terrible government it is that listens to the voice of the people and does what the people want! I suppose we could take it that if the Opposition came to power it would not listen to the voice of the people. It would simply steamroll the voice of the people. I think it is wonderful that Senator Richardson feels that he should listen to the people. Why should he not do so? That is why we are here. That is what we are supposed to do. Perhaps it is so unusual for a government to listen to the voice of the people that it was singled out by Senator Puplick. I find it a healthy thing. If the people of Melbourne, Sydney, Wagga, Hobart or anywhere want World Heritage listing of an area of Australia which, after all, belongs to all of us, why should that not occur?

As far as I can see, the Government has always given the people of north Queensland great consideration; it has offered them compensation packages and made numerous trips to the area. Senator Richardson has made trips to the area to try to explain the Government package. I, too, have made statements about the people of north Queensland, the people of Tasmania and people anywhere who are affected by a World Heritage listing or any other environmental listing. It turns out generally that environmental considerations simply ensure that the people of an area will have a place to live and work in in the future. The way we are going now with all of our exploitation schemes, we will rip it out of the ground now and who cares what happens in five years time. It turns out that the conservationists are really the conservatives; they want to conserve society. It is the get-rich-quick artists like Senator Puplick who would have us destroy it immediately and let future generations take care of themselves. The conservationists want the future generations to be provided for. I believe that the World Heritage listing does such a thing.

We hear emotive terms such as `land grab' as if Senator Richardson has grabbed this land, is going to put a fence around it and not let anybody else get in. That is not so at all. It is not a land grab. It merely outlines an area which is of world significance. The Government will do everything in its power to make sure that any developments in that area are commensurate with the World Heritage listing. It is not a land grab. It is not a Federal Government takeover of State land. It is simply a means of preserving something for the future. It is nowhere near as draconian, incidentally, as the United States national parks legislation. When Yellowstone-one of the first national parks to be established-came into being in the 1870s, it was managed for some years by a commissionaire who was selling, as Senator Puplick probably would, mineral rights, timber and trapping rights. The United States Congress heard about this and was so incensed that it removed him from his position and sent in the United States cavalry, which ruled Yellowstone National Park for 30 years with drawn sabres and guns. That is the way to protect an area. Senator Richardson, however, relies upon his sharp wit rather than a sharpened blade to preserve this area for pos- terity. The Australian Democrats do not support Senator Puplick's motion. We feel that the World Heritage listing is a great step forward. Future generations will admire the stand taken by this Government and will look back with some wonder at any opposition which could suggest that a World Heritage listing for the wet tropics was not an entirely good thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Black Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Sanders for his contribution. I am pleased that out of consideration to this side of the chamber he kept it reasonably brief. I listened with some sympathy to Senator Puplick's contribution. I am surprised, if he was so pleased to be identified with the National Party of Australia on this issue, that he did not actually debate it last week when it could have been broadcast to all his supporters in north Queensland. I am sure that the fact that this is not a broadcast day, as it normally would be, had absolutely nothing to do with it.
—It was deferred because I asked for it to be.

—Right. It has been established in this place many times already that the nomination of the World Heritage listing of the wet tropics was the only option that the Federal Government had left if these valuable rainforests were to be retained intact for future generations. On the other hand, all that we have heard from the Queensland Government is its record of neglect, mismanagement and political opportunism. There is no doubt that without the intervention of the Federal Government the Queensland Government's policy of development at whatever the cost would have eventually destroyed a region with universally recognised natural values.

SPEECH.PARA: The decision to nominate the wet tropics for World Heritage listing was made in response to the Queensland Government's absolute determination to continue logging the north Queensland rainforests. This determination is despite the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources calling, as long ago as 1984, on both the Queensland and Federal governments to recognise the value of the area and nominate it for World Heritage listing. Last year, 65 per cent of the nominations before the World Heritage Committee were passed. The Federal Government is confident that the wet tropics will be approved for nomination when the Committee meets in November. Our best evidence suggests that the region meets all four of the criteria that have been set down for the establishment of outstanding universal value. Yet, even after the nomination, the Queensland Government made it absolutely clear it was not prepared to alter its normal forestry management practices.

In the Federal Government's view, the planned recommencement of forestry operations with the start of the dry season in April-and the Queensland Government's refusal to police such operations adequately-would have posed a severe threat to the natural values of the area. This is the reason that we moved to provide the area with interim protection, by amending the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act. The World Heritage Committee is currently making its independent assessment of the area. If the Committee refuses to inscribe all, or even part, of the area nominated for World Heritage listing, protection under the amendments to the World Heritage Conservation Act will cease. But it must be agreed that we cannot allow the ridiculous situation to develop where this valuable area is irreparably damaged in the year of nomination. It is clear from Senator Puplick's motion that he is determined to assist those members of the National Party, the Queensland Government and the timber industry who wish to indulge in the wholesale destruction of the area while there is still a chance to do so.

It is fairly simple, although obviously not for some members of the Opposition, to realise the Queensland Government's motives for opposing an important initiative such as the World Heritage listing of the wet tropical rainforests. I remind honourable senators that not only was the Australian Government willing to take on the Queensland Government over nomination of the wet tropics, but also it was prepared to meet its responsibilities to those workers and businesses affected by the listing. The Queensland Government has also been generating misinformation on this issue. Senator Richardson recently detailed a compensation package worth more that $75m that will ensure the future of both the workers affected by the World Heritage listing and the region itself. This package includes a sum of $50.9m which over a three-year period will be directed to job-creating private and community initiatives. A labour adjustment package will be funded by the Federal Government at a cost of $6.5m. This includes an immediate payout of a $2,500 dislocation allowance to all eligible workers. This package also includes redundancy payments of up to $30,000 for workers 55 years and older. I assure honourable senators that it is a damned sight better than they would ever receive from the timber industry. Wage subsidies of about $100 per week will be available to workers for a period of up to 26 weeks. A training allowance of $30 per week, plus unemployment benefits, will be made available for a period of up to 13 weeks.

The Federal Government will also provide relocation assistance, including fares and removal expenses for workers taking up employment in other locations. The Government has allocated $24.4m in compensation for companies and businesses directly and substantially affected by the cessation of logging in the World Heritage area. Payments will be made to those businesses which had been logging within the World Heritage area and to other businesses, such as logging contractors, sleeper cutters, supplies and rainforest timber users. The continued operation of the Associated Plywood Sales mill at Ravenshoe has been assured, through a series of payments from the Federal Government to meet the cost of retooling the mill to enable it to process plantation timbers. The Federal Government is confident this will ensure the future of the town of Ravenshoe. As a result of all of these initiatives, 600 jobs will be created because of the World Heritage listing. A further 240 workers will take up adjustment measures provided by the Commonwealth.

I make the point that the Federal Government's job creation initiatives and adjustment assistance will not ignore the 100 workers affected by a recent reduction in the Queensland Forestry Department's timber quota. While these jobs would have been lost irrespective of the World Heritage listing, those 100 workers will be entitled to take advantage of the initiatives that I have just outlined. The Queensland Government and the Opposition have both chosen to ignore the fact that some logging operations will continue in north Queensland, outside the World Heritage boundaries. Consultants have advised the Federal Government that the Associated Plywood Sales mill at Ravenshoe and another five mills could remain open. These mills employ about 200 workers and represent about one-quarter of the existing timber milling industry.

Amid all its campaigning against the World Heritage nomination and the Federal Government's compensation package, the Queensland Government has consistently refused to acknowledge that the north Queensland timber industry has, in fact, been declining for the past decade. The Queensland Forestry Department claims that its Crown rainforest annual timber quota of 60,000 cubic metres can be sustained for all time. Yet since the 1960s the Department's sustained yield predictions have been reducing at an alarming rate. In 1960 the Department said that surveys proved that the forests could sustain the then annual production in north Queensland of between 240,000 and 270,000 cubic metres. By 1975 this estimate was reduced by about 30 per cent. Estimates of the long term sustainable yield then ranged from 160,000 to 200,000 cubic metres. Six years later, in 1981, this figure was cut in half, to 80,000 cubic metres. In 1986, the estimated yield was further reduced to the current figure of 60,000. Not only did the estimate reduce by 20,000 cubic metres, but the aggregate land base on which the estimate rests was expanded by 15,000 hectares. That is hardly a picture of a industry with a long term future.

This planning procedure by the Queensland Forestry Department involved no public participation and, indeed, the Department is reluctant to divulge any significant details about how its final quota was arrived at. No-one even knows, for example, the details of the land base to which the calculations apply. So it is little wonder that there is widespread doubt, even among the Department's own staff, about the viability of forest management and the rainforest timber industry. I quote Mr Vic Stockwell, who worked as a ranger in the north Queensland rainforests for almost 30 years and in that time gained a pretty good idea about how the system really worked. Mr Stockwell said that forestry officers were often under enormous pressure from representatives of milling companies. He confirmed that the Queensland Forestry Department never had an effective rainforest management plan. In Mr Stockwell's experience--

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that Stockwell or Stocker?
—Stockwell. I have the article here for Senator Boswell, if he is interested in reading it. I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: The Department of Forestry had rules but no-one ever took any notice of them and there were enormous breaches of departmental rules.

So much for the Queensland Government's forestry management plan. Up to 40 per cent of jobs in the north Queensland timber industry had been abolished prior to the World Heritage nomination. The State Government has made no effort to compensate these workers and neither have the employers. Rather, the Queensland Government has attempted to mislead the timber workers into thinking that had the World Heritage listing not gone ahead their jobs would have been assured, whereas in fact it would only have been a matter of time before economics would have forced the closure of the north Queensland mills and there would have been no compensation forthcoming from the National Party State Government. All that it has sought is someone to blame for something that was going to happen anyway.

Senator Richardson has already stated that the Commonwealth requires only cooperation from the Queensland Government to ensure the economic prosperity of north Queensland following the World Heritage nomination. Yet recent events have confirmed that the Federal Government cannot depend on any such cooperation. I will give honourable senators a few examples. Take the case of Douglas Simms, a sawmiller, and William Quaid, a timber cutter, who will both appear in the Cairns Magistrates Court next month on charges of illegally removing rainforest trees from the Cape Tribulation National Park last year. If found guilty, they could be fined $1,000 under State laws. Yet the Queensland Government is considering buying the timber-valued at $100,000-that Simms and Quaid are alleged to have removed from the park. As my colleague the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) has pointed out, such an offer could prove the State Government guilty of receiving stolen goods.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not going to buy the timber, they are taking it over.

—I understand why Senator Boswell is sticking up for them. Australian Electoral Commission records show that Simms donated $1,000 to the Queensland National Party. I applaud Senator Boswell's loyalty to the donor of $1,000 to the National Party last year. Consider also the Queensland Government's support for the construction of a road proposed by the developer George Quaid to be constructed through the proposed World Heritage boundaries. The road would run from Southedge Lake, between Mount Molloy and Mareeba, to Wangetta on the coast, 40 kilometres north of Cairns. This little atrocity has been welcomed by the Queensland Northern Development Minister, Mr Bob Katter, Jr, who has described the road as `a great thing' for north Queensland. My Queensland colleagues in this place will be familiar with the Queensland Government's approach to environmentally threatening development. Valuable areas of land, particularly along the Queensland coast, are constantly under threat from developments approved by the Queensland Government without any consideration for the environment. Much has been said about the procedures used by the Queensland Government to facilitate such developments, particularly controversial developments proposed by National Party members or their friends or relatives. These special ministerial rezonings were commonplace under the former Premier and they have been retained in principle by his successor, Mike Ahern, despite his `vision of excellence', as he terms it, which I and an increasing number of State National Party backbenchers, including Yvonne Chapman, have been anxiously waiting to arrive. A ministerial rezoning is an arrangement whereby the State Government intervenes in the rezoning applications of privileged developers. Applications are approved by the Queensland Executive Council. The objections of local authorities, interest groups or individuals are completely ignored. These select applicants are saved the considerable cost normally incurred in a rezoning application. Sadly, the people of Queensland have been led to believe that the `clean broom' Mike Ahern claimed he would be sweeping through the Queensland Government would see the end of this particular form of cronyism. In fact, the Queensland Local Government Minister, Mr Randell, ordered a freeze on applications for ministerial rezonings in December. But recent events have proved the freeze was no more than a publicity stunt. Had the Queensland Government not demonstrated such an appalling disregard for both the environment and the rights of ordinary Queenslanders, legislation such as we are debating here today would not have been necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind all honourable senators that the Federal Government's entire package of job creation, labour adjustment assistance and business compensation will require no funds from Queensland. That is probably fortunate. The Federal Government is well accustomed to the misdealings of the Queensland Government when it comes to matters involving Federal and State funds. The Queensland Government's notorious misuse of Federal funds, whether it be to assist National Party cronies or to prop up that State's pretty sick economy, has been well documented in this place by me and others. Take, for example, Federal funds for the community employment program (CEP). The Queensland Government constantly abused the CEP scheme by using funds to balance the State Budget and to fund projects normally covered by Queensland Government departmental activities. A number of my colleagues have expressed concern in this place that the Queensland Government had reduced the number of its own permanent employees by employing CEP participants to carry out duties such as clerical work within the Queensland Public Service. I have raised in the Senate several times the matter of the Queensland Government's use of Commonwealth funds, supplied under the natural disaster relief arrangements, to assist National Party favourites.

Then there is the matter of the Queensland Public Service Board report last year which alleged the Queensland Government had deliberately overstated the number of homes built under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. Another glaring example is the Queensland Government practice of siphoning into Consolidated Revenue Federal funds loaned to the State's Rural Reconstruction Board. The Queensland Government then loaned these funds out, at a higher interest rate, to sugar millers-and called it State Government assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. The subject before the Senate is a disallowance motion on the World Heritage area. It is not a bash at the Queensland Government. All Senator Black seems to be able to do in this Senate is attack the Queensland Government. I suggest that you call him to order and make him address the point of relevance.
—I do not think there is any point of order, Senator Boswell, but I ask Senator Black to speak to the relevant disallowance motion.

—Yes, Madam Deputy President, I will be very conciliatory towards the former Queensland Government. I simply wanted to make the point that when it comes to co-operation with the Queensland Government we, as a Federal government, have to consider the cooperation we have received in the past-and we have not received any. Any money which has been handed over has been filched, siphoned off and loaned at a higher interest rate. The Queensland Government has then claimed the credit for it. That point needs to be made. The Queensland Government has been happy to use any of the funds we have made available in any way it sees fit. Yet when the Commonwealth honoured its commitment, such as protecting the north Queensland timber workers, the Queensland Government was the first to condemn the assistance package as inadequate. I ask: Is the Queensland Government prepared to assist these workers in any way? The answer of course is no. The current Queensland Premier has continued along the same reckless path that was exploited by his predecessor. In fact, in every substantial way he has proved to be simply a pale imitation of the former conservative Queensland Government Premier. The Queensland Government has shown no concern for the timber industry. That industry was declining and was destined to become bankrupt within a very short time. Mills were closing and would continue to close at a rapid rate. All the Federal Government has sought to do is conserve what is left of a very valuable international resource and to compensate fairly those workers who are going to be displaced in the short term and who would have been displaced at any event in the longer term.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard from an honourable senator who represents the Australian Workers Union faction in Queensland. I would have thought that the workers, unionists, who sent Senator Black to Canberra to protect their way of life and their interests would be terribly disappointed with the apology Senator Black has made. Instead of vigorously defending the timber industry and trying to protect the jobs of timber workers, he has sold out, as all the Australian Labor Party (ALP) members have sold out, to the greenie section of the constituency they are trying to attract. The further they go with the greenies, the further the greenies wipe their hands and say, `We are not interested; you are not giving enough'.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the whole point of the disaster that is confronting the Labor Party members as they lose contact with their grassroots support in their heartland. They are trying to outflank the Australian Democrats and to achieve that 3 per cent or 4 per cent vote. They are trying to move to the left, if that is possible, of the Democrats. Where they are failing is that they are losing about 96 per cent of their support. If the truth were known, they would rue the day they ever heard of World Heritage listing. They would like to back out of it very quickly and not have a thing to do with it. I give some advice to members of the Labor Party: leave that minority 3 per cent or 4 per cent to the Democrats. They are already working for the Labor Party and vote with it on every occasion. Those opposite should leave the Democrats their bit of constituency and coalesce happily together forever. But what they are doing now is losing their grassroots support.

We move this disallowance motion in a last ditch attempt to save a $33m industry and 2,500 workers' jobs and to protect 890,000-odd acres of the World Heritage listing area. Let that be in the hands of State and local governments that have been elected by the constituents of that area. I desperately wanted to lead in this debate today but I have yielded to my colleague Senator Puplick. As a senator from Queensland, I thought it would be wonderful if I could lead in the debate-but I yielded to Senator Puplick because he has done an excellent job on the World Heritage listing matter.

In the 1987 election campaign the ALP made a concerted push to capture and attract that greenie vote. Senator Puplick has alluded to that in his contribution. We saw advertisements that depicted trees crashing to the ground to the roar of chainsaws. The advertisements were designed to attract the conservation vote. Those opposite were trying to attract the people in Sydney and Melbourne, people who live in their three-bedroom brick homes in the suburbs of those areas; but they did not attract them. The advertisements did not really get to the bottom of what World Heritage listing is all about. In the aftermath of the election we saw the Government rush in like a bull in a china shop to get its campaign geared up to World Heritage listing.

The fact that this matter is before the Senate today really indicates that the future of north Queensland has been placed in the melting pot by the Federal Government's blind push for World Heritage listing. This Government has bungled and blustered its way through this World Heritage listing matter in its proposal to nominate the area. Instead of choosing to adopt a long term, calm, studied, rational approach, the Government has disenfranchised 2,500 workers and destroyed a $33m industry. People in north Queensland were scared when the listing was first mooted because, like the rest of Australians, they had no idea of the full extent of the proposal. Not even the Government had any real idea of how the proposal would be implemented.

Anyone daring to question Senator Richardson on the reasons for listing was not met with facts and supporting evidence. Despite Senator Richardson and his Government spending $300,000 on environmental and social impact studies, those studies became available only two or three weeks ago. So what Senator Richardson was giving us was blind rhetoric. It was only after months of pressure from the Opposition, mounted in Question Time, in debates and in Estimates committee hearings, that the results have now become publicly available. I have continually asked questions in this chamber such as: Where are the $300,000-worth of environmental and social impact studies? I was told that they were not available. I even had to mount a freedom of information campaign. When Senator Richardson found that the game was up and he had to answer us, he issued those environmental impact studies.

I have no doubt in my mind why Senator Richardson had to hide those environmental impact studies: they were all detrimental to his proposal for World Heritage listing. Let us look at some of the results of the studies. They all vindicate, to varying degrees, the concerns being expressed by the Opposition.
