The overall impression gained from the reports is that the listing will cause widespread damage to the people of north Queensland, that the Federal Government has rushed the listing proposal, that a viable timber industry could have existed without World Heritage listing and that the Federal Government cannot afford to compensate adequately those people directly affected by the proposals for the loss of their jobs and future. That is not my assessment or that of this side of the House. It is the assessment given by Senator Richardson's social and environmental impact studies, by people he and the Government commissioned to bring down reports.

At the risk of repeating Senator Puplick, I will also refer in my speech to the paragraphs of the social impact assessment of World Heritage listing carried out by the Department of Anthropology and Sociology, University of Queensland and the School of Australian Environmental Studies at Griffith University. It indicates the depth of feeling in the north Queensland local community. The study states that the people in the area considered for listing are overwhelmingly against the proposal. They are afraid, uncertain and frustrated by the Federal Government's lack of information. They do not wish to be forced into alternative employment and they doubt strongly the Government's ability to provide adequate retraining and compensation. In short, the people of north Queensland do not buy for one minute the Government's shallow promises.

The report also outlines the immediate effect of listing the proposal on the local area. Families face dislocation, with declining housing value and possible loss of mortgages. There has been a severe decline in small business profits, with banks discouraging investment and with money withdrawn from ongoing business transactions. Sales of businesses within the area have quite simply stagnated until buyers see the long term effects of the listing proposal. Children are being affected with increasing family stress, potential dislocation and break-up of existing friendships and schooling patterns. The findings of the report mirror the concerns expressed to the Federal Government from day one.

If Senator Richardson is proud of that report, I invite him to get up and say so because that is what the report has said. Senator Richardson is trying to defend the indefensible. The reports that he commissioned have attacked him vigorously. Let us put that report aside and pick up another one. More damaging is the finding by ACIL Australia Pty Ltd. It states that the rainforest based timber industry in north Queensland is an important and economically viable part of the regional economy. The Federal Government has consistently stressed that the north Queensland timber industry is on its last legs. We have just heard Senator Black say that it is on its last legs. Unfortunately the report commissioned by Senator Richardson, one of the front men in the Labor Party, disagrees with Senator Black. That is an independent report. It is not paid for by the National Party of Australia, the timber industry or the people who live in the World Heritage area. It is paid for by the Government. Where the Federal Government consistently stressed that the north Queensland timber industry is on its last legs, the report clearly indicates that the industry has an important contribution to make. In fact, the report went further in stating that the industry, given further rationalisation and modernisation, has a promising future.

Either Senator Black should withdraw his contribution and say that it is based on misinformation, or he should demand his money back from ACIL. Both cannot be right; one is either right or wrong. I suggest that the independent people would be right and Senator Black would be totally wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell that to the workers who do not have jobs there any more; they know.

—The industry, workers and the people of Australia had a promising future before this Labor Party got elected. The irony of it is that the conservatives on this side of the House are protecting the workers and the sawmillers in the timber industry who probably never voted for us in their lives. They send their men, such as Senator Black, down here to represent their interests in this Parliament and Senator Black has written them off, wiped them off, as has everyone in the ALP. The Government's own members are becoming highly embarrassed about this. Senator Button, Mr Kerin-all the Ministers-and a number of backbenchers, such as Dr Klugman, are all walking away from it and I do not blame them.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Richardson's misinformation in this regard will be a constant reminder to people throughout Australia of the danger of this Government. Senator Richardson said that the logging industry in the World Heritage area was finished, that thousands of jobs had already been lost and that it was only a matter of time before the industry was closed. Senator Richardson obviously wrote Senator Black's speech. His own consultancy report prepared by ACIL Australia Pty Ltd outlines that the industry could have continued to exist on a quota of 60,000 cubic metres provided that this quota was sustainable. The fact is that the Queensland Government, following its own long term management plan for the area, has already taken steps to reduce the timber harvest in this area from 195,000 cubic metres to 60,000 cubic metres, bringing the harvest to a figure that could sustain the industry. That is what the Queensland Government has done. The timber harvest has been voluntarily reduced from 195,000 cubic metres to 65,000 cubic metres. ACIL maintains that the industry can be viable with that capacity. Perhaps it is time to address another piece of misinformation given to this House by Senator Black. Senator Black said-I take exception to his using this House to push this misinformation -that Quaid was fined for illegally taking--

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not.
—What did he say?
—He said that it was coming up to court in a week's to two weeks time.

—The implication in his statement was that $100,000 worth of timber taken by Quaid was paid for by the Queensland Government, thus aiding and abetting someone who had done something that could have been construed as illegal. Let me put the true picture before this Senate. The $100,000 worth of timber was not bought by the Queensland Government; it was confiscated by the Queensland Government to be used in the restoration of old Queensland buildings. That is the type of misinformation we get day and night in this Senate. I say to Senator Black, `If you are not going to defend the people who elected you, if you are not going to represent the working class men and women of this nation, at least get your speech right', because the honourable senator is pushing misinformation in this Senate. Let me not get diverted on that. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) has been continually critical of the Queensland Government's management plan in the World Heritage area.
—Correct.

—I am glad to see that the Minister goes on record and says that that is correct. In the Estimates Committee on 22 October, the Minister asserted that `the State Government had mismanaged the rainforest resources'. Does Senator Richardson agree that he said that?
—I do not recall saying it, but if I did not, I should have.
—I will quote him. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: In the first instance one would say that the management plan for the forests is at fault.

He then went on to blame the Queensland Forestry Department, stating that the overall results had been appalling. Those are his words. This statement was obviously prior to his receiving the ACIL consultancy report. What does this report have to say about the Queensland Forestry Department's performance and management? These are the Minister's people. He nominated them, not us. Despite the Minister posturing to the contrary, the report found:

In more recent years, the Queensland Forestry Department's performance and sophistication in rainforest management have improved markedly to the point where it is generally agreed to be held in high regard by interstate and overseas public sector forestry organisations. The operations of logging and timber businesses are possibly the most tightly governed in the nation to ensure that public policies are adhered to at all times.

That is Senator Richardson's report from his consultancy. I know that he did not like the report. I know that he did not want to accept it, but the facts stand for themselves. The Queensland Forestry Department and the State Government have acted in a responsible manner at all times. Senator Richardson has told this Parliament and this Senate time and time again that nothing is going to be swept under the carpet. He said that he was confident that the nomination would stand up to the most rigorous examination. They did not stand up to any examination; even his own consultancy reports would not even back him up. He has said that he has read the scientific evidence and that he knew where he was heading. He certainly may have known, but he kept us in the dark. He knew that the moment those consultancy reports hit the deck they would blow the whole World Heritage area apart. That is exactly what has happened. I say to the Minister that this nomination does not stand up to the evidence and that it will not stand up to rigorous examination. His own research reports indicate the true cost of the proposal and the baseless rhetoric of the Government's arguments. Senator Richardson ought to apologise for misleading the Senate. The people of north Queensland are the ones who are being caught in the Government's vice over this issue. They are being placed in a situation where they are being forced to second guess the decision made by an outside body, the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN). The people of north Queensland are sick of the Federal Government's interference, the State Government is sick of the Federal Government's interference and the IUCN is sick of being involved in the political squabbles of this nation.

In December last year the Australian Ambassador to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO) warned the Minister, in a confidential telex, to adopt a more open approach to solving Federal and State differences on World Heritage listing. In part, the telex warned-this is in inverted commas:

`We are the only country that sends its internal difficulties to the Committee on an annual basis and to this extent appear to be gaining a bit of a reputation for eccentricity . . . Some members resent being placed in a position of having to react and to resolve matters that they think should be resolved in Australia'.

That is from the telex the Government's Ambassador to UNESCO. The problem is clear. The Federal Government has bulldozed ahead with its listing proposal without any real regard for the people of north Queensland. It has placed the IUCN committee on an unenviable position, where it is now forced to adjudicate on what is basically an internal fight-a fight by the Queensland Government to preserve in a structured manner not only the ongoing viability of the north Queensland timber industry but also the States' forestry reserves and its right to administer this land.

As all honourable senators would be aware, the IUCN evaluation team visited north Queensland in order to address the Commonwealth nomination. During the brief visit the team managed to meet not only with representatives of the States and Federal governments but also with other interested parties in north Queensland. From the information that we have received it is clear that the IUCN committee has seen through the Federal Government's shallow claims as to resource management by the Queensland State Government.

I have here a letter that makes very interesting reading. It is from a member of the IUCN evaluation team, Lawrence S. Hamilton, and is directed to someone in the timber industry. The letter states that time constraints prevented the IUCN team from personally meeting with a representative of the group. It further states that the writer is in sympathy with many of the statements made by the Institute. However, the real crux of the letter is in the concluding paragraph, which I would like to quote:

I would therefore like to assure you that the viewpoint you wished to present has been received and has been considered by the IUCN evaluation team. I hope that the recommendation which we make, which has many aspects of compromise, will have the support of your group.
The fact is that the IUCN team has not swallowed the Federal Government's proposal hook, line and sinker. It is at least prepared to accept the need for compromise.

TALK.START.PARA: —That did not sound like great support. I am not quite sure why you quoted it.

—I have the letter. I will show it to the Minister. Here it is. The IUCN is saying that it is going to go for a compromise and it is not going to take any notice of what the Minister is suggesting. Does the Minister understand it now?
—No.

—There are none so blind as those who do not want to see. Far from being horrified at the timber industry's practices in north Queensland, the IUCN team acknowledged the Queensland State Government's responsible approach to rainforest management.

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government does not have to believe me that the Queensland rainforests are being well looked after. It can choose to ignore the valid claims of the Queensland Government. But I suggest that it should take note of the IUCN. I have received information from the timber industry that the IUCN assessment team went on record at a public meeting in north Queensland as saying that it believed that the Queensland Government had the best logging and roading record in the world. The IUCN team said that the Queensland Government's approach to ongoing rainforest management in the State had resulted in foresting practices that were the least environmentally damaging of those anywhere in the world. Far from condemning the State Government as the wreckers of our national heritage, as the Federal Government has tried to say in this Parliament it is, the IUCN is on record as praising the efforts of the State Government in developing a sound management policy that permits minimal environmental damage. That is really the conclusion to which the IUCN has come. It is on record as acknowledging that the practices developed by the Queensland State Government have been sound.

As I come to the final five minutes of my speech, I believe that it is time to reflect on what has been achieved over the last 12 months during which this debate has raged. It is time to examine the balance sheet of Labor's disastrous attempt to win a few votes in the inner suburban areas of Melbourne and Sydney. As I have indicated, the Labor Party has betrayed the unionists and the grass roots support of the Party, really at the altar of the greenie vote. But that support of 3 or 4 per cent is not really the constituency that should be looked after. Let the Democrats have it. They will vote with the Government anyhow.

Our Constitution has been raped by this Government. It has been desecrated to the point where it now denies the Queensland Government the right to appeal to the High Court of Australia. The Government has done this in a backhanded manner through retrospective legislation, giving the final say on World Heritage matters to UNESCO-an unelected body that can now tell Australia what it can and cannot do. The Government has given UNESCO this power, despite the fact that no-one in Australia has ever voted for UNESCO. The ledger sheet on World Heritage also shows that the Government has now established another police force that can impose fines of $1,000 or gaol a person for 12 months without a warrant.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—That is a fact. That is in the legislation. It does not even need a warrant to do it. The Government has also moved ruthlessly to impose changes to the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act that make it legal to nominate areas of land for World Heritage listing without the need for prior environmental impact studies to be carried out. It has done this because, despite spending $300,000 on commissioned socioeconomic and environmental impact studies, there was not one report-apart from that tame cat biased report from Aila Keto-that could sustain an argument to support World Heritage listing.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest that her credibility has been shot to pieces; it is severely tainted. I believe that she has been bought lock, stock and barrel by this Government, which paid her $14,000 for a report, as President of the Rainforest Conservation Society of Queensland, recommending that logging cease. Of course she was going to recommend that logging cease. That has to be the most stupid waste of $14,000 I have ever seen. The Federal Government then gave her $3,835 to attend the IUCN meeting in Costa Rica, including $250 telex expenses for her to issue Press releases against the Queensland Government's stand. There is no doubt in my mind that she has sold out to this Government.

During the debate this Government has constantly distorted and misled the people of Australia, and we have seen more evidence of that today. Senator Richardson said that he could not get consultation with the Queensland Government. But I put down in this House some time ago a telex from the Queensland Premier asking for an appointment. Of course, we never hear about those things. Well, the battle is really over now as far as we in this House are concerned. It has not all been one-sided, though. I will concede that the Government has managed to cause widespread havoc among the people of north Queensland. It has destroyed their jobs.

In fact, the Labor Party has paid a very high price for the ground it has taken. The Labor Party lost the Adelaide by-election because people have come to realise that it does not represent them any more. Its precious jewel in its crown was lost in the New South Wales State election in a political rout, because the people, the grass roots, have realised that the Labor Party does not represent them any more, that it has lost touch with them. They are reacting against it in the ballot box.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha, ha!

—I am glad that Senator Richardson can laugh, because he did not have too big a smile on his face the night the New South Wales State election results came in. All he could say then was, `We do not understand the working class people any more'. The Minister has time to repent and vote for the disallowance motion. He may regain some credibility with his lost heartland and lost grassroots support-the working men and women of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —All honourable senators will know the results of the evaluations and recommendations of the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN) within a fortnight. Unfortunately, the Senate will not be sitting at that time but, when it does resume, I will have great pride in pointing out to Senator Boswell how wrong he is about the way the IUCN feels about the wet tropics of north Queensland. So many foolhardy, wrong and ridiculous statements have been made today that I will not be able to cover them all. I will however, in the time available to me, not only attempt to go over the misinformation raised by Senator Puplick and Senator Boswell but also try to give some background as to why we are having this debate today and why the Government moved towards having the forests listed in the first place. I hope to explain the basis of the system.

SPEECH.PARA: The basis of the system does need some explanation. Senator Puplick wrongly suggested that the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers (CONCOM) agreement of 1984 had within its terms a requirement for agreement between the States and the Commonwealth. I can understand why he incorrectly did that, and I do not blame him for it. In 1986, I think, my Department put out an information paper in which it got the CONCOM agreement wrong. However, it corrected it thereafter so many times I cannot remember, and why the honourable senator would continue to use the wrong document is beyond me. Nonetheless, the 1984 CONCOM agreement has nothing in it about agreement and everything in it about consultation. It certainly suggested that there had to be consultation. I am happy to table the agreement if necessary, but it certainly has nothing in it about agreement between the Commonwealth and the States. The reality is that we spent three years trying to consult with the Queensland Government about the wet tropics.

We have heard much today about scientific evidence. Both Senator Puplick and Senator Boswell seem to suggest that the Government simply does not have any. It is time to correct that impression. First of all, the forests were nominated in 1987 because they represent one of the most significant rainforest ecosystems in the world. There are unique species of birdlife and plants, exceptional coastal scenery where the tropical forest joins the sandy beaches and magnificent reefs just off the coast. It is the only remaining Aboriginal rainforest culture in the world.

Scientists from all over the world have supported what the Government is doing, and I shall cite just a few of them: Professor Peter Ashton of Harvard University and the President of the International Association of Botanical Gardens; Professor Paul Richards of Oxford University; Sir Peter Scott of the World Wildlife Fund International; Professor Peter Endress of the University of Zurich; and Professor Schuster of the University of Massachusetts. As all honourable senators know, because it achieved some publicity, the Duke of Edinburgh, in his capacity as the President of the World Wildlife Fund, wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) congratulating him on the Australian Government's initiative in protecting the area. It is a bit difficult for a conservative opposition to criticise the Duke of Edinburgh, so I am on pretty safe ground. I will not hear too many interjections about the Duke. Members of the Opposition cannot say anything too nasty about him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you just interject then, Ron?

—He was thinking about it, but he backed off. Let us look at the question of selective logging because it has often been claimed that it is compatible with the World Heritage values in a rainforest, and that is the basis of the debate. Despite what some people may claim, one cannot compare logging with the natural disturbances of cyclones. There is nothing about logging in a rainforest. It represents a special man-made disturbance over and above those natural disturbances which occur from time to time as part of the normal life of the forest and its evolutionary process.

SPEECH.PARA: Logging leads to serious disruption of the dynamic balance of a rainforest and, at times, it can be impossible to re-establish that. Short and long term changes in the composition of species result from logging. It also must be remembered that changes in the age classes of trees are present in the forest. As a result of logging, soil scarification, erosion, nutrient loss and the introduction of exotic species can occur.
As part of the scientific evidence on the side of World Heritage listing, I want to quote Professor David Curtis, the President of the Australian Academy of Science:
Arguments for continuation of current managed exploitation of the tropical rainforests, based on the suggestion that selective logging has few effects, are very superficial.
Professor Daniel Janzen of the University of Pennsylvania studied the north Queensland rainforest with the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, and he said:
Despite all the noise to the contrary by the commercial exploitation interests, Australia's tropical rainforests have in fact been seriously damaged and are on the verge of much more serious loss.

Against the weight of those eminent scientists from around the world and at home, Senator Puplick has quoted the Institute of Foresters of Australia. I suggest that the enormous weight of scientific opinion is on the side of World Heritage listing.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the IUCN?

—I will get to that; I will not miss that or Senator Boswell later on. I shall look at the claim that because areas have previously been logged they should not be included in a World Heritage area and, allegedly, the fact that we have must prove that logging does not degrade World Heritage values. The reality is that while some areas have been damaged by logging, it is still possible to protect their World Heritage values provided that logging does not continue. It must be remembered that current logging practices are very different from the practices of the past. It is no good saying, `We have logged there for 100 years and it has not done any harm.' The sort of logging that went on 100 years ago is very different from the logging of today.

SPEECH.PARA: If honourable senators want to get into the mechanics of that, they need only look at the number of species that were able to be harvested to see what sort of damage can occur to the rainforest. In the early 1900s, only 10 rainforest species were allowed to be harvested from the forests. In the 1930s that had gone up to 26 species. In the 1940s, the figure was 36 and now, as we move into the 1990s, there is a compulsory list of 150 species that can be taken from the forests. The change has been dramatic in the last 100 years from the days when very few logs were taken from only a handful of species. Now, rainforest logging in north Queensland has become an open go. Some 150 species can now be taken. Of course, in the old days, bulldozers, tractors and trucks were not going into the forests. The damage they cause is enormous.

We have heard much today about sustainable yield and that, again, is a central argument. The Queensland Department of Forestry, backed up by no less an authority on the subject than Senator Boswell, has told us that 60,000 cubic metres is the sustainable yield for all time, that it is the benchmark figure. That figure was first heard of in October 1986. At the time, there was a headline in the local paper at Ravenshoe, which said, `Ravenshoe under threat'. It was, of course, under threat not from World Heritage listing but the fact that, once again, the quota of timber that could be cut from the forest had been reduced dramatically. The reality is that the Queensland Forestry Department has to revise its predictions of what sustained yield is every few years because it does not have a clue what a sustained yield might be.

TALK.START.PARA: —I doubt that.

—I will go through the figures and Senator Boswell can tell me whether any of the figures are wrong. Is it a fact that in 1960 the Queensland Forestry Department said that the sustained yield was 240,000 to 270,000 cubic metres, forever? The reality is that there is only one possible answer-`Yes, of course it is a fact'. By 1975, 15 years later, apparently it had been realised that 270,000 cubic metres of timber could not be taken from the forests every year. The new figure arrived at, which naturally would be right for all time, was 160,000 to 200,000 cubic metres. Of course the figure had been reduced, but it was decided that that much timber could be taken every year from the rainforests without any damage to the forests' sustained yield. In 1981 the Department revised the figure. The next line taken by the Queensland Forestry Department was that a further downward revision would have to be made and the new estimate, for every year and for all time, was 80,000 cubic metres. Is it a fact that those things happened?
—They were reducing the area.

—No, the area increased by 10 per cent. The other nonsense that those opposite have touted is that the area was reduced. It was actually increased. But still the Queensland Department had to keep revising downward what it reckoned was the sustained yield. It did not finish in 1981. After all the changes that I have just mentioned, all the times the Queensland Forestry Department had to say `Whoops! We got it wrong; we have had another look', in 1986 another reduction was made in the sustainable yield, down to 60,000 cubic metres. When one considers the timetable for these reductions, one realises we are probably only two or three years away from another revised figure from the Queensland Forestry Department. If we allowed this to continue, the Department would say `Whoops', again. Are we just about allowing the Department to continue admitting its mistakes? Is that the only benchmark for forest management in Queensland? Those mistakes are so massive-for example, the difference between 270,000 and 60,000 cubic metres in less than 25 years is extraordinary. If those sorts of mistakes can be made, what trust can anyone put in forestry management by the Queensland Forestry Department?

SPEECH.PARA: The truth is that no-one knows. I do not know; Senator Boswell does not know; and certainly the Queensland Forestry Department has no idea what sustained yield means to a rainforest. The fact that those figures are revised so regularly is sad. It is sad because each time the new figure is released the claim is that it will be the sustained yield forever and that it will not damage the forest. But usually within about five years someone from the Department says, `That was actually wrong. This time we will reduce it by 50 per cent or 40 per cent or whatever.' The reality is that downward revisions go on and on. They make the planning processes of the Queensland Forestry Department laughable. The public is given no opportunity of participating in those processes.

Senator Boswell ought to try to find out how that figure of 60,000 cubic metres is arrived at. He should approach the Queensland Forestry Department and ask it to give him an idea of how it reached that figure. Senator Boswell knows what the answer would be: `There is no way we could tell you that. We will give you no information whatsoever'. The people of Queensland, for whom, allegedly, Senator Boswell speaks so passionately, are never told how the Department arrives at those figures. The Department is so afraid of its paucity of knowledge on the subject that it will not subject itself to any form of public examination. Why should it? It has been wrong so often that I can understand its fear.

It is not only me who doubts the Queensland Forestry Department on the subject; the debate has been raging within the Department for years. I shall quote Mr Sam Dansie, an Atherton forestry district rainforest logging inspector. In 1980, he said:

The problems are real, brought about by the over-removing of the productivity of such forests, blinding those involved to the realistic facts that rainforests the world over are, in general, one-cut, relatively low production forests and ours are no exception to the rule.

I shall also quote Dr Ross Hynes. It will be hard for Senator Boswell to knock him, given the role he has played in NORMA-the Northern Rainforest Management Agency-in recent times. He would not like us to remember what he has had to say in the past when he was a real scientist, but I shall quote him anyway. In 1980, he said:

The human demands on our rainforests over the last century have exploited the natural capacity of most accessible stands to the point where their potential to supply timber on a sustained yield basis is no longer viable.

In these communities short cycle logging (for example every 30 years) leads to diminishing species richness. Thus the long-term result of typical logging operations is the destruction of rainforest community integrity. Rainforest is a renewable resource only in the most simplistic sense.

That is Dr Ross Hynes, who is not known for his strong support of the Labor Party or of me. Most Australian and international foresters agree that nowhere in the world does sustained yield logging work in a rainforest. I shall quote another scientist, Dr Neil Byron, a lecturer at the Australian National University School of Forestry. His comment is worthy of note by everyone who is interested in the debate about sustained yield:
The sustained yield model evolved in 18th century European conifer forests-
that is from where it came-eighteenth century conifer forests of Europe-
working with three or four types of tree. It has proved totally inappropriate to the tropical forests which are so much more complex.
The Queensland Forestry Department has never been able to demonstrate that sustained yield will work.

When quoting the report of ACIL Australia Pty Ltd, Senator Boswell neglected to say-as he so often does-that the qualifications on the prospects of the Queensland timber industry are that there be modernisation, that the industry restructure itself, and also, not unimportantly, that sustained yield can work. As I have just explained, the concept of sustained yield, even in the terms of the Queensland Forestry Department, is laughable. It always has been and will remain so. I hope it is noted from the consultant's report that we are not only talking about the sustained yield question; any suggestion that this industry will modernise or rationalise is pretty hard to imagine, so far as I am concerned. The industry has not done that in the past and there is no reason to suggest that it will in the future.

The ACIL report also suggested the Queensland timber industry needed to better use its available resource if it were to have a future. In the past 10 years the use of north Queensland rainforest timber has been virtually static. It is 40 per cent for structural timber, 35 per cent for miscellaneous cabinet wood, and only 25 per cent for prime cabinet wood. That is how the industry has continued to use the resource. I do not know who could even suggest that it would start to change. This is an industry that has never been interested in change. However, changes have been forced upon it. If one is considering the future of the industry in Queensland, one of the benchmarks on which one can judge it is its past, and the timber industry has been in decline for a long time. In 1960 there were 80 sawmills and plywood mills using up to 270,000 cubic metres of timber-Senator Boswell would remember the sustainable yield figure that the Queensland Department talked about. Those mills then employed more than 2,000 people. In 1986, less than 30 mills were operating, using 77,000 cubic metres and employing 940 people. When I spoke with the industry last year prior to this decision being made, the number employed had declined to 750 and the new figure for sustainable yield was 60,000 cubic metres. That was the absolute latest figure. I wonder how many of the 1,250 workers who hit the fence in the Queensland timber industry during the past 25 years received redundancy packages from their employers. I should imagine it was very few, because employers in that industry were accustomed to treating their workers in that way. Only now, through Commonwealth intervention, are workers being presented with redundancy packages and alternatives for their future. Only now can they recognise that they have some sort of future. Although a change is called for, there is no doubt that their future will be assured.

I wish to turn to some of Senator Puplick's remarks. Firstly, Senator Black did not know, when he remarked on why the debate was changed from last week to this week, that it had been changed at my request. Therefore, Senator Puplick had done nothing other than to reach agreement with me. Unfortunately, in the past 12 months that is the only agreement Senator Puplick and I have been able to reach on environment questions. I only wish we could get a little further, not from my point of view but from the point of view of the environment in Australia.

When Senator Puplick became the shadow Minister for the environment he came to that position with something of a track record in the environment field. He had attempted to save seals in the Arctic and had a record which suggested to many people concerned about the environment in this country that he might bring the Liberal and National parties some new sense of reason and justice when it came to the rape of our environment. Unfortunately, they were disappointed. Anyone who really thought that Senator Puplick might bring about such a change no longer thinks this.

I had wondered why there was so much silence on this issue. I note that Senator Boswell mentioned how the debate had raged. The debate has raged everywhere except in the Senate. This is the first time that I have stood up in this Senate to debate these questions other than when I introduced legislation. There has never been a matter of public importance on the question of World Heritage listing of the rainforests. Day after day in this place we have all the stupid, useless matters of public importance to which we all have to listen. Not once has Senator Puplick as the shadow Minister, or Senator Boswell, the alleged lion of the north, ever got up to debate a matter of public importance on this question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't challenge them.

—I do challenge them. I have waited a long time for this opportunity. But, of course, Senator Puplick would never do that. He had to walk away from this debate because he had to walk away from this question in his own Party. The reality is that the troglodyte end of his own Party and the Queensland Nationals ran over him. The bulldozers were out. This time the target was not trees; it was Senator Puplick, and they did not miss. They went straight over the top and down he went. That fact, which is now well and truly established by this debate, runs a bit contrary to some of the things that Senator Puplick and his Leader were saying earlier. Following the 11 July election last year a lot of people wondered whether the Opposition would adopt a more enlightened policy. No less a person than John Howard said on the Sunday program on Channel 9:

SPEECH.PARA: Well I think one thing we have to look at is whether we aren't perhaps taking a slightly dementedly puristic view about States' rights when it comes to environmental issues.
In the Age on 31 August Senator Puplick said:
There have been two elections where the organised conservation vote has been against us. I don't want that a third time. We've got to get it right.

TALK.START.PARA: —He said that, did he?
—He said that. He went on in a Press statement of 24 August:

SPEECH.PARA: The Queensland wet tropical rainforests are worthy of inclusion on the World Heritage List: they are unique; they are of international significance; they contain one of the greatest and scientifically significant concentrations of unique flora and fauna in the world. Australia is the only industrialised country with remaining tropical rainforests and we have a responsibility to protect them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Strong words.

—Strong words matched with no action. The only action we have seen from Senator Puplick on the question of his beliefs is that he has come here today and said, `Destroy the rainforests. Knock them over'. That is the policy of the Liberal Party of Australia. That has always been the policy of members of the National Party of Australia and they are stupid enough to be proud of it. But the Liberals went on with the pretence, at least for a while, that they might have had a different view. In the Courier-Mail Senator Puplick even suggested that the Queensland Government should stop posturing over the issue and get down to Canberra for talks.

SPEECH.PARA: What happened to all those words? Where did he go wrong? He talked today about people in my Party having a different view. There have always been people in my Party who have had a different view from mine and the same applies to Senator Puplick's Party. However, the difference is that my view has continued to prevail and it will prevail in the future because we are more than happy with the stance that we have taken on the environment as we know that it is right. We will not walk away from our commitments on the environment and we certainly will not walk away from them in north Queensland.

Having watched the decline of Senator Puplick's environmental views over the last 12 months it comes as no great surprise to me that he now runs a line in this debate that would have done Joh Bjelke-Petersen proud, and I am sure that he is proud of it. He has backed away entirely from any support of World Heritage listing. He is now compromised with the Queensland Government. Let me say that compromise with the Queensland Government is pretty difficult. For a start the Queensland Government will not talk. It adopts the attitude that only its view can prevail and there will be no discussion. When one goes up to north Queensland, in the words of the former Premier, Joh Bjelke-Petersen, `it is war'. People in north Queensland are urged to take the battle to me and, of course, they have done that. In the Age of 3 March Senator Puplick said:
Nominations for listing should proceed only with the agreement of the State Government.

That sort of abject crawling to members of the National Party is really sickening. It contradicts Senator Puplick's earlier statements and the statement made by his well and truly forgotten predecessor and colleague, Alexander Downer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who?
—I am not surprised that honourable senators ask that question. Mr Downer, in his declaration of the poll speech, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is the environmental credentials of the Queensland Government are perceived to be bad and by saying we would only act in concert with the States, we become damned with the reputation of that State Government.

How right he was when he said that. No government in Australia's history has had environment credentials as bad as those of the Queensland Government. Now Senator Puplick is prepared to say, `If Queensland does not like it, it will not bat on. In fact, if I ever become a Minister'-God help Australia's environment-`I will delist these areas. I will not worry at all about saving anything. I will have the Queensland Government as the final arbiter of what ought to be protected in Australia. I will allow Geoff Muntz, Bob Katter and Ron Boswell to set the tone. If they tell me it is right, it is right'. This Government cannot and will not take up that attitude. Let us look at Senator Puplick's exact words on 14 April. He said:
A coalition Federal government would consider taking the forests of north Queensland off the list.

He wants to vandalise the forests. He has shown his true colours. He might have had an encouraging start and there might have been those in the environment movement who said, `Hello, there is finally a chance, a light at the end of the tunnel. Perhaps at the end of this tunnel we will find Senator Puplick and he will do something for us'. He has done no better than that eminently forgettable and equally pompous Alexander Downer. The reality is that the Liberal Party could not stand the heat from the Nationals.

Senator Puplick, in failing to produce any sort of decent environment policy in north Queensland, has I think for all time killed the opportunity for the Liberal Party to be able to appeal to anything other than the narrow base from which it came. Before I finish, I must just quote some of Senator Puplick's sayings because I think they are worth quoting. When it comes to cliches there is no-one in the Senate-I will be adventurous and say no-one in Australia or the world-better at it than Senator Puplick. In a document that he produced to demonstrate what the Liberals stood for we were told:
No man is an island.
I wish I could have thought of that one. He said further:
Man is not alone on the planet.
That is a pretty good one. Even better, he said:
The price of liberty is eternal vigilance.
Fantastic! And, wait for it, he said:
Our nation occupies an entire continent.

My God, this is heady stuff. But it requires more than that sort of rubbish to do anything to protect Australia's environment and its last remaining tropical rainforests. Senator Puplick has said that he would quit politics if he could not convince the coalition parties to embrace a greener environment policy. He said:

I accept that it is my neck that's on the line if the whole thing falls in a heap. If I can't convince my colleagues that would be a mark of substantial personal failure as a politician. I don't think I'd be much use to the Liberal Party.

I said earlier that Senator Puplick and I had reached agreement only once before, but I can agree with every word he said there. If he has any honour and any principles whatsoever he will live up to his own words. He will resign, he will get out of politics and he will go back to the cucumber sandwich set from where he and the Liberal Party came.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Madam Acting Deputy President--
—Make it a short speech-`I resign'.

—Your resignation is accepted, Senator. Senator Richardson, in his response to these motions for disallowance and disapproval, has raised a number of matters to which I propose to reply. In particular, I wish to deal with a number of the allegations he has made and to put squarely certain clear repudiations of the undertakings given by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) which have been central to Senator Richardson's presentation in the Senate this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: I start, however, with the comments which he has made about the management of the wet tropical rainforests by the Queensland Department of Forestry. It is all very well for Senator Richardson to continue to blame the Queensland Forestry Department for all of the ills which he perceives in the industry. Again, the evidence simply does not support that proposition. The consultants' report to which Senator Boswell and others have made reference, entitled `The Forestry and Timber Industry of North Queensland-Impact of Proposed World Heritage Listing' and prepared by ACIL Australia Pty Ltd, says:

In more recent years, the Queensland Forestry Department's performance and sophistication in rainforest management have improved markedly, to the point where it is generally agreed to be held in high regard by interstate and overseas public sector forestry organisations. The operations of logging and timber businesses are possibly the most tightly governed in the nation to ensure that public policies are adhered to at all times.
Senator Richardson is simply wrong in his attacks on the Queensland Forestry Department. He is equally wrong in what he says about the timber industry. The report from which I have just quoted says:
The principal issues and findings of the study are as follows:
a smaller but viable industry could have existed without World Heritage listing. . .
However, the report says elsewhere:
The consultants believe that World Heritage listing would cause a medium term decline of the entire North Queensland timber industry to almost negligible levels.

So the attacks Senator Richardson makes upon the timber industry, upon the economics of the timber industry, and upon the Queensland Forestry Department, are refuted by the evidence which is on the public record.

Senator Richardson makes a great deal about job losses in the area. Yet his own consultants' report-and on this occasion I refer to a different consultants' report, namely, the one entitled `Alternative Employment Creation and Mitigation of Impacts of Listing the Queensland Wet Tropical Rainforests as a World Heritage Area' by the Institute of Applied Environmental Research at Griffith University-estimates that the introduction of World Heritage listing in north Queensland will lead to the loss of 1,074 jobs in the area. Mr Howard, speaking on 15 October 1987, said:
I don't see why it can't be possible to preserve special areas of Australia's heritage and environment such as rainforests, and at the same time, stop the destruction of jobs and family livelihoods.

That is the position which the Opposition has consistently taken-that environmental protection and the protection of jobs can take place at the same time. That is the position which Senator Richardson so cavalierly rejects.

Senator Richardson makes a great deal about the wonderful areas that have been preserved, those wonderful areas he describes where the rainforest comes right down to the sandy beaches on the edge of the beautiful ocean. Those areas-the ones that feature on all of the Australian Conservation Foundation's (ACF) posters and elsewhere-are areas which Senator Richardson has specifically excluded from the boundaries of the World Heritage List. The monumental, crashing hypocrisy which is to be seen in this Government and in that nomination can be seen from the fact that the very areas which Senator Richardson cites as being the most unique, the most special, the most worthy of protection, the ones that are put on the ACF posters and are put on the front of the Government's reports, are areas specifically excluded from the boundaries which Senator Richardson has drawn in terms of World Heritage listing. If people want to blow up those areas, those trees, ride their dune buggies over the whole area, flatten them and put up a block of commercial flats, a whole series of tourist developments, a hostel or a municipal toilet block, Senator Richardson has no power to prevent that from being done because those are the areas which he has excluded from World Heritage listing.

We come then to what Senator Sanders and all the others had to say about the Opposition attitude and what Senator Richardson was saying earlier about strong words being matched by no action. The action we have taken is what Senator Richardson has clearly failed to do. We have actually met with the Government of Queensland and come to an agreement about the way in which those unique areas would be specifically preserved. To save the time of the Senate, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the statement which I put down about that, which appeared in Hansard of 15 March 1988.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

I am in a position to say that the approach we would have made to the Queensland Government as the basis upon which those discussions would have proceeded-I believe they would have proceeded in a satisfactory fashion towards a satisfactory conclusion-would have been on the following premises: First, we would have proposed that the State of Queensland take steps to create a greater Daintree national park which would have been created within the laws and jurisdiction of that State. It would have been created in the area between Mount Molloy and Cooktown, based upon the existing national parks of the Daintree River, the Dagmar Range, Wonga, Cape Tribulation, Cedar Bay and Black Mountain. We believe that it would have been possible to identify clearly the absolutely unique characteristic of the Daintree-Cape Tribulation area and to give that area very special protection, because it is quite unique and undoubtedly worthy of very special protection, without in fact drawing the sort of extensive, ambit claim boundaries which have been drawn by Senator Richardson and his Government.

We would have sought to have, in conjunction with the Queensland Government, a complete socioeconomic and environmental evaluation of the Queensland wet tropic rainforests. That inquiry would have been open and public and conducted along the lines of the Fox Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry so that everybody who was interested, everybody who wanted to present scientific evidence, to challenge scientific claims, to have evidence or claims independently, properly and publicly evaluated, would have had the chance to do. We would not have proceeded with World Heritage listing until that process had been completed and until we had secured the agreement of the Queensland State authorities to proceed with that World Heritage listing. We would have sought to develop a sensible multiple land use plan, using the sorts of zonal arrangements which have been applied successfully by the Commonwealth in Queensland to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.

We would have ensured that the north Queensland timber industry would have been allowed to continue its operations and that there would have been an independent evaluation of the need to commence any logging activities in areas which are currently virgin. We would have expected that, as evidence of good faith on the part of the local industry, it would have agreed to a voluntary moratorium on that particular activity; and, indeed, there should be no variation in the current logging quotas set by the State Government. That, together with the proclamation by Queensland of the Greater Daintree National Park in which those activities destructive of the environment, including specifically logging and mining, would not have been allowed to proceed, would have been the basis for an intelligent discussion of these particular matters. We would have sought to bring an end sensibly and in an orderly fashion those activities which could be demonstrated to be sufficiently and significantly environmentally destructive in a way which clearly would have been incompatible with the maintenance of a good national park and significant heritage values.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. For all the quoting of comments about what was to be done, what steps were to be taken, the realistic step that Senator Richardson has not taken, has not sought to take, is to have a proper and civilised meeting with the Premier of Queensland and to sort out this matter in a proper and civilised fashion. There has been, on our part, no backing away from the concept of World Heritage listing in appropriate circumstances. That has been made clear by me, it has been made clear by Mr Howard and it remains the policy of the Opposition. What has been backed away from is the words of the Prime Minister. Let me quote them again to honourable senators: The Prime Minister's letter to the Premier of Queensland of 12 September 1984 stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not the intention of my Government to take unilateral action to nominate the region for World Heritage listing.
Let me quote the words of ex-Senator Ryan, a former Minister in the Cabinet of this Government:
The Government has made it clear that the wet tropic rainforests of north east Queensland will only-
I stress the word `only'-
be nominated for inclusion on the World Heritage list with the agreement-
I stress the words `with the agreement'-
of the Queensland Government.

That has been backed away from, and dishonoured, the written assurances of the Prime Minister and the assurances given in the Senate by Senator Ryan, a former senior Cabinet Minister. They are the promises that have been dishonoured-not what the Opposition has said. It is a question of why Senator Richardson can come in here and publicly repudiate his Prime Minister. That is the issue which is at stake. We know that the public repudiation of the Prime Minister on privatisation by Mr West, or by any of his Ministers at any time, without the Prime Minister having the strength of courage or the force of leadership to prevent that repudiation from taking place, is a feature of the way this Government operates. Therefore, one really should not be surprised in that regard.

I will not respond to the personal attacks that Senator Richardson sought to mount. He will be answered in due course. He will be answered on this question not only when the Opposition's policy on this matter is published but also comprehensively at the ballot box, because that is where the ultimate answer to Senator Richardson will lie. All the vituperation, abuse and personal vilification he likes to indulge in have absolutely no impact upon me. As for quotations of one sort or another, Senator Richardson is fundamentally too thick to see a quotation from other sources when it is put in front of him and simply describes it as a cliche being used by somebody else. It is not of the least interest to me to respond to that sort of cheap and juvenile debating point.

What we are dealing with is not a cheap and juvenile debate-at least it should not be. It is that only to the extent that Senator Richardson makes it that. It is important for a number of reasons. It is important for the livelihood of the people of north Queensland. It is important for the way in which governments go about dealing with each other in this country. It is important to the extent that the Prime Minister's word can or cannot be trusted. Those are important issues. They are issues which Senator Richardson clearly will not, does not and cannot address in this debate.

The motions which have been moved on behalf of the Opposition for the disallowance of both a declaration in the Governor-General's proclamation and the regulations made under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act form the basis of an important debate. It is a great shame that Senator Richardson would not address the primary issues. It is a great shame that Senator Richardson would not tell us, first, why he has ignored a large weight of scientific evidence about what should or should not be included; secondly, why he is not prepared to meet in a civilised and proper fashion with the Government of Queensland to bring about a resolution of this matter which will protect the unique parts of our environment without causing distress, without causing harm and without causing the devaluation of public support for environment preservation; and thirdly, why it is that the word of the Prime Minister given to the Government of Queensland about the way in which this matter would be handled cannot be relied upon. Those are the issues. They remain unaddressed. For that reason I believe that the motions for disallowance moved by the Opposition ought to be supported.
Question put:
That the motions (Senator Puplick's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (PARLIAMENTARY TERMS) BILL 1988CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (ELECTORS' INITIATIVE) BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILLS:
CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (FAIR ELECTIONS) BILL 1988
CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (LOCAL GOVERNMENT) BILL 1988
CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (RIGHTS AND FREEDOMS) BILL 1988]
Debate resumed from 24 May, on motions by Senator Tate and Senator Macklin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Constitution Alteration Bills cognately. The four questions to be asked of the people relate to the provision of a four-year term for both Houses of Parliament, the extension of the principle of one vote one value in all elections, recognition of local government by States, and the extension of guarantees of trial by jury, freedom of religion and fair compensation for property acquired by any government. I want to put down my Party's very strong opposition and objections to all four questions contained in this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I place on record my appreciation of Senator Chaney's very fine contribution the other day. He addressed the questions logically and gave the Opposition's arguments in a clear and concise manner, backed up by charts that proved beyond any doubt the the Opposition's stand on these four questions was right. Senator Robert Ray has achieved a reputation in this place as being an expert on all matters pertaining to elections. Senator Robert Ray tried, unsuccessfully I might add, to drive a wedge between the National Party of Australia and the Liberal Party of Australia.

We again saw Senator Richardson trying those tactics. Obviously, those tactics will now be adopted by the Government to try to divide and conquer, divide and rule. The National Party and the Liberal Party are both totally opposed to those four questions and will see them soundly defeated by the people when they go to the referendum around September. The first question is: Are you in favour of a four-year term of parliament? Many people would agree and say, `Yes, we have too many elections'. In Queensland we have a State Government election, a Federal Government election and very hotly contested local government elections in Brisbane with the Liberal Party and the Australian Labor Party (ALP) as the main participants. In Queensland we have elections at least once every year. Most people would agree that a four-year term of parliament would be a good thing. It certainly would be good for business and the people. But the question is wrong and misleading and it should be challenged in the High Court of Australia because this proposal does not guarantee a four-year term.

In the last 43 years the Federal Parliament has been to the people 22 times. This legislation will do nothing to allow for fewer elections; it has the potential to allow for more elections. Under our present Constitution, the Senate is elected for twice the normal term of the House of Representatives. If the Senate refuses to pass legislation, the Government has the right to reintroduce that legislation to the Senate within a period of three months. If the Senate again refuses the legislation, the Prime Minister of the day can call on the Governor-General and ask for an election. All that would be finished under the proposed legislation we are now debating. It would enable the Government and the Prime Minister to go to an election at any time that it is politically opportune for them to do so. The Senate would have very little power to amend legislation as the Government could call an election at any given day if legislation was refused or amended. I would love to ask Senator Ray how this Bill would provide for fewer elections. At present, the Government has to go through quite a deal of drama to obtain a double dissolution but, with this proposal, we could go to a double dissolution at any time, at the drop of a hat.

In my term in Parliament I have seen the Senate amend many pieces of legislation, some of which, if allowed to go through in their un- amended form, would have been very deleterious to the people of Australia. One piece of legislation we altered that comes to mind is the veterans' entitlements Bill. The Senate stopped in its tracks the introduction of an Australia Card. My colleague Senator Stone is here and he should take a great deal of credit for that. If it had not been for the Senate forcing the Government to reintroduce that legislation the Australia Card would now be a part of Australian legislation. The Bill of Rights was another proposal stopped by the Senate.

I understand that if the Bill of Rights had not been pulled out from the Senate the Government would have been defeated at the next election, such was the opposition to this type of legislation. It was the Senate that acted as a brake on the excesses of the Government. We also saw the Industrial Relations Bill withdrawn because it was headed for defeat in this place. But we would not be able to have such a brake in future. The Senate rejected the Government's wish to abolish sections 45d and e of the Trade Practices Act. That is the only protection that small business and farmers have against the thuggery of unions and unfair union strikes.

This Bill that calls on the people to vote for four-year terms has to be defeated. If it is not, the Senate as we have known it since Federation will have no teeth at all. It will not be a House of review; it will be merely a mirror image of the other place across King's Hall. It will be absolutely devastated and it will have no significant role to play, as it has had previously. It will not be a States rights House and it will not be Australia's insurance policy which has been relied upon for 61 years to curb any excesses of any government. It will be a toothless, meaningless House and a mere reflection of what happens in the other place.

We should not really be surprised at the Government's attitude in introducing this legislation. It has always been Labor Party policy to abolish upper Houses in the State Parliaments and the Federal Parliament. It is Labor Party policy to have a one-chamber system in politics. So we should not be surprised. The Government knows that it cannot achieve that and that the people would not accept the abolition of the Senate or the upper Houses in the States. But the Government does not have to abolish the upper House. If this legislation is passed and put to the people and agreed to, the Senate will be totally emasculated. That is what this Government is all about. I say that with all the sincerity at my command. This Senate will not reflect what the people have expected of it over the last 61 years. It will not reflect what our founding fathers put in the Constitution. No-one can argue against that. Is is a clever Labor Party ploy to reduce the power of the Senate and emasculate it. It is doing this under the guise of asking people whether they want a four-year term for parliament. But it has nothing whatsoever to do with allowing for four-year terms. There has never been a time in the last 10 or 15 years that parliaments have served out their three-year term. Nothing in this Bill will ensure that parliaments serve out a full four-year term. It is diabolically clever and it is designed to emasculate the Senate.

Another consequence of four-year terms is that the Senate quota would be permanently reduced from 14.28 per cent to 7.69 per cent. The outcome would be that no government would ever be able to gain a majority in the Senate-neither the Labor Party nor the Liberal Party-National Party coalition. We have seen the Australian Democrats control the Senate with 7 per cent of the vote. They want one vote one value. They have more power with their 7 per cent of the vote achieved throughout Australia than they deserve. We have now seen the peaceniks-the peace senators-be elected with a very minor vote. We will turn this chamber into a place for all sorts of odd bods and other remnants if we allow the requirement for election to be reduced to a 7.69 per cent quota. Any single issue person will be able to be elected and the Senate will never be able to represent the true ethos of the Australian people. It will be composed of the peace groups, the ultra right groups, the communists, all sorts of greenies, peaceniks and all types of other people. It will be reduced to a valueless exercise. Every one of us here today should take those consequences on board. The Government will be forced to do deals with these minorities to get its legislation through.

We should ask why the Democrats suddenly supported the Government's resource rent tax when they had previously rejected the idea? Was it because the Government gave a commitment to the Democrats to set up a committee to investigate all chemicals used on farms so that the Democrats could have a platform on organically grown foods to impress their green constituents'. I suggest, without reflecting on a vote in the Senate, that that is exactly what happened. The Government is doing deals with the Democrats. I do not think that is good for democracy. We should not get into the position that a government of any persuasion has to do backroom deals with minority groups. That is not truly reflecting the democracy of this nation. Certainly in the last session of Parliament it has been very rare for the Democrats to support the National-Liberal conservative side in a division. If any party wants to have representation in this place, it should be able to achieve 14 per cent of the vote. Under this legislation, under what the Government is proposing, we will have quotas of 7 per cent at every election in Australia. Backroom deals are not in the best interests of this nation's political system.

I now come to the question of the extension of the principle of one vote one value in State elections. Let me say at the outset of my contribution on this matter that boundaries in the States have absolutely nothing to do with the Federal Government. That is not only my view but a view shared by none other than the former Premier of Western Australia, the Hon. Brian Burke, when he told the Federal Government to keep its hands out of Western Australia and off the State boundaries. By putting this question to the electors of Australia the Government is once again centralising power in Canberra, removing the decision-making of the parliamentary representation closest to the people-the governments of the States. I do not believe that people want any more Big Brother control in Canberra. This question ultimately will be rejected, as will all the questions.

This Bill is clearly designed to defeat the Queensland Government. Everyone on either side of the House would concede that point. After every election in Queensland we see the defeated Leader of the Opposition there calling foul. He bleats that the boundaries are against him. We have seen that time and time again, no matter which Leader of the Opposition it is. He appeals to his Federal colleagues to cover the Labor Party's lack of electoral appeal, asking the Federal Government for intervention on the boundaries. What generally happens is that the response from the Federal Labor Party is to send some heavies up to Queensland to try to sort out their State Queensland Labor Party colleagues, that faction-ridden party, to find out why the Labor Party did so badly. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was sent up after the last election defeat in 1986. He was dispatched to try to sort out the mess in Queensland. He was virtually told to get out of Queensland and mind his own business. He came out of Queensland in absolute shock and said, `I do not know what to do about it'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. I believe we are currently discussing the Government's referendum proposal for one vote one value. I cannot understand how the Prime Minister's involvement in the Queensland Branch of the Labor Party-no matter what degree of cane toad juice Senator Boswell has been on-can somehow be related to this specific measure.
—I ask the honourable senator to direct his remarks to the legislation.

—The facts are very simple. We are debating one vote one value, and that certainly reflects on what is happening in Queensland. The ALP has not won an election in Queensland since 1957 because it has never achieved over 50 per cent of the vote. Between 1969 and 1986 the highest Labor vote was 46.75 per cent, when the Labor Party achieved a fairly significant number of representatives in the State Parliament. I do not want to bring up the matter-but I suppose I have to-of the very low point in 1974 when the Labor Party ranks were down to a cricket team of 11. The Leader of the Party was defeated and the vote achieved in 1974 was 36.03 per cent of the total vote.
—We are talking about 1988 at the moment.

—Let us get to 1988. We will talk about 1986, which was the time of the last election. In the last election the Labor Party achieved the remarkable score of 41.38 per cent of the vote. If any people on the Government side of the House are so stupid as to believe that a government should govern in a State with 41.38 per cent of the vote, with 56.14 per cent of the people not wanting a bar of its party, they should stand up and be identified.
—Sixty-three per cent didn't want you.

—I pick up the interjection. What did we get? The National Party got maybe 2 per cent less than the Labor Party. The honourable senator asks why we should form a government on 39.64 per cent of the vote. He calls himself some sort of economist. He should know that the Liberal Party got a significant vote and passed its preferences across to the National Party. That is called a two-party preferred vote and it meant that 55.64 per cent of people did not want a Labor Government and 41.35 per cent of people did. Therefore, the Labor Party was defeated. This Government is responding by trying to introduce legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us face it: the Labor Party can achieve government in Queensland if it achieves 51.4 per cent of the vote. It has Buckley's chance of getting it because the Queensland constituency is different from that of Melbourne, Sydney and Adelaide. It is made up of small business people, farmers, graziers and miners, who do not want a bar of socialism-and they will never vote for the Labor Party. Let us compare the 51.4 per cent of the vote that the Labor Party had to achieve to gain government with what the National-Liberal parties had to achieve to win the recent New South Wales election. The coalition had to obtain close to 53 per cent of the vote. Federally, the coalition will have to obtain 52.3 per cent of the vote to beat a Labor government. I understand that in Western Australia and in South Australia a considerably higher vote than 50 per cent is required to remove the Labor Party.

The interfering Federal Labor Government now has the audacity to talk about gerrymanders and malapportionments. It should hang its head in shame at the mention of a gerrymander or malapportionment because Queensland really has the fairest elections of any State, where the Labor Party has to get only 51.4 per cent to win government. That is a lot lower figure than in any other State. If the Government were serious about fair elections, it should put the question to the people of Australia: Do you want governments to govern with less than 50 per cent of the vote on a party-preferred basis? That would be a fair question. It is appropriate to examine the consequences of what would happen if this question were passed. The results in Queensland would be that no electorate would be larger than 20,551 people or less than 16,819 people. The consequences would be that the western and northern areas would lose 7 per cent of representatives to the south-east corner of Queensland. The area from the Sunshine Coast to the Gold Coast and to just beyond Toowoomba would contain 67 of Queensland's 89 seats. That would leave a total of 22 seats representing about 85 per cent of the total area of Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is unfair about that?

—What is unfair is that it denies representation for the rural people of Queensland, for the great wool, beef, grain and mining areas that contribute so much to Queensland's and Australia's wealth and prosperity. These export industries provide foreign exchange that allow us to meet our commitments to reduce our balance of trade figures. This Government never has cared for rural people. By introducing this legislation it shows that nothing has changed; it still treats rural Australia with absolute contempt.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I inform honourable senators that I have received a number of congratulatory messages in relation to the opening of the new Parliament House from overseas legislatures, including messages from the Speaker of the British House of Commons, the Rt Hon. Bernard Weatherill, and the Speaker of the United States House of Representatives, the Hon. Jim Wright, both of whom will be in Canberra for the first meeting of the Parliament in the new building. Senators who wish to read the messages may peruse them in my office.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. It concerns the circumstances surrounding a letter written to you, Mr President, in February by the Deputy Secretary of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs advising the Senate of the citizenship status of then Senator Wood and particularly that part of the letter asserting that the Department was `obliged' to notify the Senate. Has it emerged that the Department did not seek any formal legal advice on its supposed obligation until the day after the matter was raised in the Estimates Committee? Did not the opinion when it was finally received advise that there had been no obligation on the Department, even though there was no prohibition on the Department taking the action it did? Does it not seem now that the Department has no legal basis for its claim that its actions in making known then Senator Wood's citizenship status rested on some obligation? Do not the events suggest that the Department seems to have very few scruples about making disclosures of details from applications for citizenship in circumstances where these disclosures are likely to be made public, as they were in this case? In view of the widespread concern that any public disclosures of details of applications for citizenship should be limited to those absolutely necessary, will the Minister ask her colleague to recommend to his officers that a more appropriate course of action would have been to encourage the person involved-that is, then Senator Wood-to have made known to Mr President for release any possible problems with his citizenship status?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Members of the Estimates Committee who were present during this matter when Senator Peter Baume raised it with us will recall the degree of frustration that we experienced in terms of getting the kind of response that the honourable senator was seeking. I do understand the frustration that he experienced in not being able to get an early response; in fact, it did take us some time.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the second part of the question, I am not aware of the timing of that legal advice, but I will certainly ask Mr Clyde Holding to seek a response on that matter. In regard to the disclosures, I think the honourable senator will agree that when Mr Tony Harris appeared before the Committee subsequent to this matter being raised, he was at great pains to point out the exceptional circumstances and that it was not normal for him, or indeed any other officer of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, to disclose lightly-I think that was the word used-information of such a personal nature. If the honourable senator refers to his direct quotes-I do not have them with me-he will see in the summing up in the last meeting of the Estimates Committee that Mr Harris assured us that the circumstances were very unusual and that it would not be normal practice. Nevertheless, all things considered, I do appreciate the concern that Senator Baume and, indeed, the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Mal Colston, expressed in the Estimates Committee. I will certainly refer the detail of the honourable senator's question to Mr Holding for a response.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Home Affairs. With regard to the move to the new Parliament House, taking place between the autumn and Budget sessions of Parliament, is the Minister aware that when senators and members pack up their offices to move to the new Parliament House in the non-sitting period, many will not be able to bring a member of their electorate staff with them due to the fact that a significant number have fully extended their staff travel entitlement of 15 trips to Canberra and 100 days of travelling allowance?
