Does the Minister propose to take any action?
—Why not send us a letter?

—This is a measure to save on postage. I have had numerous representations, especially from backbenchers, pointing out that the actual task of moving from here to the top of the hill will be made much more difficult if they have to do it themselves without staff assistance. That means placing probably a lot more pressure on the staff of this Parliament House in attempting to assist them. So what we are saying is that on application to the Minister each senator and House of Representatives member will be granted one extra staff trip per year for this sole purpose and two days travel allowance. It is not really even a joking matter about moving offices because if one mislays vital files and if they are not supervised properly it will cause problems.
—You never know who might get into trouble.

—I will not get into trouble. I do not put much on paper, but others do. To facilitate that, on application to me we will grant one extra trip and a couple of days travel allowance to help members move. I am not sure of the Senate timetable in this regard. It may be in the next financial year, but it will still be approved. I think most of the House of Representatives members are moving in the next few weeks.

—I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to tonight's statement on the Government's policy regarding the telecommunications industry and the revised policy guidelines for government business enterprises, including Telecom Australia, as set out in correspondence with the Telecom Chairman which received some publicity this morning. Do these documents reveal the likelihood that the Government will incorporate Telecom under statute and that the Government is proposing to revalue Telecom's assets and require a new dividend payment for Telecom? Further, does it reveal that the Government is proposing to remove Telecom's exemption from paying income tax from 1 July 1990 in addition to all the new taxes and charges that were announced at the recent Premiers Conference? Does this mean that, far from removing the current restrictions on Telecom, the Government is merely using tonight's statement as an opportunity to treat Telecom as a milking cow for increased tax collections, hence resulting in significantly higher telephone charges?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would say at the outset that Senator Messner's question is based on a false premise. There was a draft letter to the Chairman of Telecom that found its way into the media but that draft letter was never sent because I was unhappy with the detail in it and the manner in which that was presented. I propose rather to discuss these matters with the Chairman in question. In particular there is no great occasion for mystery or secrecy of the kind that was implied by that newspaper story this morning, because I think every single matter dealt with in the newspaper story, or stories if one includes the Melbourne Age as well, will be the subject of quite explicit reference in the statement which is made tonight. I think under those circumstances Senator Mess- ner should endeavour to curb his impatience and wait to see what is in the statement, because the full context in which these various decisions have been made will there be set out.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, I will comment very briefly on the question of the tax liability of Telecom and indeed some of the other authorities. Some of that is already subject to public announcement in the context of the Premiers Conference so far as payroll tax is concerned. In that respect I refer the honourable senator to the response made by the Managing Director of Telecom, Mr Mel Ward, when the news of the payroll tax liability came out. I have not his exact statement in front of me, but he said it was not unreasonable that Telecom, engaged as it now was and as it hoped to be increasingly in competitive commercial endeavour in essentially a private sector environment, should be playing in that environment on a more level playing field so far as taxation liability is concerned than has been the case in the past. Equally, of course, it is the concern of these enterprises that the playing field be level so far as the removal of managerial and other constraints traditionally imposed by governments are concerned in order that the competition can be robust and genuine between them. Again I refer Senator Messner to what I will be saying in a lot of detail on this matter as well in the two statements to be made tonight.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SIR JOH BJELKE-PETERSEN: DISPUTE WITH TAXATION COMMISSIONER

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to a report in yesterday's Courier-Mail which, amongst other things, stated that the former Premier of Queensland, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, `took the witness stand for the first time yesterday since he took the Taxation Office to court more than 25 years ago'. Could the Minister advise whether the results of Sir Joh's disagreement with the Commissioner of Taxation were made public and, if so, what was the outcome?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply to the last part of the question, details were ultimately made public from the previous time when Mr Bjelke-Petersen, as he then was, appeared in conflict with the Federal Commissioner of Taxation, and that was in October 1962. I shall quote from page 21 of an extract of the High Court judgment, which states:

ANSWER.PARA: In November 1958 the taxpayer-
that is, Bjelke-Petersen-

made application for an authority to prospect for petroleum in an area in north-western Queensland. At that time he was endeavouring to raise sufficient finance to carry out test drilling operations and the application was said to be made on behalf of a company to be formed. The application was approved and taxpayer paid the required deposit of #2000 and the first year's rental, #723. However, the authority was not immediately issued as the proposed company had not been incorporated. Taxpayer's attempts to raise finance were unsuccessful and finally, in April 1959, the authority was issued in taxpayer's own name. On 25 May taxpayer entered into an agreement with L Co. by which he undertook to form a company and to transfer the authority to it. The transfer was to be for a nominal consideration as it was the practice of the Department of Mines to refuse approval unless a transfer was for no more than nominal consideration. Under the agreement, L Co. undertook to purchase from taxpayer 51 per cent of the issued shares in the company to be formed for #12,650 and to pay him 51 per cent of the deposit and first year's rental paid by him. The company, A. Pty Ltd, was formed on the same day and the authority was sold to it for #2. The issued capital of A Pty Ltd Ltd consisted of two subscribers' shares held in trust for taxpayer. On the following day A Pty Ltd revalued the authority to #24,804 and on 4 June 1959 it declared a dividend of #24,802 wholly and exclusively out of the profit arising from the revaluation, which dividend was satisfied by the issue to taxpayer and his nominee of 24,802 shares of #1 each in the company credited as fully paid up. Taxpayer then sold 12,650 shares in A Pty Ltd to L Co. for #12,650. Of this amount, the Commissioner included #12,450 in taxpayer's assessable income for the year ended 30 June 1959.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. This is clearly not an answer to a question. It is no more than an attempt to read into the record material which is 30 years old, and it is obviously an abuse of Question Time. I hesitate to say that the Minister is debating the question, but it seems to me that he is simply not providing an answer at all; he is making a statement, which can be justified only as some attempt to get at the ex-Premier of Queensland. I think it is a pathetic matter. You ought to ask the Minister to complete his answer and allow Question Time to proceed.

—Order! I must say that my first impression was that the question might have been out of order. I waited until Senator Walsh started his answer. He is representing the Treasurer and he was dealing with a taxation issue and, for that reason, I did not rule him out of order. But I would ask him to conclude his answer.
—Thirty-two years ago he was stealing oranges.
—Fifteen years ago the honourable senator was writing shonky prospectuses for Patrick Partners.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. That interjection of Senator Michael Baume's is totally disorderly. Not only is it disorderly; it is offensive to the Minister for Finance. To suggest that 30 years ago the Minister was stealing oranges is a pretty small slight. If he were stealing something big, the interjection would have some point to it. It is most offensive.
—Order! I think both Senator Michael Baume and Senator Walsh are fairly robust in their answers and questions.

—In regard to the relevance of the question, I was asked: What was the result of the last scuffle that Mr Bjelke-Petersen had with the Australian Tax Office? I am reading from the High Court judgment on it. So I fail to see how even Senator Chaney could argue that that is not answering the question and within Standing Orders.

ANSWER.PARA: The sequence of fiddles outlined in that High Court judgment is very hard to follow, but the essential purpose of it is not at all hard to follow. The essential purpose was to evade taxation. Although it happened 32 years ago, the underlying ethos which drove Mr Bjelke-Petersen to do that still drives the National Party of Australia and drives the Federal Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Can the Minister confirm that the Government is already requesting higher education institutions to provide data for the development of educational profiles as a basis for funding each institution? The concept of education profiles was raised in the Government's Green Paper. If in fact the Department of Employment, Education and Training is now requesting this data, does this not represent a denial of the promised process of public consultation on the release of the Green Paper? If the development of these profiles has not begun, how can the Government justify such a step when debate on the Green Paper has not concluded, and the White Paper presenting Government policy on consideration of that debate has not yet appeared? Does the Government propose to make the negotiations on these profiles open to public scrutiny by having them undertaken by the Higher Education Council of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training, or does the Government itself plan to conduct negotiations with individual institutions behind closed doors?

—The answer will be shorter than the question. The procedures referred to in the question were discussed at some length at the Estimates Committee which I attended. To the best of my recollection, the essential answer coming from departmental officers is that this year the Department is extending slightly the information which it has procured from higher education institutions for a number of years. If there is anything more to add to that, I will present it at the appropriate time.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Is the Minister aware of concern that, despite anti-discrimination legislation passed several years ago, women are still underrepresented in government appointments to boards, councils and committees? What action is the Government taking to redress this imbalance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Overall, women are currently underrepresented on government advisory bodies. Obviously, that is of concern. Nevertheless, this Government has set as a priority the need for a register of women to detail many women throughout Australia who have the necessary skills and expertise to be considered when government appointments are being made to statutory boards and other instrumentalities. The National Agenda for Women aims to achieve equal representation of men and women on such boards wherever possible by the year 2000. At the time the agenda was launched in February, 16.5 per cent of Cabinet appointees to government boards were women.

ANSWER.PARA: I would like to point out, however, that some departments have been able to achieve a much higher representation, and it is important to highlight these. For example, the Department of Social Security has been able to achieve a representation of women on its boards and instrumentalities of up to 50 per cent; the Department of Aboriginal Affairs has achieved 42 per cent and the Department of Employment, Education and Training is up to 28 per cent. Obviously, when the question of representation of women on government boards is concerned, one must look at the appropriate skills and the appropriate background. Of course, the Government knows that women are underrepresented in a number of fields, but it is good to know, as I am sure Senator Zakharov and other senators on this side of the chamber know anyway, that at least in three government departments we are close to achieving its aim. In fact, the Department of Social Security has reached equal representation. The Department of Aboriginal Affairs is not far behind, and the Department of Employment, Education and Training is certainly moving in the right direction.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce concerns computer software. What response has the Minister made to the representations he has received from the Australian Information Industry Association concerning the recent Australian Taxation Office ruling that has significantly widened the imposition of sales tax on the computer software industry? For example, is development work or adjustment on a software system carried out for a client rightly subject to the software sales tax? Is the recent tax ruling an unintended consequence arising from the Government's 1986 legislation? Will the Minister and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, together with the Commissioner of Taxation, ensure that there is urgent clarification of the situation so that the uncertainty for this important industry, not least in my own State of South Australia, is ended?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many members of parliament have received representations about this issue, as I have. Earlier this week or late last week-I cannot quite recall-I met with representatives of the Australian Information Industry Association and this issue was discussed again. Prior to that meeting, the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce had been having discussions with the industry and the Australian Taxation Office. A meeting is fixed for 7 June where representatives of my Department, the Treasury, the Taxation Office and the information industries will meet to seek clarification of some of these issues and, if appropriate, relief from anomalies that have clearly arisen.

ANSWER.PARA: This issue has been about for some time and the particular problem, as I understand it, is that the intellectual content of software development has been subject to the tax which is appropriately a tax on goods as distinct from services. That is the essential issue that must be examined. After the meeting of 7 June, I am hopeful that the Government will be able to make an early response to the matter.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senator Black having addressed a question to the Minister representing the Treasurer-

Senator Puplick-On a point of order, Mr President: standing order 99 provides that questions shall not contain any matter which is hypothetical and questions shall not ask for an expression of opinion. On the basis of whether the Minister representing the Treasurer knows of anything that may have arisen from what may be speculation and on which he would like to comment and speculate as to what might happen in the future in a hypothetical matter, namely, what might be in tonight's mini-Budget statement, I put it to you, sir, that the question is clearly out of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I uphold the point of order. The question can be rewritten in a way that would be within the Standing Orders, but, at the moment, it is not.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer the Minister to the call by the Australian Law Reform Commission (ALRC) for the introduction of class actions in Australia. Has the Government considered this proposal; if so, what decision has it made? If not, when does it expect to make a decision? I also ask the Minister whether he agrees with the Commission's proposal that if class actions were introduced, there would be no restriction on lawyers asking whatever contingency fee they wished?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some information on this issue as it relates to class actions and as it also relates to the whole question of consumer protection and call actions being intricately inter-related with that. The Australian Law Reform Commission has prepared a draft Federal Court group proceedings Bill and explanatory memorandum as part of its reference on access to the courts. The draft Bill proposes a framework for the institution of class actions in the Federal Court. I understand that the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Business Council of Australia have expressed concern over a number of aspects: firstly, the lack of industry consultation; secondly, potential for significant cost impact on industry; and, thirdly, the development of an over-litigious society similar to that of the United States.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised by the Law Reform Commission that the aim of the Bill is to improve access to the courts and to reduce costs of court administration. It seeks to address a problem referred to by a former United States Vice-President, Walter Mondale, when he said:

Nothing is more destructive to a sense of justice than the widespread belief that it is much more risky for an ordinary citizen to take $5 from one person at the point of a gun that it is for a corporation to take $5 each from a million customers at the point of a pen.

The underlying principle of the ALRC draft Bill is that corporations should not be allowed to escape liabilities simply because the damage inflicted on each individual is insufficient to warrant legal proceedings. In the context of this draft proposal, it should also be noted that the Government has recently amended section 87 of the Trade Practices Act and has allowed by the amendment the use of representative actions. One particular complaint about that proposal has been that those actions require the written consent of all persons for whom redress is sought. The ALRC proposal is intended to automatically cover all people in a relevant class. It does permit, from my understanding of it, that individuals will be able to opt out of proceedings if they so wish.

I am also advised that the ALRC is of the opinion that potential for abuse of class actions can arise and the Bill provides for frivolous or vexatious actions to be dismissed. That is basically the proposition of the ALRC. In this case, the Government's position is that it believes all groups should be consulted and the ALRC, I understand, is embarking upon that process. The Government thinks that, in a course that may lead to legislative change, full consultation should take place. Of course the Government accepts the submissions from business groups on this particular proposal.

It should be stated that the ALRC has not finalised its report. I am sure it will give due regard to the concerns raised by industry. Therefore, in brief, we are talking about an ALRC draft proposal, which has not been finalised, which has not yet come to the Government and which is not as yet settled or part of the Government's policy formulating process.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Is the Government balancing its need for skilled and business migrants with its commitment to family migration?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —A sharper focus is being achieved by raising the skill level of the intake as well as targeting specific skills to meet the needs of the Australian economy. The skilled and business migration category is expected to comprise 25,000 places in the 1987-88 program of 132,000, that is, 19 per cent of the total program. In addition, about 30 per cent of migrants in the independent and concessional category are skilled workers. Independent applicants need to have recognised skills and qualifications to pass the points test. Sponsored non-dependent relatives such as nephews, nieces and siblings, gain concessions from sponsorship but are also assessed under the points test in terms of economic factors such as skills, education and employability.

ANSWER.PARA: Thus, for the first nine months of the current intake, approximately 29 per cent of the settler arrivals are skilled or business migrants. This compares favourably with 25 per cent in 1985-86 and 28 per cent in 1986-87.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. I remind the Minister that on 10 May he advised the Senate and also informed Dr Blewett that Dr Menon had not provided the Australian Federal Police (AFP) with a comprehensive list of doctors who have allegedly received bogus Medicare cheques. Was not a comprehensive list of doctors provided to the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts and was not that information passed on to the police late last year? Is it not also true that details of cheques dated after November 1987, namely in February to Dr Alan White for $10,700 and in March 1988 to Dr Evans for $90 and $636.90, have also been given to the police? Did Constable Warren Grey of the AFP advise Dr Menon in April that the only information which was still required by the police was the telephone numbers of the doctors involved? In light of the fact that on 4 May Constable Grey advised Dr Mackey that there was a need for a proper and fuller investigation of the allegations and that he planned to go to Hobart the following week to interview Dr Mackey and Dr Whyte and in that he has not yet done so, when Senator Tate told the Senate on 10 May that `the AFP will not at this stage be making inquiries' did he mean that he or alternatively Dr Blewett had called off the investigation of this very serious matter?

—That is another ludicrous allegation. There is no truth whatsoever to be inferred from anything Senator Newman has said to the effect that either Dr Blewett or I-myself in particular as Minister responsible for the AFP-have required, requested or intimated to the AFP that the inquiry should be called off. In fact, day after day, knowing Senator Newman's interest in this matter, my office was in contact with the AFP seeking an answer for her. That was the answer provided by the AFP that I read into the Senate Hansard on 10 May 1988. It was absolutely without any influence, undue or otherwise, on my part or, I am confident, on the part of the Minister for Community Services and Health, that the AFP conducted its investigations according to its own independent processes.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Senate to assume, in view of the dates which I gave the Minister, that the AFP is not choosing to keep the Minister fully briefed?

—The AFP has provided me with an answer, which it provided in answer to Senator Newman's question. In providing that answer, I am confident that the AFP acted with the usual integrity. Nevertheless, given the fact that Senator Newman gave certain dates, obviously all of which I could not record during the question, I shall have them forwarded to the AFP for comment.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN PUBLIC SERVICE: EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Local Government and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women aware of criticisms from the community that the Government is not doing enough to increase significantly the participation of women in senior positions in the Australian Public Service? Can the Minister comment on these criticisms?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the criticism and much of it is very unfair. Perhaps it is based on lack of information about what has been achieved under this Government in terms of women in the Public Service. We know that women have tended to be concentrated in the lower levels of the Public Service but in 1981 the Public Service Board introduced a voluntary equal employment opportunity (EEO) program. It was not until this Government's initiatives in 1984 that the program had a compulsory and statutory base.

ANSWER.PARA: In 1986 the former Office of the Public Service Board conducted the largest EEO survey undertaken in Australia, covering all staff in agencies auspiced by the Public Service Act. The survey found that, whilst women occupied 43 per cent of Australian Public Service (APS) positions, a high proportion worked in traditional female occupations with relatively low pay and limited career prospects. In other areas representation was low although increasing. For example, women comprised 9 per cent of technical staff; 17 per cent of professional, science and engineering staff; and 4 per cent of trade staff. When this Government came to power in 1983, only 3 per cent of senior levels of the APS were women. By 1984, this had increased to 4 per cent and the latest figures show that 119 of the 1,635 Senior Executive Service officers are women. That is an increase from 3 per cent in 1983 to 7.3 per cent in 1988.

As indicated in a response to an earlier question, when one is involved, as we are, in the process of social change, in many cases it is frustrating when the change is slow. Nevertheless, genuine progress has been made and will continue to be made under this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to an article in the Australian Financial Review of late headed `Meat inspectors urge Federal action'. Is the Minister aware that beef exports, which represent $464m annually, could be jeopardised by contamination caused by traces of an organic chemical, octyl diphenylethylhexyl phosphate, in other words, ODP, as used in plastic wraps? What action does the Minister intend to undertake to prevent any further damage to Australian beef exports as occurred with the pesticide problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the Press reports referred to by Senator Panizza and that the Japanese are also concerned about them. The report referred to was carried by both the Japanese Press and the Australian media. They suggested that a potential harmful substance known, as Senator Panizza called it, as ODP-my description of it is similar to Senator Panizza's, 2-ethylhexyl diphenyl phosphate or phosphoric diphenylethylhexyl-had been detected in Australian beef. Perhaps honourable senators would like me to read that again.
—It is like having Robyn Williams in the Senate.

—I thank Senator Chaney for that implied compliment. The Japanese media based their reports on a presentation by a Japanese researcher to a public health conference held in Japan. This is an example-the Japanese say this themselves-of the media exaggerating a coincidental research finding. The researcher involved had detected the compound when unusual curved lines appeared on a graph while chemical reactions in meat were being tested and reported. It was presumed that the compound might have permeated into the meat from the plastic wrapping. There was no clear data on the toxicity of ODP-and I do not think the honourable senator wants me to define that term again. There was a need to monitor continuously and to research the possible sources of food contamination.

ANSWER.PARA: ODP is approved as a plasticiser in the manufacture of plastic food wraps by the Standards Association of Australia and the United States Food and Drug Administration. The National Health and Medical Research Council has recommended the adoption of the standards developed by the Standards Association of Australia and, of course, these authorities would not approve the use of substances harmful to human health. No concern has been expressed either by the Japanese health authorities. I might add that I have a report from the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service which goes into detail about the matters raised in the honourable senator's question.

The Japanese researcher, Mr Osatu, was reporting his research to an academic conference. He has indicated to Australian authorities that he regrets and apologises for the fact that his research has been misused and exaggerated by the media in the way in which it has. Those are his terms and this report identifies that. I will be happy to make a copy of the report available to the honourable senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of today entitled `Scientist gagged on woodchip threat to Eden wildlife'. In that article a senior New South Wales Government scientist was prevented from delivering a paper to the ANZAAS conference on threats to wildlife because of woodchipping in the south coast area of New South Wales. The scientist, Mr Dan Lunney, is the head of the environmental survey and research branch of the National Parks and Wildlife Service and he has published much work on this topic already. Will the Minister assure the Senate that the Federal Government will do all in its power to ensure the survival of endangered wildlife species in that area and approach the New South Wales State Government and seek similar assurances?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the article in today's Sydney Morning Herald. I note that the attempt by the new Government in New South Wales to suppress Dr Lunney's paper is but one-
—That is untrue and you know it.
—On the contrary, Senator Puplick, I know it to be true.
—That is untrue.
—If the honourable senator listens, he will learn.
—That won't happen.

—The honourable senator reckons that that will not happen. All right; I withdraw that statement and say that even if Senator Puplick listens, he will not learn. Nonetheless, it is another attempt on the part of the new Government in New South Wales to ensure that as little information as possible flows through to the public for any informed debate on the future of the south-east forests. That is not surprising coming from a Greiner-Murray combination, because we all knew that, once the election had been decided, there would be a new turn in terms of the handling of our native forests in New South Wales. It did not take long for that to happen.

ANSWER.PARA: The paper, which has indeed been suppressed, is the result of five years of research by Dr Lunney. We have seen the hypocrisy of the new Government, which, on the one hand, takes delight and relish in releasing all sorts of papers from the old Government where it seeks to gain a political advantage, but, on the other hand, wishes to suppress any information that might cause it some embarrassment when it comes to embarking on its new courses. As Senator Puplick demonstrated this morning, the Greiner Government in New South Wales has already abandoned even the pretence of any support for environmental causes. Already it has been bulldozed by the National Party of Australia and is sprouting its line.

Of course, we have also heard that Mr Moore has gone further than just suppressing the paper. He has told the National Parks and Wildlife Service that it is to treat the south-east forests `as if they are part of Victoria'. So there can be no more research and no more information on those forests coming out of New South Wales. Last month, in another attempt to suppress information, the New South Wales Government refused to give permission-this is extraordinary-to the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN) delegation led by Mr Jim Thorsell to fly over the south-east forests of New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —`Biggles' will fix that for you.

—The difficulty was that `Biggles' was not paying for the plane-Mr Greiner was. Neither Mr Greiner nor Mr Moore would let anyone from the IUCN even look at the south-east forests. So the fact that Mr Moore has suppressed a paper on the south-east forests is hardly surprising, given that he will not even let people look at them. We now have a farcical situation where an international delegation of very prominent people is forced to divert, after looking at our alpine region, around the New South Wales forests to ensure that they are not able to see what might be happening in them.

ANSWER.PARA: The crudest example among a series of crude examples of what the New South Wales Government has in mind for forests came from the new Minister for Natural Resources, Mr Causley, who has announced that he intends to allow timber companies to log forests in New South Wales without so much as an environmental impact statement. That measure will open up all the national parks of New South Wales to the mates of the National Party. God knows what they might do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Puplick would agree with that.

—On the basis of what Senator Puplick said this morning, he probably would agree with that. Whatever Mr Lunney may have said in that paper, I am sure that he would have made it very clear that there are dangers in the logging programs suggested for those forests. What we all ought to be doing, and what I can undertake to do for Senator Foreman, is to make sure that the national Government talks both to the industry and to the New South Wales Government about the future of those south-east forests; to make sure that we water down the more extreme desires of the sillier elements of the New South Wales Government; and make sure that we can preserve some of the special areas and make special provision for those species, both animal and plant, in the south-east forests which are endangered. I think that Mr Moore, the new Minister, began his career along with Senator Puplick in a desperate attempt to save the pine forests in a national park from being logged. I think Senator Puplick referred to it as `devastatingly destructive clear felling' in one of his more lucid comments. I think we all know that the ignorance that has been demonstrated by the Liberal Party on the question is manifest. We hope that the tail of the timber industry does not continue to wag the New South Wales Liberal Government dog and that, over the next few weeks, we get from the New South Wales Government some indication of its desire to do the right thing by the environment and some indication of its desire to protect at least some of the south-east forests.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I ask my question, I ask the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to table the paper from which he has been reading.
—Will the Minister table the paper?
—No.
—The Minister will not table the paper.

—I note the Minister's commitment to freedom of information in this matter. I therefore ask him: Was the question that he just responded to initially based on a report which appeared on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Science Show on Saturday, broadcast by Mr Peter Hunt? Is he aware that on 23 May 1988 Mr Tim Moore, the Minister for the Environment in New South Wales, wrote to Mr Peter Hunt indicating to him that he, the Minister, had taken no steps to suppress Mr Lunney's paper and giving the full details of the way in which Mr Lunney's paper was dealt with by Mr Whitehouse, the Australian Labor Party's appointment as the permanent head of the Department of the Environment in New South Wales? I ask whether the Minister is aware that Mr Moore, in his letter, states:

QUESTION.PARA: I had no knowledge of the paper (or its abstract) prior to having your remarks brought to my attention.
That is, Mr Hunt's remarks. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a copy of Mr Moore's letter.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Mr Peter Hunt,
A.B.C. Radio,
2nd Floor,
100 William Street,
KINGS CROSS, N.S.W., 2011.
Dear Mr Hunt,

I have now read a transcript of a relevant portion of a broadcast by you on the ``Science Show'' last weekend concerning a paper which was to have been presented at the ANZAAS conference on the morning of Friday, 20th May 1988, by an officer of the New South Wales National Parks and Wildlife Service.

I had no knowledge of the paper (or its abstract) prior to having had your remarks brought to my attention. Had you made an inquiry of my office, prior to going to air, I would have informed you of this and I would have sought urgent advice from the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service on this matter-advice which I have now sought and which is to be furnished to me this day.

I trust you would appreciate that, as the person who introduced the first legislative proposal for Freedom of Information in New South Wales, it is neither my philosophical credo nor my administrative style to ``muzzle'' public servants within my administration. Indeed, to the contrary, I had already refused one request to me for the withdrawal of a different ANZAAS paper.

I am always ready and happy to speak to the media on the issues within my administration-whether it is likely that the person who is seeking the information will be in agreement with my views or those of the Government or not.

Your programme also mentioned some earlier paper which had also allegedly been withdrawn. I specifically indicate to you that I have no knowledge of that matter and have also sought information from the National Parks and Wildlife Service on the subject.
I wish to indicate to you, quite explicitly, that I concur in the remarks made by my colleague, the Hon. Ian Causley, on this matter.
It may be that some breach of departmental administrative requirements has led to this occurring-as I indicated, I have sought urgent advice on this subject.

I indicate to you, absolutely and specifically, that I had no knowledge of either incident and that there was no direction, request, instruction or any other action, comment or inference which could be so construed from me which led to this occurring.

As you may gather from the tone of this letter, I am less than amused that the matter was put to air without me having the opportunity to comment on the allegation which has, inferentially, been made against me. I would appreciate you retracting any such inference and indicate that I assume that no further inferences of this nature, with respect to this matter, will be made in future broadcasts.
Once I have information from the National Parks and Wildlife Service on the matter, I would be happy to discuss it with you.
I would also indicate that I assume, for the future, that you would at least do me the courtesy of seeking to check with me before making such statements.
Yours sincerely,
TIM MOORE,
Minister for the Environment

TALK.START.PARA: —Thirdly, will the Minister indicate why, in terms of the question he was asked, he failed to respond to the question about the protection of endangered species and, specifically, why he has dishonoured the promise made at the time of the last Budget and in the Governor-General's opening speech to this Parliament for the establishment of an endangered species unit within his own Department? Finally, seeing that he has actually misrepresented and told an untruth about the involvement of Mr Moore in this matter, as will be evident from the letter now incorporated in Hansard, is he game enough to apologise?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Am I game enough to apologise? I am not so foolhardy as to apologise. Everything that I said was the truth. It does not matter whether Mr Moore writes a letter and denies or attempts to slide out from under. The Liberal Party's attempts to slide out from under on the environment lately have been legion. Senator Puplick is the leader of that charge. But, just as he failed to slide out from under this morning, so will Mr Moore on this question. We did not base any question on an Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) program. We did not need to. It is based on information that we have received quite independently of the ABC. I am rarely in close contact with the ABC on this or any other matter. We have other sources. On the basis of those sources we have been able to verify what I have said in the Senate today.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as apologising is concerned, not only do I not apologise but I condemn Mr Moore for his actions. If we want to look at the south-east forests, we ought to do so on the basis of saying, `Just whom do the forests belong to?'. They do not belong to me. They do not belong to Mr Moore. They do not belong to a few timber companies. They belong to all of Australia. It is our duty to make sure that our future generations have some of the native forests of their forebears to look at.

I am also asked about dishonouring promises on endangered species. As Senator Puplick is well aware-at least he ought to be well aware of something on the environment-we have engaged a consultant to look at endangered species. When we have received and evaluated the report properly, we will act upon it. As is the custom with the Hawke Government, we will honour our promises.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Seeing that the Minister is very keen that there should be full public disclosure on these matters, I ask him: What are `our other sources' other than the report from the ABC or the report in the newspaper to which reference has been made?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —If I thought for a moment that anyone could get justice from the New South Wales Government in having the courage to speak up, I would name them; but, given that there is no hope of justice, only the rough kangaroo court justice for which the lot opposite are famed, I would not do them the disservice of naming them in this chamber.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. How many women pilots are employed by each of Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia? Do any of these airlines have a specific policy regarding women pilots? If so, what is that policy? Finally, given Government policies on sex discrimination and affirmative action, is the Minister satisfied with progress within Qantas, Australian Airlines and Ansett with regard to women filling a whole range of positions within airlines?

—Senator Powell was kind enough to give my office very brief notice of this question, just before Question Time. I am afraid that in the time available I have been unable to get a full answer to her question. I will take on notice that part of it which I do not answer. I am advised that Qantas and Australian Airlines have developed equal opportunity policies and plans in accordance with the requirements of relevant Commonwealth legislation. Qantas currently has six women pilots and one in training. The airline is making efforts to attract more applications from women to be employed as pilots. I do not have available information on the number of women pilots employed by Australian Airlines and Ansett. I will obtain information on that and get back to Senator Powell.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Home Affairs. It relates to the recent and non-political storm here in Canberra. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the damage caused to the West Block offices during the storm last Monday night? What arrangements have been made to accommodate the occupants of the building while the repair work is undertaken?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most honourable senators, at least, would be aware of what I think the Canberra Times this morning called a `microburst', which came across the lake, went through West Block and then went by the other side of this building, and did a fair bit of damage. One of the buildings damaged was West Block. The full extent of the damage, which now appears to be confined to three floors of B Block, is being assessed. During the storm, a large section of the roof of B Block was blown off and dumped into the adjacent car park. Substantial flooding occurred throughout B Block, caused by both storm water and the fact that the sprinkler system was interfered with. There was also damage to nearby parked cars, landscaping and certain equipment. Some of the equipment in the building, such as the more vital computers, was, however, protected.

ANSWER.PARA: Emergency action was taken to contain the damage and secure the building. The Australian Protective Services did a marvellous job in dealing with this emergency. The affected area of the building has now been isolated, temporary repairs to the roof completed and preliminary repair work begun. I am pleased to inform the Senate that, after minimum disruption, all occupants of the building are now operating in West Block, albeit in cramped conditions, and services have been restored. It is fortunate that the storm, whilst it was very severe, caused no major injury to any personnel at the time.

My office was rung yesterday by the head of Australian Archives, who pointed out that 15 years ago a similar storm removed the roof of West Block and dumped it into the car park. I thought that was a marvellous piece of research by the Director-General of Australian Archives-the fact that he could press a computer button and ascertain this information-but I find that the final source of his information was that the last time the roof of West Block blew off it landed on his car. So he had a vivid memory of it. I say to Senator McGauran and Senator Black, who are not here at the moment, although they are the only ones who are likely to be here in 15 years time, that I would not go outside in the middle of winter in 15 years time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Does the Minister agree that one of the principal reasons for the Government increasing the corporate tax rate several years ago from 46c to 49c in the dollar was to bring it into line with the top personal tax rate and thereby avoid the distorted incentive structures which inevitably arise from any significant disparity between the personal and corporate tax rates? Has this approach been effective to date and is this policy prescription still valid? Would the Minister agree that any significant reduction in the corporate tax rate without a commensurate reduction in the personal rate will only encourage the widespread use of artificial corporate vehicles to reduce and avoid legitimate personal tax obligations? If there are sound economic reasons why the economy cannot presently afford any cuts in the personal tax rate, despite a significant Budget surplus, on what basis is the Government able to judge that the state of the economy in 15 months time will be such as to then be able to afford such cuts-apart from the proximity of the next Federal election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has already been made clear that the question of personal tax rates will be addressed in the Budget and not in tonight's statement. That has been published probably 50 times. The increase in the corporate tax rate from 46 to 49 per cent in 1986-I think that was when it became active-was a move which, as a question of fact, almost brought the top personal and company tax rates together. However, it was also adopted to offset in large part the cost to revenue of abolishing the double taxation of company income, that is, paying it once in the company and paying it again when dividends were distributed. From memory, I think the increase in that rate recovered some 60 to 70 per cent of the cost of abolishing the second tax on dividends.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to whether having a company rate that is different from the maximum personal rate leads to tax evasion or avoidance, if there is a wide disparity it is inevitable that some people will attempt to use shonky corporate structures to avoid or evade personal income tax. Whether it is worth their while to try to do that is another matter. I remind Senator Alston and anybody else who is listening that the days when one could use shonky corporate arrangements to evade or avoid personal income tax went out the window when a capital gains tax was introduced. The mechanism that companies used to evade personal income tax was not to distribute company dividends, therefore pay tax at a lower rate and then, one way or another, arrange to reap the capital profits accumulating within the company, or the accumulated dividends in the company, so that they were taken as capital gains and not as income. That stunt finished on 15 September 1985. I say to Senator Alston that that is one of the reasons why the capital gains tax must be retained. If he is taking a serious interest in this matter-unlike some of his colleagues who are essentially interested in opening up rorts and ramps in the tax system-and if he wants to put an effective net under the personal tax system, a capital gains tax must be retained.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —In replying to a question from Senator Reid last Friday, I undertook to respond further on a matter. The Minister for the Arts and Territories, Mr Punch, has written to the Treasurer seeking his agreement to changes to the Payroll Tax Ordinance 1987. These amendments will raise the tax exemption threshold in the Australian Capital Territory from $200,000 to $400,000, align the effective rates in the ACT with those in New South Wales and introduces an exemption for apprentices employed under approved group apprenticeship schemes. I am informed that instructions have been given to the Parliamentary Counsel to amend the Ordinance. Thus, if approval is given, and I expect it will be, the amendments would come into effect on 1 July 1988. It is not intended that these amendments be given retrospective operation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I provide some further information in respect of a question asked by Senator Childs during Question Time on Monday of this week. Senator Childs asked me whether I had seen allegations that a Melbourne company was advertising the availability of irradiation of food and to comment on the accuracy of the allegations and the Government's intended response. I indicated in my response that the Victorian Department of Health was currently investigating the allegations.

ANSWER.PARA: Representatives from the Department of Health visited Cotter Food Services Pty Ltd yesterday. I take this opportunity to pass on their advice to me to the Senate. I am advised that it appears that the leaflet in question-the one which purported to advertise gas or gamma sterilisation on request-was, although undated, at least a year old and possibly older. I am further advised that it seems that it was an internal document distributed within the company to float the idea of providing this facility. It appears that this was circulated within the company before the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts review of food irradiation was established. At the time of such distribution the National Health and Medical Research Council had endorsed a food standard for food irradiation, but the standard was not incorporated into the Food Standards Code. However, it seems that the company internally discussed its use of that process, given that at the time it seemed likely to be adopted.

The Victorian Department of Health analysis of the situation indicates that Cotter Food does not have the facilities to undertake this process itself. While there is an irradiation facility in Dandenong, Victoria, which could provide this service, the Victorian Department of Health is satisfied that the company is not currently irradiating food and that this service is used for sterilisation of items such as medical equipment. In regard to Cotter Food Pty Ltd, the Victorian Department of Health is satisfied that firstly, it is not currently irradiating food on its premises; secondly, it is not engaged in providing the service in any way: and, thirdly, it is prepared to wait until a recommendation is handed down by the House of Representatives Committee and a final decision is made by the Federal Government.

The Victorian Department of Health concludes that there is no evidence of any irradiation of foodstuffs in Victoria and that there is no evidence to substantiate any allegation made against Cotter Food Services that it is currently offering any food irradiation facility.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to give a further answer to a question posed by Senator Knowles. In my capacity as the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs she asked me a question a few days ago concerning the purchase of two cattle stations in the Kimberley region of Western Australia owned by the Western Australian Minister for Water Resources, Mr Ernie Bridge, by the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) for a sum reportedly close to $200,000.

ANSWER.PARA: The first part of the question was: Is it a fact that the stations were not advertised on the open market? The answer is: Yes, it is common practice for properties to be sold without being publicly advertised if a suitable buyer can be found. The second part of the question was: On what basis was the purchase price negotiated? The answer is: The purchase price was negotiated on the basis of three professional valuations. The third part of the question was: Is the Minister aware that the chairman of the Aboriginal community for whom the stations were bought has described the properties as broken down and claimed that the ADC paid $60,000 too much for the land? The answer is: Whatever claim might be made about the ADC purchase price, in the end the price was based on three professional valuations according to normal practice.

The fourth part of the question was: Is it a fact that the community's chairman tried to persuade the Commission against purchasing the stations on the grounds that the cost of making them fully operational was prohibitive? The answer is: It is true that the community's chairman is particularly interested in purchasing an adjoining station because of traditional ties. However, the community's chairman and the community were involved in the purchase of the two properties. The fifth part of the question was: Has the ADC given any commitment to the community to assist it financially and, if so, how much public money is likely to be expended to turn Mr Bridge's broken-down properties into viable operating units? The answer is: The ADC is committed to assist development of these properties based on a three-year development plan prepared by a pastoral consultant in consultation with the community. In order to achieve viability the development plan is aimed at both pastoral activity on the properties and the community's mustering contract enterprise. The cost of the development plan is estimated to be in the order of $250,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to my notice given earlier today, I now withdraw Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1, standing in my name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented. Yesterday in Question Time, in answer to a dorothy dixer from Senator McKiernan, Senator Evans answered a question concerning statements reported in the Gold Coast Bulletin that I made about him. He used most florid language. He said that the headline was lurid and that I had accused him of having blood on his hands because of the fatal air crash at Coolangatta Airport a few days ago. I took the trouble to get a copy of the front page of the Gold Coast Bulletin. I did not say that he had blood on his hands because of that, and I would never say that. I will seek leave to table a copy of the front page of the Gold Coast Bulletin. All I said was that if Senator Evans did not take steps to improve safety at Coolangatta Airport, he would have blood on his hands.
—That is not the way it came across.

—That is not the way it came across from Senator Evans. Nevertheless, whether he did it or whether he had his own reporter here, the story has gone around today, and it has been reported widely, that I said he had blood on his hands because of that crash. That is wrong. Later, in answer to my question, `Did you have knowledge of an invitation to visit Coolangatta Airport?', he waxed even more lyrical and hysterical and wondered from what kind of garbage cans I got my evidence. I will seek leave to incorporate a letter from Mr Leo Gately, who was my source, which was faxed to the Minister on 11 May, a good nine days before the accident, and received and acknowledged by the Minister's office. I point out that such invitations have been issued for 18 months, trying to get some upgrading of Coolangatta Airport. I seek leave to table the Gold Coast Bulletin front page headline which reads `You'll have blood on your hands', not `You do have blood on your hands', and to incorporate in Hansard the letter from Mr Leo Gately.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Senator Hon. Gareth Evans
Minister for Transport and Communications
Room M48
Parliament House
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Mr Minister,

I have, since 1986, continually been confronted with information relating to the lack of radar and adequate safety equipment at Coolangatta Airport. The use of binoculars to bring aircraft into Coolangatta Airport in 1988 is NOT good enough!

The latest information I have to hand, is contained in a statement from Mr Robert Davis, a Constituent of Currumbin who lives alongside Coolangatta Airport. In his statement he describes an aborted landing, made in order to avoid a collision with another aircraft, which he and his wife observed on Friday 6 May, 1988. A copy is enclosed for your perusal.
I therefore respectfully request that you undertake a full investigation into this incident and make out a report to be made available to me at your earliest convenience and to include the following:
Identification of the two aircraft involved in the aborted landing on Friday night 6 May, 1988 at about 9.15 p.m. at Coolangatta Airport.
A written report from both the pilot and co-pilot of each of these aircraft.
Identification of the aircraft which was on the ground and held in the holding area at the North Western end of the runway at the time of this incident.
A written report from the pilot and co-pilot of the aircraft which had been held in the holding area at the North Western end of the airport during the incident.

I am not prepared to wait until there is an accident similar to the one in Cairns before anything is done for Coolangatta. I do not need to remind you of the catastrophe that could have occurred if the two aircraft had continued approaching each other from opposite ends of the runway.

It is my understanding that there has been for some seven years, a request for and approval given, for a new Air Traffic Control Tower to be installed at Coolangatta Airport. This situation has now become critical.

From information available it appears that there is no definite date yet laid down for the commencement of building a new Air Traffic Control Tower. Through this letter I seek your urgent advice in this regard.

In the past three years there has been an increase in excess of 57% of passengers entering and leaving Coolangatta Airport and in the last year alone, (period ending 31/12/87) there was an increase in passenger movements from 791,453 to 930,354, up 17.6%.

Apart from Hamilton Island, which is a relatively new resort, and which shows a phenomenal increase in domestic airline movements, Coolangatta has experienced the third highest increase in domestic airline aircraft movements with a 22.8% increase in the period ending 31 December 1987. From a previous figure in 1986 of 10,295 it has increased to 12,640.

I believe it is imperative that this matter be addressed as a matter of urgency and that your Government make money available forthwith for the provision of all the necessary safety equipment in the form of Radar, Curved Instrument Landing System as well as a new Control Tower, so as to minimise, as far as practicable, the likelihood of a mid air collision or other accident and or fatality resulting from any accident involving aircraft approaching or leaving Coolangatta.

I am extremely concerned for the safety of the pilots flying the aircraft and the passengers travelling in them, as well as the residents living under and adjacent to the flight paths into and out of Coolangatta Airport.

I am seeking to ensure the utmost safety for every person for whom I am making representations. I make no apology for demanding that the Federal Government make this equipment available urgently, in order to provide lasting and tangible benefits for the residents of Australia and in the interests of safety.
If these items of safety are not given urgent attention, I will hold yourself as the Minister, and your Government, responsible for gross negligence.
I make no apology for my strong statements to you in this letter and look forward to your urgent and positive response to my request.
Yours faithfully
LEO F. GATELY, mla
Member for Currumbin
Enc.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented. During Question Time yesterday, in response to a dorothy dix question from Senator Black, the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, referred to an article which appeared last Saturday, 21 May, in the Sunshine Coast Daily, an esteemed newspaper. This newspaper is published in the Sunshine Coast area of Queensland where I now have my home. The article in question referred to a Press release which had been issued in my name last Thursday by my electorate office in Mooloolaba, but for which of course I take responsibility, commenting upon a recent proposal by the Queensland Government to construct a toll road in the area. In that Press release it was stated that over the past four years the real level of Commonwealth funding for roads had fallen by more than 40 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walsh made two comments of substance-I leave aside his many, unfortunately characteristic, comments of no substance-on that point; namely, first, that the extent of the real cut in Commonwealth funding for roads was just over 20 per cent, not the 40 per cent indicated in my Press statement and, second, that less than a year ago I had said that the proper amount of money to provide to the States for roads was some $164m less than the figure which the Government is now providing. Let me dispose of Senator Walsh's first point simply by agreeing that, as he has stated, since 1983-84 the real reduction in Commonwealth road funding payments to the States has been just over 20 per cent rather than the 40 per cent which the Press release issued by my electorate office had indicated. I note that Senator Walsh has now conceded that under this Government there has been a cut in road funding of some 20 per cent in real terms over the past four years, a concession which I think leaves the basic point essentially unchanged. As to Senator Walsh's second point, I regret to say that in making it he failed to inform the Senate that the proposal in question, in respect of road funding, was put forward not in isolation as one might have thought from his answer to Senator Black--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I think what Senator Stone was saying was that Senator Walsh `failed to inform'. Senator Walsh can hardly misrepresent Senator Stone just because he fails to inform us of something. Personal explanations are usually best if they are concise, I would have thought.
—Senator Stone, you have to point out where you have been personally misrepresented.

—Mr President, I put it to you, in response to Senator Ray's point of order, that I can point out where I have been misrepresented only if I point out first the fact that the Minister did not present the full facts in putting his point, which is what I am in the process of doing. It was put forward not in isolation, as one might have thought from his answer to Senator Black, but as part of a total package of proposals for cutting Commonwealth spending in order to finance a reduction in the rates of both personal income tax and company tax to not more than 25 per cent. I say in conclusion that when Senator Walsh and his Government get within a bull's roar of that achievement they will be in a better position to criticise me and anyone else for suggesting ways of doing so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Senator Sheil, in the course of his personal explanation a few moments ago, repeated his statement that I had received and neglected to respond to an invitation to visit Coolangatta Airport to inspect air traffic control facilities and systems there. In answer to a question yesterday I said that I had no recollection of receiving any such invitation. Senator Sheil has now referred me to a letter from Mr Leo Gately, MLA, the member for Currumbin, couched in the offensive terms that one has come, regrettably, to expect from Queensland conservative members of parliament. It says no more than this:

SPEECH.PARA: I therefore respectfully request-
I think that is a lawyer's `respectfully' that has been put in there-
that you undertake a full investigation into this incident-
he was referring to the incident on 6 May-
and make out a report to be made available to me at your earliest convenience and to include the following:

There is then a series of detailed points in that respect. I recall receiving the letter in question. I certainly had not recalled any invitation to personally visit and talk to the air traffic controllers coming from anyone in a position of authority to issue such an invitation. It is self-evidently the case from the text of the letter which Senator Sheil has just had incorporated that there was no such invitation in any terms that could remotely be so construed. Before me there is simply a request that there be an investigation. There is of course an investigation of all such incidents. It occurs through appropriate departmental processes and that is the way in which I will be replying to the letter in question. I indicate that, of course, I remain willing to personally visit facilities of this kind when issues of the kind that are involved in the present discussion are alive and I would be happy to do that on some appropriate occasion. I do not find it helpful to the cause of public debate or political decency to be the subject of highly personalised allegations on a matter of this kind for which there is manifestly no foundation.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the House of Representatives without amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
This report of the Aboriginal Development Commission 1986-87 may report the last full year of the ADC as a functioning body working to advantage Aboriginal Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps not.

—Perhaps not, if we have our way. The passing or alteration of the Commission, the corruption of the Commission by the Government, will be tragic for Aboriginal people. It was established during a period when my colleague Senator Chaney was the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Honourable senators will recall that the second reading speech introducing the Bill for establishing the Aboriginal Development Commission was made by then Senator Neville Bonner. The ADC has emerged through a difficult period of development. It has learned its administrative task not the easy way but by making mistakes and answering for them. It has emerged as an effective administrative body. It has learnt to say no to importunate demands as well as how to say yes to good demands. Its commissioners have learned to exercise independent judgment in circumstances where this has been very difficult because of other obligations.

SPEECH.PARA: The question is: What does the Aboriginal Development Commission face today? The commissioners were properly appointed. Their photographs appear in this report. They are eminent Aboriginal Australians, many of whom were known to me and respected by me while I was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer to people such as Shirley McPherson, who is still the Chairman of the Commission. Mr Mick Miller, for all his radical politics, played fair by me a couple of times when, as Minister, I needed it. I put that on record. Getano Lui, Jr, Ossie Cruse and many other commissioners who have been involved in Aboriginal affairs and administration for years and who have proved themselves, have been sacked.

TALK.START.PARA: —Getano is back on.

—I am grateful for that. The commissioners who were party to this report have refused to accommodate themselves to Government proposals to abolish several independent bodies such as the Commission, Aboriginal Hostels Ltd, the Institute of Aboriginal Studies, et cetera and to incorporate them into a new proposed body, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. Yesterday the Senate was very fortunate to debate and agree to a motion of urgency moved by Senator Coulter. That motion called upon the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) to allow any legislation to establish the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission to lie before the Parliament for at least six months. I hope that the Government will do that. The motion called for more active involvement of Aboriginal people and groups in consultation and for the possible amendment of legislation. I hope the Minister will do that. The motion also called for the reinstatement of the Aboriginal Development Commission as it was constituted before the recent dismissal of commissioners and for some other things.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has sacked the commissioners of the ADC. It has appointed its mates. Senator Coulter set out the issues. It worries us that this Minister is altering structures, rewarding his mates, getting rid of those who have exercised power responsibly and appointing those who he thinks might be more compliant to his wishes. In the process, like a dervish, he has been destroying Aboriginal structures which work-for example, Aboriginal Hostels Pty Ltd, which has worked well for Aboriginals. It is all an exercise in mad ideology by Minister Hand. It will promote discord and worse administrative practice and will aggravate community discord among the wider Australian community. The cause proposed in yesterday's urgency motion is the least we can do not only for Aboriginal people but also for the pursuit of the maintenance of what the Aboriginal Development Commission is and what it has stood for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In light of what Senator Peter Baume said in his speech, I think I should say some things about the 1986-87 annual report of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). The honourable senator has, of course, a great record in this area. But I think it would be appropriate for him to look at what the situation really is at this time. The situation is-and through you, Mr Deputy President, I ask Senator Baume to take this on board-that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) is establishing a Commission which, to borrow a phrase coined by a great President of the United States of America, will be elected of the Aboriginal community, by the Aboriginal community, for the Aboriginal community. It is in those circumstances that the present situation of the Aboriginal Development Commission should be seen.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister wants the body elected by the Aboriginal people to have control over all their affairs, including those affairs that are presently handled by the Aboriginal Development Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why sack the Commission?

—Because the Commission, for whatever reason, does not go along with what the Minister says. In an Aboriginal Development Commission media release of 17 December 1987, Mrs McPherson was quoted as stating that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission was to be nothing more than the old Department of Aboriginal Affairs under another name-`nothing more than an upstart crow dressed in parrot's plumes'. She went on to make two inaccurate statements. Firstly, she said that `all the decision-making power will rest with the Government'; secondly, she said `the ADC Act already provides for a majority of the commissioners to be elected'. In fact, the new Commission will have the same autonomy in relation to all the current responsibilities that the ADC enjoys plus a number of other functions. The plain fact is that the ADC Act provides for all the commissioners to be appointed by the Governor-General.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the Minister who is responsible for Aboriginal affairs to do if he is unable to carry out a plan because of actions by the ADC? That is the situation in this case. Who is in charge of Aboriginal affairs? Who is the elected representative of the people with responsibility in Parliament to answer for Aboriginal affairs? It is not the ADC.

TALK.START.PARA: —They only gave him advice.

—It is not the ADC, I point out to Senator Tambling; it is the Minister. If the Minister is unable to carry out the plan for which he has a mandate because of attitudes and actions taken by the ADC, is he to resign or has the Commission got to give way?
—In this case, yes.

—Senator Chaney, of course, says yes. The reality of the matter is this: He is in opposition. He will remain in opposition if his approach to government is one where elected Ministers should give way to those who should properly listen to the policies of an elected government and carry them out. If they are not going to do that and if it becomes impossible for the Minister to carry out his policy, something simply has to give way. That is the reality of the matter. The action taken by the Minister in regard to the court case was in line with the position held by the legislative arm. Indeed, the result of the court case has vindicated what the Minister did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I know that a lot of senators want to speak on this paper, and that is hardly surprising when the Government has just dismissed the majority of the board members of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). Indeed, they have been dismissed since this report was prepared. I just want to make a couple of things clear in this debate. The Aboriginal Development Commission is under the chairmanship of Shirley McPherson. She is an Aboriginal woman and a qualified accountant-the sort of person who is doing things which the whole community would approve of. She is someone who has brought to this Commission a demand that Aboriginal people should receive money from it only when they are accountable for that money and are prepared to use that money for the reasons it was given. She is a person who has brought a strict approach to the administration of an element of Aboriginal affairs. She is a person who has run the Commission after it was inquired into and much criticised by various parliamentary committees. The Commission has met those criticisms. We are now in a situation where, in Senator Barney Cooney's immortal words, the commissioners have been dismissed because they have not done what the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) has told them. What an absolute, wonderful exposure of the basic Australian Labor Party attitudes to an independent commission!

SPEECH.PARA: The Aboriginal Development Commission set out to ensure that there are commercially viable enterprises run only by Aboriginal people with proper accountability for the taxpayers' funds involved. There is a clear five-year plan for the building of houses, both for purchase and lease by Aboriginal people. The Commission has a clear approach to ensuring that the sorts of abuses of taxpayers' funds that have occurred in the past do not occur in the future.

I want to make the point that the people who have been affected by this Government are people who have long been supporters of the Labor Party. The three consultants who were dismissed by the new board of the ADC included Kate George, who will be known to many people here as the first wife of Minister John Dawkins. She is someone I have worked with in Aboriginal affairs since the early 1970s when she and I were members of the Aboriginal Legal Service. She is one of the people who have been dismissed. She is not some Liberal stooge; she is not some opponent of the Government. She is somebody who has been trying to work with the Aboriginal people for virtually the whole of her adult life. She is somebody who was a great friend of the late Gloria Brennan, who would be known to Aboriginals throughout Australia as one of the people who are trying to get some order and sense into Aboriginal affairs.

Ossie Cruse, who has been dismissed, is a splendid example of what people want to see in the Aboriginal community. He happens to be the President of the Aboriginal Evangelical Fellowship. Perhaps the fact that he is an active member of that organisation puts him on the nose to the Minister. But the truth is that he is an absolutely splendid, fine person. He is a man who has been in ill odour with the Minister because he got his Aboriginal organisation in Eden to join with the rest of the community in a bicentennial project. What a dreadfully offensive thing to do! Of course, Mr Hand has divorced himself from the bicentennial celebrations for some reason that he seems to connect with the advancement of Aboriginal people. I defy anyone in the Labor Party in this place to say a word against Mr Ossie Cruse, who is one of the finest Aboriginal people with whom I have ever worked. I would have to say that he gave me plenty of curry when I was Minister. As the Labor appointed Chairman of the Aboriginal Land Trust in New South Wales and as a member of the National Aboriginal Conference he was a fearless critic of government when we were in government. But fearless critics of government do not fare very well under Minister Hand. Next I refer to John Newfong. I do not think anyone would claim he is some sort of anti-Government stooge.
