This Aboriginal who has had a distinguished career as a writer and journalist has also been sacked.

The fact of the matter is that this Commission, which is aiming to produce effective and efficient services by Aboriginals for Aboriginals without the waste which has excited so much political passion and public opposition over recent years, is being carved up. Let me put one caveat on the record. If this Government now tries to discredit the Aboriginal Development Commission by selective leaks, which I believe have already started, and by now starting to push our moneys through the Commission, particularly to projects which have not previously received the approval of the Commission because they have been doubtful from accounting and other points of view, we are going to see something that this Parliament is going to have to bring the Government to book for. I will be seeking the support of the Australian Democrats and I acknowledge their lead yesterday in bringing this matter before the Parliament to ensure that the Government does not get away with murder in its treatment of the Aboriginal Development Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report before us, the 1986-87 annual report of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC), is, in fact, dated April. I believe that it has been available for some time. One wonders why it has been left until now before it has been brought forward. One is suspicious that it may have something to do with the events of the last week in relation to the dismissals that Senator Chaney has just referred to.

SPEECH.PARA: The ADC was created in 1980. As Senator Peter Baume has pointed out, there was a very moving speech at that time by the only Aboriginal senator in this place, Senator Neville Bonner, in which he remarked on the fact that the ADC would be `placing the decision-making process in the hands of Aboriginal people, making them instruments of their own advancement'. The function of the Commission is defined as:

. . . to further the economic and social development of people of the Aboriginal race of Australia and people who are descendants of indigenous inhabitants of the Torres Strait Islands, and, in particular, (as a recognition of past dispossession and dispersal of such people) to establish a Capital Account with the object of promoting their development, self-management and self-efficiency.

It is a matter of clear record that the ADC legislation is the only legislation which recognises prior Aboriginal occupation and the responsibility which devolves upon the European community as a consequence of that. It is not surprising that this piece of legislation is, therefore, repugnant to the present Government. It is also interesting to note that no additions have been made to the capital fund in the life of the Labor Government; they ceased in 1982-83.

As indicated by previous speakers, there was an inquiry into the ADC spanning 1984-85. A number of suggestions came out of the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure. It suggested that a corporate plan be developed and implemented. It suggested that there be a development of programs and procedures, and manuals which would outline those procedures; that there be a network of linking computers which would facilitate the devolution of power from the central ADC to regional offices; and that the loan functions also be centralised.

The annual report before us indicates that every single one of those recommendations which were made in 1984-85 by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure has been implemented. As Senator Chaney has pointed out, we have in charge of the ADC now, in the position of Chairman, Mrs Shirley McPherson, who is an accountancy graduate of the Western Australian Institute of Technology.

TALK.START.PARA: —A lovely woman.

—As indicated, she is a lovely woman. She is also extremely competent and professional. As a consequence, the ADC has carried out the following intentions, and I quote from the previous annual report:

SPEECH.PARA: higher priority shall be given to loan applications as against grant applications;
loans shall be the method of funding where there is a capacity to repay.

Not surprisingly, that action has meant that many Aboriginal individuals in relation to housing loans, and Aboriginal groups in relation to business loans, have found themselves denied funds, or, where loans have been made and those loans have not been properly serviced, then those loans have been foreclosed. By becoming a more professional and responsible organisation, the ADC has acquired some dissatisfied customers-those who still believe in welfare rather than independence and economic competence.

Senator Chaney also referred to the spreading of misinformation. In the moment left to me I will point out that I believe-I have not yet seen the article-that the later editions of the Sydney Morning Herald this morning make a claim, which presumably is based on claims coming from the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) or from people in his Department, that the ADC has spent $670,000 in its efforts to defeat the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission proposal. My understanding is that only 14 per cent of that amount of money was indeed spent in that way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is impossible in five minutes to canvass all the issues that are associated with the tabling of this annual report of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) for 1986-87 which, under any other circumstances, would probably not have been perhaps as contentious as it is at the moment. That is probably the understatement of 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the speakers in the debate I think have missed the point a little so far in that there is an assumption in what has been said that the functions of the ADC that have been carried out-in what I believe has been an efficient and beneficial manner to the Aboriginal community in Australia-will not be continued under the proposed new Commission.

I want to make a number of matters quite clear. The commissioners who were dismissed by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) were not dismissed for any personal reasons in the sense that they had not discharged their functions correctly.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was just that they disagreed with the Minister.

—That is correct; I will canvass that in a minute. They had discharged their proper functions under the ADC. I must make that point in the House because I certainly had a hand in the appointment of more than one of those commissioners in making recommendations to the former Minister for their appointment. On a personal level-I said this when I was interviewed by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation on the subject in the Northern Territory-I think it was unfortunate and regrettable that that action had to be taken, because of some feelings that may be held by some of the commissioners at least that they had personally behaved in a way which warranted their dismissal. That is not the case.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that the ADC has had a difficult charter to fulfil. I just want to make one point in terms of how it has fulfilled the charter in reference to a comment that Senator Chaney made. If there were any stories about that perhaps the ADC did not succeed as well as it could in delivering its functions, I would have to make one obvious point in defence of the ADC. It is an extremely easy organisation to criticise and it is extremely easy to find critics of it, because anyone who has been knocked back for a loan from the ADC will, of course, criticise it. It is not a very easy matter to say no in the area of Aboriginal affairs. It is one of the more difficult portfolios to administer. The ADC had to say no on many occasions. Quite often there will be complaints about the ADC from people who, not unnaturally, have been aggrieved by the fact that their applications for loan funds were knocked back. They are not criticisms on which I personally place any weight because I think that, by and large, the ADC has carried out its functions quite well.

But that same defence also applies to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Quite understandably in my view, the ADC said no to a policy decision that had been taken quite correctly and quite properly by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to establish the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). I said at the beginning of this short address that some of the people who have spoken in this debate have perhaps missed the point a little. There will be one substantial difference between the current ADC and the proposed ATSIC. The reason why the Minister was able to dismiss the former commissioners is that he was able to appoint them. The major difference between the current ADC and the proposed ATSIC is that the substantial majority of the commissioners on ATSIC will be elected by the Aboriginal community of Australia. That is a move forward which was supported by all honourable senators who spoke in the debate on Foundations for the Future.

I fully understand and appreciate the reasons why the Minister had to take the action that he did. For the benefit of those aggrieved commissioners, I stress again that the action does not in any way reflect on them personally in regard to the way in which they carried out their functions as ADC commissioners. It is simply that the Government was elected to implement its policy. The particular policy now under discussion is the establishment of ATSIC. The ADC opposed that policy to the extent of taking legal action to prevent it. The Minister was perfectly entitled, therefore, to take the action that he did. When ATSIC commences, the functions that are currently administered by the ADC will then be administered by ATSIC under elected, rather than appointed, Aboriginal representatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very unusual for a Minister to intervene during the consideration of papers, but I wish to speak briefly. I guarantee that Senator Tambling will get his full five minutes to speak. Senator Coulter made an attack on the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) concerning the timing of the furnishing of this annual report to the chamber. I simply wish to point out that the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) was obliged to report by 31 December 1987, but the Commission informed the Minister that it could not meet the 31 December 1987 deadline because of delays in finalising the financial statements owing to new procedures. The ADC accordingly applied to the Minister on 13 November 1987 for an extension until 29 February 1988. On 8 February the ADC sought a second extension until 22 April because of delays in the Australian Audit Office. On 27 April the Audit Office provided financial statements signed by the Auditor-General, and on 4 May the ADC sought a third extension until 24 May to allow for printing time.

SPEECH.PARA: I just want to make it very clear that the ADC was the body responsible for seeking to have the tabling of the annual report delayed. If I have caused anybody to miss out on a minute or two, I will grant leave for an extension of time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report before us today by the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) is a very commendable one because it looks, as other senators have said, at the story of an organisation that has grown through many growth pains to a position of success. It has certainly been successful in the development of people who are exercising considerable representation on behalf of Aboriginal groups throughout Australia. It has been very interesting to note the difference in the contributions of Senator Cooney and Senator Collins. Senator Cooney took an apologist line, whereas Senator Collins seemed to have a very real understanding of the performance of this Commission in the particular parts of Australia in which it has carried out its functions.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out that the section in the report which outlines the functions of the Commission includes the statement that it is:

to give advice and make recommendations to the Minister with respect to the furtherance of the economic and social development of Aboriginals; and such other functions in connection with the furtherance of the economic and social development of Aboriginals as the Minister determines by notice in writing to the Commission.

The document Foundations for the Future certainly flagged that invitation and it was very mindful of the fact that the commissioners should undertake the role they did. The fact is that they were critical of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, with regard to this matter and I believe he has shown his arrogance by riding across the advice they gave.

In looking at this report we can see that it embraces a whole range of functions to do with finance corporate services, housing and in particular commercial and business enterprises. They are most important and are the success story of the Aboriginal Development Commission. If we look at the chapter entitled `Corporate Services' on page 7 we will see that the Commission dealt with an additional 640 submissions during the period under consideration. Forty-four per cent of them were for commercial development, 24 per cent were for housing loans, 15 per cent were for corporate services, 10 per cent were for housing grants, and 7 per cent were for management functions. The success of this Commission always stands on a document such as this, the annual report. As Senator Collins has said, the 10 commissioners named in this report can all stand proud, as can the other commissioners who were subsequently appointed and then sacked by the Minister. There was absolutely no reason whatsoever for sacking them on any grounds of personal incompetence and personal irresponsibility and in fact it was a very great slight to all of them by this Government.

The area currently under consideration is the development of a new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. (Extension of time granted) The role proposed for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission is certainly intended to embrace the functions already given to the ADC. I have argued in this place, and I am sure many others would do the same, that because of the very success of the Aboriginal Development Commission as an appropriate and responsible commercial body carrying out delegated functions, there is no established or demonstrated need for the Commission to be put under an umbrella and gobbled up by various social security, education and welfare functions. It is the very amalgam proposed by the Government that will doom this great area of Aboriginal advancement to failure. That concerns me, because it is the Aboriginal people of Australia who will stand to lose. The wealth of experience and responsibility that has been demonstrated and built up by the Aboriginal Development Commission should be enhanced and certainly not put down. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —The time for the consideration of Government Papers has now expired.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON VIDEO MATERIAL

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 May, on motion by Senator Chaney.
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like the opportunity of saying a few words in relation to the report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material. I take the liberty of reminding the Senate that at the end of 1984 I moved for the establishment of a joint committee to examine the material that had been allowed to flood into Australia as a result of the activities of the then Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans. We had had a number of debates in the Senate about the effect of his decisions, particularly in relation to the new category of X-rated material which Senator Evans had been negotiating with his State colleagues responsible for censorship.

SPEECH.PARA: It was clear that there was a great deal of community concern and controversy about this policy of the then Attorney-General, indeed of the Hawke Government. As a result of that concern which had been expressed over quite a period of time, on behalf of the Opposition I moved for the establishment of the committee. Unfortunately the Government then did not agree with the concept of having a joint committee or a parliamentary committee investigate this matter. Following the 1984 election and the advent of Mr Bowen as Attorney-General, the Government took a slightly more conciliatory and rational approach to this question and the Committee known as the Joint Committee on Video Material was set up, and early in 1985 it took over the work which had been begun by the Senate Committee. It has been working away at it ever since. It has only just reported, about three years after it was first set up.

On the one hand, I must express some disappointment at the time it took the Committee to report. On the other hand, I must express my satisfaction about the views of the majority of that Committee. Unfortunately, it was a narrow majority. Six of the 11 members of that Committee have made a number of recommendations with which I agree and to which I would like to lend my support in the short time we have to discuss the report today. However, I hope there will be subsequent occasions when there will be more time fully to debate this matter.

The Committee came to consider the question of what is generally referred to as pornographic material. In some places it is called video nasties, but generally speaking it is referred to as X-rated material, although in Australia, by virtue of some close consideration of this material and perhaps tighter administration of it by our own censorship board, X-rated material had been somewhat narrowed from the wider and even more offensive and more harmful material of that kind. Such material, largely depicting sexual violence in extreme and highly dangerous forms, has not been permitted in Australia. Nevertheless, a lot of that material does seem to slip through.

The other unfortunate aspect is that, despite the establishment of the Committee to review and report on this material, the Hawke Government and even Attorney-General Bowen have permitted a classification of X-rated material in the Australian Capital Territory. Even though the Committee was looking at the material, the laws the Government introduced in 1984 are still on the statute book. That, coupled with the easing of the importation of such material, has enabled it-albeit a limited type of X-rated material-to continue to flood the whole of Australia. That has placed a considerable strain on State governments because, over this period of three years, all the State governments have banned X-rated material.

It is interesting that despite the apparent agreement the then Attorney-General, Senator Evans, made with State governments in 1984, the State governments felt the pressure of public opinion much more immediately than the Federal Government seems to have done. State governments have banned that material. In Western Australia and one other State, I believe, the possession of such material has been banned because the banning of the commercial sale of the material was not effective when it was available through mail order from the Australian Capital Territory under the permissive laws that the then Attorney-General introduced even though his colleagues in State Labor governments as well as State Liberal governments had banned the material. Indeed, that material had always been banned in Australia prior to the libertarian permissiveness of the Hawke Government and its first Attorney-General, Senator Evans.

An unfortunate aspect of the report has been the confusion about its findings. The majority of six members cuts across the party lines. They are: the honourable member for Fairfax, Mr Adermann, of the National Party, the honourable member for Isaacs, Mr David Charles, and the honourable member for Forde, Ms Mary Crawford, of the Labor Party; independent Senator Brian Harradine; and the honourable member for Fadden, Mr David Jull and Senator Walters of the Liberal Party. They are the six members who formed the majority view which is, in simple terms, that the X rating should be abandoned and that there should not be a new category which incorporates the X rating, although there is some difference of opinion about whether there should be an additional category to accommodate some of this material. However, they are all agreed that the X-rated material as it exists at the moment should be stopped from being imported into Australia or being sold in any part of Australia. That particularly involves a change of the law of the Australian Capital Territory.

I commend the work that has been done, particularly in relation to scientific evidence that the Committee commissioned. The reports contain some very useful summaries of the wealth of scientific evidence. Opinion has differed between the majority of the Committee members and the minority about the significance of that material. But the fact of the matter is that the onus of proof that such material is not harmful or damaging to people and will not result in bizarre and criminal behaviour on the part of some people rests on those who want to make the material legal. That sort of scientific approach was never undertaken by the then Attorney-General, Senator Evans, or the Hawke Government. It allowed this material to flood into Australia in defiance of real concerns that some scientists have expressed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Others have expressed differently.

—Admittedly, other scientists take a different view, but that is not good enough with this material. I know that Senator Zakharov also takes a libertarian view, but that is simply not good enough; it is totally irresponsible. When there is plenty of scientific evidence, as is the case, to say that the material could well pose a risk, we as legislators should take note of that and should not risk it being let loose on the Australian public. Therefore, I would like to call strongly on the Government to introduce legislation without delay to give effect to the view of the majority of members of the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the luncheon break, I was pointing out to the Senate the reality of what a purely one vote one value system would do to the rural electors of Queensland and Australia. Before I continue in that vein, I seek leave to incorporate a table in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reality is that if rural Queensland loses its State representation, the result will be a loss of State government services as the State members of parliament fight for their share of State government revenue around the south-east corner of Queensland. Rural Queensland will be neglected as health services run down; hospitals close; if possible, roads become worse than they are already after this Government's reduction in road funding; decentralisation as it is known now will be a thing of the past; small schools will close down; school bus routes will be removed; and government departments and depots will be gradually sent back to more populated areas. The outback of Queensland will be depopulated. That will happen if rural representation is removed. One must be prepared to take that into account when one moves a one vote one value Bill. No-one in the Senate would want that.

SPEECH.PARA: Only a few intrepid graziers or farmers and miners will be left to provide the services to give a decent standard of living to rural Queensland and rural Australia. The Bill will deny electors the equality of their vote as they will have no access to their members of Parliament and there will be no community of interest. Rural Australia's ethos and voice could be lost forever; it will be lost in State governments and in the State upper Houses. Rural Australia's voice will be a lone cry in the wilderness. In any Westminster system of Parliament, a weightage system operates to compensate for distances and rural electorates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not this one.

—I am glad Senator Ray is present to hear my speech. He may learn something. Great Britain allows four to one; the United States of America allows three to one; Canada allows 12 to one; and Queensland is running at three to one at present. The Government has never had any sympathy with rural Australia and nothing has changed as a result of the introduction of this Bill. Senator Ray should listen to this: the irony of the one vote one value legislation is that it will probably make the National Party stronger. The seats removed from the country will be placed in the Gold Coast and the Sunshine Coast. The two new seats in Brisbane will be won by either the Liberal Party or the National Party. The position in provincial cities will be improved by the expansion of voters to take in country dwellers who are traditionally National Party supporters. The whole question of one vote one value is a sham. It will not win government for the Labor Party because it will have to achieve 51 per cent of the vote to do so, and at present it is running at around 46 per cent of the vote, which is the best it has ever done, and at a worst approximately 36 per cent. The Bill will destroy rural Australia and will destroy rural Queensland.
—Ha, ha!
—Senator Ray laughs but I shall quote to him an article in the Sunday Mail editorial of 28 February 1988. If Senator Ray does not believe what I say, maybe he will believe the Sunday Mail.

SPEECH.PARA: But one vote one value is a noble illusion; to adopt it as things stand would be an abrogation of responsibility, a decision to indulge ourselves forever along the coast, content with smooth roads, good plumbing and lots of telly.
In Queensland's unique circumstances, stripped of its hyperbole, it means to hell with the bush, and to hell with development west of the Great Divide.
The National Party is not saying that; that is a quote from the Sunday Mail, a Brisbane based newspaper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who owns it?

—It is irrelevant who owns the newspaper; it is certainly not Queensland Country Life, if Senator Ray is applying that criterion to it. I do not have time to deal with the third question but I shall speak to the fourth question, which extends the guarantee of trial by jury, freedom of religion and fair compensation for property acquired by the Government. Those rights are implied; we have them at present. This legislation is no more than a Bill of Rights. The Labor Government proposed a Bill of Rights during the last Parliament but it had to retreat from that position when it became obvious that electors would have no bar of it. Australians do not want their rights written into the Constitution. Australia's system of law and order is based on British common law and not on the American type Bill of Rights. If rights are written into the Constitution, they will be open to interpretation by a centralised High Court and also become limited to what is precisely written. Any rights that are not included could be negated by their non-inclusion. That is not the Australian way. Australians are overwhelmingly against the danger of putting words on paper to define rights and freedoms which would place exorbitant amounts of interpretive power on the High Court.

SPEECH.PARA: If the fourth Bill is carried, it may well be the end of religious education and prayers in government schools because a High Court may very well rule that a Christian prayer is offensive to atheists, agnostics or people of different faiths such as Buddhists or Moslems.

TALK.START.PARA: —That happens every day here.

—That has happened in America under its Constitution; no longer are prayers allowed to be offered and children are denied the right to religious education in American public schools despite the Christian stand of the American President, Mr Ronald Reagan. The first amendment of the American Constitution, which is also the beginning of its Bill of Rights states:

SPEECH.PARA: Congress shall make no law reflecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof . . .

This has an amazing likeness to the Government's Bill; I suggest it is a direct take-off. The first amendment has been interpreted in the American courts as not allowing prayers or religious education in public schools where government expenditure would be seen to be aiding or making a law concerning the establishment of religion. These are the dangers and minefields that lie in waiting if we allow a Bill of Rights to be cemented in our Constitution. It would become a double-edged sword and would possibly achieve the reverse of the original intention. It is essential, if Australians are to continue to enjoy democratic rights and freedoms, that these not be stamped and sealed in a legal document which would be subject to legal interpretation for hundreds of years into the future. Who knows what the High Court of Australia will do in those times?

I am not willing to see our present rights and those of future Australians destroyed over time. As senators, we should be the guardians of democracy, not the vehicles for its demise. I urge all Australians to reject the referenda. Nothing is to be gained by voting for any one of these questions. They do not allow for fewer elections; they do not provide for free and fair elections; they give nothing to local government but tokenism; and they do nothing for the freedom or rights of any Australian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a Liberal senator for South Australia, I believe the Labor Government's referendum package is a direct attack on the rights of the States and on the Senate and, as such, will seriously undermine the balance of our Federation and the effectiveness of our Parliament. Nowhere is this attack on the States more obvious than in the referendum proposal to neutralise the Senate. Australians relied on the Senate to save them from Labor's Bill of Rights and the identity card. They must now reject the latest attempt to reduce the power of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: One essential point to be understood is this: the questions to be asked bear little relationship to the actual legislation involved. Mr Gary Morgan, Australia's leading polling consultant, has said that any public opinion polling company `who asked questions as blatantly biased as the Government proposes would completely lose credibility'. For the exercise, the first question, which is titled `four-year terms', could be titled instead-accurately based on the legislation-`to abolish fixed terms for senators and to ensure all senators alike face an election whenever there is a House of Representatives election'. The second question, the so-called fair and democratic elections question, could be alternatively titled, `to force the States to prohibit malapportionment in all State electorates'. Nothing in the legislation affects gerrymanders, which Senator Ray has already acknowledged.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I haven't. That is untrue.

—By the legislation gerrymanders cannot be prohibited but they certainly can be by State legislation to prohibit malapportionment as is the case in South Australia, where it was introduced by a Liberal government. The third question, the so-called recognition of local government, could alternatively be titled, `to override the States by adding a vague reference to local government in the Federal Constitution'.

SPEECH.PARA: The fourth question is made up of a package of three matters. Instead of being titled `to extend the right to trial by jury', `to extend freedom of religion' and `to ensure fair terms for persons whose property is acquired by any Government', they could be titled: firstly, `to provide that juries be of any number and reach conclusions by majority verdicts'; secondly, `to prevent governments not only from making laws to establish any religion but also from taking any executive action in this direction'; and, thirdly, instead of so positively asserting `just compensation', it could be `to override the States in matters of compensation for land acquisition'. I put it to the honourable senators that those titles are not much freer of bias than the titles the Government has chosen for its quite detailed proposed amendments. I assert that the questions to be asked bear little relationship to the actual legislation involved. This is important because the matters that have been described by the titles that the Government is proposing are all motherhood questions.

Everybody I have ever spoken to in Australia is in favour of fair elections. Most people would like to see a sensible way of achieving four-year terms for government. Most people would like to see ensured freedom of religion, just compensation and the appropriate application of trial by jury. Most people in Australia want to see an appropriate place and powers for local government. So if we put it on those terms, on a superficial reading we would expect that the majority of Australians would like these vague and superficial references. But the point is that these references are wrongly chosen as a description of the actual amendments to the Constitution.

For reasons which I will now outline-I will deal with the matters one at a time-I am opposed to each of the proposed amendments. I believe that the Constitution should be safeguarded by the people of Australia rejecting each of the referendum proposals.

Let me also add that the referendum proposals are not politically neutral; they are enormously biased to advantage the objectives of the Australian Labor Party. Indeed, they even have the immediate short term effect of extending the life of the present Hawke Government by six months. The next half Senate election is due by June 1990. If constitutional amendment No. 1 is approved in September that will no longer be the case and the Senate will face election, at the furthest extremity, in November 1990 when the House of Representatives election is due. For the reasons Senator Stone outlined here very effectively yesterday against the incredible claims of Senator McMullan, any sensible political observer knows that that will be the effect of the first question with regard to the life of the present Hawke Government. If this question is passed, a subsequent parliament would have a four-year term-that is, four years from the first sitting of that parliament-and, presumably, that would take it into February, which is 4 1/4 years from the November 1990 election. So there would be ample latitude in a subsequent election for the government of the day to pick any day in November, or any day in December, or even to go to an election early in 1995.

This will have enormous consequences in giving more latitude to the present Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, to work out his retirement in the light of what might then appear to be the certain defeat of the Labor Government and to make arrangements for Mr Keating, Mr Dawkins, Mr Beazley, or whoever else it may be in the other place, to succeed him and, at the same time as Mr Hawke steps down, for the author of this legislation-the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Lionel Bowen, to step down. That extra latitude gives time for such rearrangements and it also distances this Government from the predicted worldwide recession of 1989. On the Government's reckoning, the further away from 1989 that it chooses to have an election, the more likely it is to be successful. These measures are not politically neutral. They give an enormous advantage to the present Government to have an extended term of office. This is offensive to me and it ought to be offensive to the Australian people.

One accusation that has been made by Paul Kelly of the Australian newspaper, which has been quoted by Government senators ad nauseam in the debate, is that the Opposition is only being negative; it does not have any actual arguments and is just being reactive. Indeed, some Government senators have even added that the Opposition is being opportunistic in opposing these referendum proposals. I want to make it quite clear that that biased article by Paul Kelly and the accusation that there is non substance to the decision by the Opposition are completely baseless.

Let me quickly move on to give the sound reasons why the Opposition rejects all these proposals. I point out in passing that, for many years, the Opposition and I have advocated reforms to the Constitution-such well-known amendments as the Court proposal, the Rae proposal and the Hamer proposal. The first question concerns the abolition of the fixed term of the Senate and is described by the Government as four-year terms. A strong Senate is an important protection for smaller States such as South Australia. A strong Senate is vital to discouraging hasty or rash decisions, for example, the Bill of Rights, but also legislation which is now before us in the Senate on the National Board for Employment, Education and Training. I believe that legislation will be significantly amended in Senate debate over the coming seven days. This will be achieved in this place whereas it was not achieved in the House where the Government has an absolute majority.

The Senate stopped the insidious Bill of Rights and Labor's identity card and, as a pay back, the Hawke Government is now trying to stop the Senate. This referendum proposal would reduce the term of senators from a fixed six years to a maximum of four years and increase the term of the House of Representatives from a maximum of three years to a maximum of four years. The 88-year-old practice of fixed terms for the Senate would be abolished. Equally, the practice of electing half the Senate at a different time from the government of the day would also be abolished. To elect the whole Senate at each election takes away the stability the Senate has always provided and gives nothing in return. This has never applied to any upper House in any of the State parliaments. In addition, the Senate would no longer be an effective House of review. The Senate would become a rubber stamp of the House of Representatives. They would always be elected simultaneously.

The Government claims that this referendum proposal will lead to fewer elections. In fact, it is likely to cause more elections. This is because the abolition of the present six-year fixed term of senators would allow the Prime Minister to call a simultaneous election for both Houses at any time he likes. As I have said, it is not surprising that Mr Hawke wants the first question approved, since its immediate political impact would be significantly to advantage the Labor Party by effectively extending the tenure of office of the Hawke Government by six months. More precisely, the deadline for the next election could be put off from 2 June to 17 November 1990.

The coalition supports an increase in the House of Representatives' term from three years to four years but it strongly believes that the Senate's term should be twice that of the House of Representatives. That has always been the case, and that system has served Australia well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Eight years?

—There are three alternative ways, Senator Ray, of doing what I have broadly described. The first of these I would call the simplest. The simplest way is to change the Constitution to allow the six-year fixed term of the Senate to become eight years. This would allow some ability to manage simultaneous elections for the House of Representatives and half the Senate in a similar pattern to that which we have now. This is all on the basis that the term of the House of Representatives would change from three years to four.

SPEECH.PARA: The second alternative is what I would call the most convenient-at least for government-and that is to give the Senate two terms of the House of Representatives and have simultaneous elections, but this is not a secure and stable basis for the Senate. For example, a Prime Minister could, in the honeymoon of his recent election, six months later have an immediate simultaneous election in which he would wipe out that half of the Senate that was elected the time before and which he would reckon was at odds with the electoral mood that had put him in office.

Therefore, I put forward the third and sensible compromise approach, which is to have two terms of the House of Representatives on the conditions that a minimum of six years has been served by senators. This is what I would otherwise call the South Australian model. It is exactly what happens in South Australia. I seriously put it forward in this debate as a constructive way, which I am confident would gain the assent of both sides-both major parties at least-in the Senate because there would be a guarantee of a minimum six-year term for senators, as there is now. There would be a four-year maximum term for the House of Representatives and there would be an ability for half of the Senate to miss a House of Representatives election if the Prime Minister opportunistically called a quick election.

The South Australian model, I believe, has settled down well. In my own State it applies to the Legislative Council. It is a model that could be followed to achieve a four-year term for the House of Representatives, rather than the proposal that is before us in this referendum, question No. 1. I note in passing that the Government's proposal is not even the recommendation of the Constitutional Commission, which it set up at great expense and whose first report, the summary version, of May-that is, this month-says on page 16:

We recommend that the Constitution be altered to provide that: (i) Senators chosen in the States shall hold their places for two terms of the House of Representatives except in the event of a double dissolution;

Against the advice of its own Commission, the Government is proceeding with a maximum four-year term for the Senate in which all the Senate comes out on the occasion of every House of Representatives election. I predict that this referendum question will fail because it will not be supported by the people of Australia in the majorities that are required for changing the Constitution.

Question No. 2 forces the States to prohibit malapportionment in all State electorates. The Government has described this proposal as one for `fair and democratic elections'. This question undermines the federalist nature of our system because it seeks to enforce on individual States the particular form of electoral arrangements that they should have. I believe that it should be left to each State to determine its own electoral system and not have it imposed by Canberra. It is my view that each State should determine by its own Act that there is a prohibition of malapportionment. Labor governments have often sought to override the States. Labor objectives are centralist, wanting more and more power for Canberra. The Hawke Labor Government forgets that sovereign States, including South Australia, my own State, created this Commonwealth.

Despite the misleading title that the Government has given to this question, it does not provide for fair and democratic parliamentary elections. Indeed, it does not even try to stop the rigging of electoral boundaries. There is no way anyone can guarantee a strict one vote one value election. This proposal has a tolerance figure of plus 10 per cent or minus 10 per cent, thus revealing its own inherent weakness. The question imposes a standard on the States that the Commonwealth does not and cannot impose on itself. My Leader, Senator Chaney, put this aptly in his own speech. Certainly, the Senate is specifically constructed to represent each State equally, regardless of population. Since 1901, Tasmania has had inflated numbers in the House of Representatives.

The proposal may well increase the involvement of the High Court of Australia. In this highly controversial area, this would do nothing to enhance the smooth working of our political system. It should not be assumed that this referendum proposal would simply add another section to the Constitution. On the contrary-and this is a surprise for many-the proposed amendments are complex. They require 2,000 words. They add 2,000 new words to the Constitution. The amendments would abolish two sections, replace three sections and insert 10 completely new sections, including a whole new chapter, into the Constitution.

I assent that there is a high danger of unintended consequences arising from such a wholesale set of changes, from such a large number of new words. I note that since 1901, there have been only eight successful amendments to the Constitution. I put it to the Senate that this question alone, question No. 2, changes more words than all of those eight amendments put together. However, I concede to this debate that the abolition of one section, section 25, is highly appropriate. I support the abolition of section 25. If that was the only matter in this question, I would be supporting it, but it is only one small item in a huge number of changes. Section 25 contains the offensive reference to exclusion of people of a race, of one race or several races, from voting in an Australian election. It is entirely out of date and should have no place in the Australian Constitution.

The South Australian Constitution Act already entrenches a prohibition against malapportionment, although it does not prohibit a gerrymander for the reason that it is not possible to express in law such a prohibition-or, at least, it is very difficult. The second referendum proposal is, I believe, a fraud and should be rejected by the people of Australia.

The third question concerns local government. This proposal is a crude attempt to trick those who have a deep concern, as we in the Opposition do, for the well-being of local government in this country. The Labor Government is only putting it up as a smokescreen to cover the defects in the other proposals. The words `recognition of local government' are dangerous tokenism. The proposal offers no guarantees against wrongful dismissal of councils, no guarantees against enforced amalgamations and no guarantees against the abolition of local government in parts of States. This referendum proposal offers one meaningless sentence to be added to the Constitution, to be titled section 119a, as follows:

Each State shall provide for the establishment and continuance of a system of local government, with local government bodies elected in accordance with the laws of the State and empowered to administer, and to make by-laws for, their respective areas in accordance with the laws of the States.

Even if these words had been included from 1901, neither the practice nor the powers of local government would have been any different in all parts of Australia throughout the whole of this century. The inclusion of those words is not going to make the powers or practice of local government any different in the future of this country. The question is really an attempt to divert attention away from the failures of Labor's policy for local government, instanced by the Hawke Government's cutbacks in road funding, amounting over the past three years to a reduction of 25 per cent, of $300m, and the Hawke Government's cutbacks in local government's share of personal income tax collections. I seek leave of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard a brief table setting out those shares for the years 1976 to 1988.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Another instance of failure in Labor's policy is the Hawke Government's abolition of the only national forum available to local government-that is, the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations, which was abolished in 1986. Another instance where the Commonwealth had direct authority in the local government area was in the territory of Christmas Island. The Hawke Government intervened in September last year and sacked the local government authority.

SPEECH.PARA: Constitutional recognition of local government is rightly placed in the Constitutions of the States. This has already happened in four of the six States. In South Australia this was done by a State Liberal government in 1980, and it is still very much in place today. I will encourage the Australian people to reject this third referendum question, as it is a smokescreen and is worthless.

The fourth question concerns trial by jury, freedom of religion and just compensation. This package purports to extend rights, but it is a three-in-one, or all or nothing, package. We cannot have one and leave the other two; we have to accept all or reject all. I reject all-each one for sound reasons. The proposal is a re-run of Labor's Bill of Rights which was rejected and not proceeded with because of the opposition expressed in this chamber. Instead of giving rights it actually limits and restricts those rights. By reducing our existing and unthreatened freedoms to a few short legal definitions, it makes those freedoms subject to the uncertainties and shifting legal philosophies of the courts. Thus, to go in this direction actually puts our existing freedoms in jeopardy.

All three subquestions are completely unnecessary. Can anyone suggest that these freedoms are currently under serious threat in Australia? The first sub-question, on trial by jury, has serious drafting problems. There is no sound reason why the Federal Constitution should intrude in this new way in the running of the criminal justice systems of the States. The proposal also seriously redefines the term `jury'. It allows for any number of people to make up a jury and, contrary to all practice, it allows for majority verdicts rather than unanimous verdicts.

The second sub-question is entitled `freedom of religion' but its main effect is the opposite. It provides that government at all levels `shall not establish any religion'. The proposed wording could lead to the High Court of Australia ruling to confine or prohibit prayer or religious observance within government institutions such as schools. Thus, existing practice regarding freedom of religion could be limited or removed.

Reference has already been made to the United States and I add reference to India. In October last year India was in some constitutional turmoil about suttee, the burning of widows. Some Hindus were claiming that they had a right to follow that practice because of the guarantees of freedom of religion in India. The Government was saying that suttee was not to be allowed. This ill-founded proposal opens up the possibility of validating extreme practices of minorities. I am not saying that we are going to have a rash of suttee around Australia, but it gives the possibility of validating extreme practices of minorities conducted under the guise of religion.

The third sub-question of just terms for the acquisition of property could also have unintended consequences because of inadequacies in drafting. It is yet another unjustified intrusion into the operation of States and an interference with State responsibilities.

Justice, religion and property are complex matters which should not be subject to simplistic formulas, let alone putting the formulas in the inflexible terms of an entrenched Constitution. There are enormous dangers in the three sub-questions. The objectives of the proposals are so very important that to get them only half right is to get them wrong. The Constitution is not the appropriate place for these inadequate words. I will encourage the people of Australia to vote against these proposals.

In the 30 minutes that have been available to me, of which two minutes are left, I have only been able to give a summary of what I believe are sound reasons for rejecting all of these referendum proposals. In due course, after we have voted on these matters, I look forward to participating in the writing of the No case and to having that No case go to every voter in Australia. That will have the capacity of setting out in more detail the convincing reasons why I believe the people of Australia should reject all of the referendum proposals.

I conclude by noting again that there is a lack of unanimity in Australia for the referendum proposals. Only the Labor Government has indicated its assent. The Liberal and National parties are opposed to it; the Queensland Government will be opposed; the Tasmanian Government is opposed; the New South Wales Government is opposed; and many community groups are also opposed. There was no consultation with us prior to these matters being defined. Because there was no consultation and because there is so much dissent and opposition to them, there will not be any great surprise when they are rejected. If the Government withdraws these referenda proposals between now and September on the ground that it expects that rejection, then be it on its own head that it did not consult the Opposition or other parties in putting forward-quite unilaterally, and against the advice of the Constitutional Commission-these highly contentious matters that should be rejected by all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In September the people of Australia will be asked four questions contained in the short titles of the Constitution Alteration Bills that are before us. The questions in effect, are: Do you agree that the Constitution be altered to provide for four-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of Parliament; do you agree that the Constitution be changed to provide for fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia; do you agree that the Constitution extend the right to trial by jury, to extend freedom of religion and to ensure fair terms for persons whose property is acquired by any government; and, do you agree that the Constitution be altered to recognise local government. Those are the four questions that people are to be asked. But the real question to be answered is: What is the purpose of these being put before the people in the first place? Is there any real reason why the people, at great expense to the taxpayer, will cast votes on these issues? Where is the evidence of the need for these suggested changes to the Constitution and what is the hidden agenda behind these provisions?

SPEECH.PARA: In the short time that is available to me I want to concentrate on the issue of the so-called extension of the right of freedom of religion. I agree with what Senator Teague has said. This is a very dangerous proposition and it is likely to have completely the reverse effect to that which appears on the face of it. I have a very grave reason for saying that. I believe that as time goes by it will be understood by the people. The people who adhere to various religions will become aware of the threat to them posed by this proposition.

Let me deal very briefly with the other proposals, because I want to concentrate on that matter. I agree that most of the questions on all of the other issues have been raised and answered thus far in the second reading debate. The proposal relating to four-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament was put more correctly by Senator Teague. This proposition really is to alter the Constitution to delete the fixed terms for senators provision which is currently in the Constitution and to provide for simultaneous double dissolution elections-not necessarily every four years but at the maximum every four years. Where is the evidence produced by the Government to suggest that the current provisions relating to the House of Representatives term of a maximum of three years is inadequate? I think Senator Boswell was the last person to draw attention to the fact that the majority of House of Representatives terms have not gone the three years. We should at least have three-year terms instead of placing into the Constitution a provision that is not needed.

There would have been some cause or reason for us to be concerned if it had been seen that the three-year period was inadequate for a government to undertake the legislative program for which it had sought a mandate from the people but the Government has not produced such evidence. Rather, the evidence is to the contrary. Typically, governments have not gone their three years. So why is the Government seeking a maximum of four years? The problems associated with this proposal for simultaneous elections are compounded by the destruction of the basic principle of the rotation of senators. Let me remind honourable senators that the provisions in the Constitution for the rotation of senators were based on the provisions of the United States Constitution.

I draw attention to a comment made by Professor Geoffrey Sawer in evidence to the Select Committee on the Constitution Alteration (Avoidance of Double Dissolution Deadlocks) Bill 1950. Professor Sawer said:
There is no point in having a House of review unless you have some degree of difference between the points of view of the Houses, and you get that more with the staggered system of elections.

It is almost a guarantee that under our structure at present there will be differences of opinion between the House of Representatives and the House of review, namely the Senate. But with a double dissolution election available to the Government at its pleasure there are no constitutional or practical constraints on a Prime Minister-whether it be the current Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the previous Prime Minister or any future Prime Minister-who wants an election at any time that it suits him. This is an attack on the rights of this Senate to review legislation without fear or favour and to do so in the interests of the people who have elected it.

I have already spoken on the question of so-called fair and democratic elections. I do not want to belabour the point that has been made here previously that this issue is largely to do with malapportionment. But that is only one aspect for consideration in respect of fair elections. What about gerrymanders? In any event, what does the Government mean by one vote one value? A lot depends on the basis for the electoral division. Should it be on the basis of people in that division or voters in that division? At present, the basis for electoral divisions is the number of voters. Why should it not be people? Should members of the House of Representatives represent only the voters or should they represent all of the people in their electorate, including the children? How many schools are there? What is the expenditure on roads? What sort of child care facilities and the like are available? Are these not matters for consideration when the issue of fair voting and one vote one value comes up? If the electorates are to be based on voters instead of population districts, it changes the whole aspect of whether or not the vote is valuable. I will not go to the other extreme and suggest that the person who casts the vote should get a weight for every dependant that that person has. If that were the case, I suspect that there would be better family policy by various governments. But I do not want to argue that point here. That matter has gone through and been discussed in the Joint Committee on Electoral Matters, of which I am a member, and in this chamber.

I come to the third question: an Act to alter the Constitution to extend the right to trial by jury, to extend freedom of religion and to ensure fair terms for persons whose property is acquired by any government. The question to be asked of the Government is: Why are these lumped together like this? What is the community of interest, as it were, between those rights? The issues about trial by jury have been raised. Of course, they will be raised again in the committee stage. I do not know whether the issues concerning property have been raised but what would the proposition entrench into the Constitution? It would entrench the right of governments to acquire property but under what terms and conditions? The proposal for ensuring fair treatment for persons whose property is acquired by any government does not address the issue of whether the property should have been acquired in the first place.

Let us go to the question that I raised first; that is, the issue of freedom of religion. I will leave aside the question of recognising local government for the committee stage. This constitutional question attempts to extend the existing provisions under section 116 of the Constitution to the States. In effect, it would heighten the the potential problems of section 116. It would enlarge the minefield wherein unanticipated casualties could occur and exacerbate the potential for greater divisions in the community on the basis of the isolation of religion. It has the potential to erect an impenetrable wall to isolate and effectively discriminate against persons with religious beliefs. Its main object is the extension of the ill-conceived provisions of section 116 to apply directly to State legislation. Let me prove precisely what I have said. I refer to a very interesting paper which was written by Clifford L. Pannam, a legal researcher. It is entitled `Travelling Section 116 with a US Road Map', Melbourne University Law Review, Vol. 4, June 1963, pages 41 to 90. Pannam wrote:
(s. 116) is regarded by many as a curious historical oddity and by all as having little practical value.

This is what was written 25 years ago. Pannam explained that the whole provision was taken as being necessary to prevent the `insidious threat' that the Commonwealth might have power to pass Sunday observance legislation. Section 116 of the Constitution states:

The Commonwealth shall not make any law for establishing any religion, or for imposing any religious observance, or for prohibiting the free exercise of any religion, and no religious test shall be required as a qualification for any office or public trust under the Commonwealth.
Has the Government examined the discussions that took place on this subject during the constitutional conventions late last century? Pannam continued:

By a vote of 25 to 16 this clause became section 116 of the Australian Constitution. It was an historical accident based on an incredible legal analysis by a man (Higgins) who was later to become a justice of the High Court of Australia.

We really have to ask the question: Will this provision ultimately be interpreted in the same way as a similar provision was in the United States Constitution? We do not have to look too far to find the answer to this question. In the Defence of Government Schools case in 1980 section 116 was used by the opponents of state aid to non-government schools in an attempt to cut out the rights of parents to send their children to schools of their own choosing and to have some of their tax money allocated for that purpose. In other words, this was to cut off funds for non-government schools.

Is section 116 a `curious historical oddity'? Well, this historical accident has great potential to cause previously unimagined mischief. It happened that the majority at the time ruled that certain laws relating to financial assistance for non-government schools were constitutional. But there was a significant dissenter, and that was Mr Justice Lionel Murphy. Had the previous Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans had his way, he would have had a Bench full of Lionel Murphys. What did Justice Murphy say? In his written dissent he used the expression `freedom from religion'. His view was clearly expressed in that dissent. It was clear that a court composed of a majority who followed his philosophy would interpret the section, to use his words, `with all the generality which the words admit'.

As I said, Lionel Murphy used the expression `freedom from religion'. However, the question which will be based on the cleverly worded title of the Bill we are debating refers to a Bill `to extend freedom of religion'. Yet, here is a High Court judge who interpreted the section to mean freedom from religion. Further, he interpreted it really to mean the establishment of an impenetrable wall so as to isolate and effectively discriminate against persons with religious beliefs. That would have been the result of the Murphy decision. The new section 116, as proposed, will be capable of being used to attack those who seek to express their rights in the exercise of their faith and to isolate them from the general political milieu.

A case has not been made by the Government for the extension of this provision to the States. Neither has consideration been given by the Government to removing section 116 or subjecting it to the greatest possible scrutiny. Only casual perusal was given to it by the Constitutional Commission. Detailed scrutiny of the provision should include the bizarre interpretations which are creeping into judicial determinations in other democracies.

Again, I come back to the question: will this provision ultimately operate and be interpreted in the same way as has been done in the United States? Another interesting case has just come to my notice and I will raise it right now. I refer to an article headed `The separation of Church and child!' contained in the Catholic Weekly of 18 May 1988. This article is a review by Stephanie Overman of a book entitled Separation of Church and Child: The Constitution and Federal Aid to Religious Schools by Bruce Cooper and Thomas Vitullo-Martin of the Hudson Institute. The article states:

In the United States over the past few years mobile vans have cropped up outside parochial schools. The reason-the Supreme Court ruled in the 1985 Aguilar vs Felton decision that public school teachers could not teach remedial classes in religiously affiliated schools!

On what basis were these Christians who had some need for remedial classes segregated from school rooms and put into caravans? On the basis of the freedom of religion provisions in the United States Constitution, that is what. Can the Government guarantee that there will be no further attempts by the High Court of Australia to try to interpret the words, as was attempted by Mr Justice Murphy and, in fact, as has been done by the Supreme Court of the United States of America? One of the big problems of placing in the Constitution provisions in wide general terms is that it leaves the way open for the issues to be determined by non-elected judges rather than by the elected representatives of the people.

Let me deal with a couple of other decisions by the supreme courts in other democracies in respect of rights-the right to freedom of religion, and we have dealt with that; the right to privacy; and the right to freedom of speech. What are the bizarre interpretations that have been made by non-elected judges; in other words, what judge-made laws have been imposed on the community? Abortion is very often the pivot on which these strange interpretations are developed. I will give the Senate a couple of examples. The abortion on demand situation in the United States has been approved by the United States Supreme Court-it is a judge-made law-not on the basis of the existence of any specific reference to abortion in the United States Constitution, but on the right to privacy which is found in the text of the Constitution. In a similar move a United States Federal Court judge in March this year ruled unconstitutional regulations prohibiting abortion activities by federally funded family planning clinics. They were knocked out by a ruling based on freedom of speech. In a similar fashion, the Canadian Supreme Court in a decision earlier this year struck down Canada's abortion law and thereby permitted an abortion on demand situation by utilising Canada's Charter of Rights and Freedoms. The Canadian Court on that occasion found that the Canadian law infringed on a woman's right to life, liberty and security of person because of State interference with bodily integrity and serious State imposed psychological stress.

It is this possibility of a converse interpretation in regard to freedom of religion which is of concern to many people. As was pointed out in Volume 2 of the first report of the Constitutional Commission:
Section 116 is concerned with both the toleration of all religions and the toleration of absence of religion.

But how does this apply in the non-government school area? This question becomes even more relevant when honourable senators realise that the main objective of the proposal is the extension of the concept to the States. Of course, the States have the main responsibility in the areas of education and health. These are indeed very serious questions. This concept fits in with the Evans-type concept of a Bill of Rights which would have entailed provisions in broad, loosely defined terms which could be interpreted by non-elected judges.

I will conclude by referring to what a former Chief Justice of Tasmania said about this type of activity, this type of generalised provision. On 24 June 1978 at the Thomas More Quincentenary, a former Chief Justice of Tasmania, Sir Stanley Burbury, a very learned man, said:
I do not wish to be misunderstood when I say that I do not think it possible to establish a Court which we could trust with such a solemn judicial task.
He was referring to the interpretation of a Bill of Rights. He continued:

The interpretation and application by any Court of fundamental laws necessarily expressed in wide general terms leaves an immense area for the exercise of judicial discretion and for sharp differences of opinion between judges . . . Nor can many decisions in this area be based on bare legal reasoning. The personal attributes of the judge will often be stronger factors in moulding his opinion-his social, religious, political, philosophical and cultural backgrounds and beliefs. Complete objectivity is impossible. Judges who are entrusted with the solemn task of judicial review of Acts of Parliament to determine whether they should be declared void as infringing fundamental laws inevitably become legislators; legislators who are beyond the control of democratic will . . .
The Chief Justice went on to say:

I would prefer the democratic control of legislation through the political sanction of the ballot box and a strong second Chamber of Parliament to handing over a substantial measure of control of legislation to a judicial tribunal of a few men-eminent in their profession and men of integrity and wisdom though they may be. Judges are but men and are as subject to subtle corruption by the exercise of great power as other men.
What the Government is attempting to do here is to extend a provision which has the potential for great division in this community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Harradine on his eloquence in putting his case forward and in warning the Australian people about the inherent dangers of this proposed referendum that the Australian Labor Party is trying to foist on the Australian people. I am the first to admit that our Constitution is most probably not the most perfect Constitution. I was enthusiastic at the prospect of some appropriate changes being put to the electorate. However this package that the Federal Government is to put to the Australian people at a referendum is inappropriate and misleading; in fact, some of the questions are so misleading that I would imagine that if somebody was advertising in the community in the way that this Government will advertise during the referendum campaign, he would be in a lot of trouble with some of the courts.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to address some remarks to all four questions, but the first question I wish to comment on is proposed question No. 3. That question is: Do you approve of an Act to alter the Constitution to recognise local government? That looks to be a fairly naive sort of question. Of course, it begs an answer of yes. Local government ought to be recognised. The question is so innocently expressed-although I do not have any doubt that there is little innocence in the intent of the question-that one could be excused for wondering why anyone would want to oppose it. Inherent in that question is the assumption that approving this question will give something concrete to local government that it currently does not have. That definitely will not be the case. There is no denying that local government has, for a long time, been seeking constitutional recognition. About that aim the National Party of Australia has absolutely no qualms. In fact, we wholeheartedly endorse their desires. The difference that I and my fellow National and Liberal party colleagues have with the Federal Government is that we believe that local government should have meaningful constitutional recognition, and that means recognition within State government constitutions.

What local government has been seeking through constitutional recognition is a guaranteed proportion of revenue and a guarantee of non-dismissal by State governments. Of course, the Labor Party is well known in this area, most recently for the dismissal of the Sydney City Council by the State Government. However, neither of these two desires of local government is guaranteed through this Government's constitutional proposals. In fact, the Attorney-General, Lionel Bowen, in his second reading speech in the other place said quite clearly that the changes would not provide for either guaranteed revenue or protection against dismissal by State governments. If the proposals do not satisfy the basic requests of the groups most affected, what do they do and why are they in the referendum? There is every indication that it is yet another attempt by this government to centralise power in Canberra. This suggestion in the referendum does not give local government autonomy. It has been suggested that it could be the thin end of the wedge, to allow for a system of regionalisation of local councils.

Local government authorities are suspicious of the proposal, and with good reason. This Labor Party Government's record with local government is not a good one. I know that Senator Messner would agree with me on a few of the points I would make about what this Federal Government has done to local government. Commonwealth road funding has been frozen since 1983-84, which means a loss in real terms of about 25 per cent. General purpose assistance grants to local government have been maintained only in real terms; in other words, there has been no improvement.

Having exposed the motives behind one of the referendum proposals, one must look with increasing suspicion at the other three. Again we see more examples of Labor's attempts to centralise power in Canberra and destroy the power and independence of the States. Of course, of even more concern to this chamber are the Government's continuing attempts to destroy the Senate. I believe that the Labor Party has never really forgiven the Senate for its role in the events of 1975. It also remembers that it was this House that stopped the identity card and it was this chamber that stopped the Bill of Rights legislation. Do not let anyone in the Australian community forget that.

The first question to be put to the people in the referendums is: Do you approve of an Act to alter the Constitution to provide for four-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament? Again, as with the question on local government, it appears simple enough. People are pretty fed up with elections and they probably believe that this change just might reduce the number of elections we have in this country. Of course, four-year terms might have an appeal, given that we have not had anything like a three-year term of parliament for some time now. This Government campaigned strongly, in its opposition days, for letting parliaments run their full term. What was always in parentheses was `provided it does not affect our ability to win'. That is what Senator Ray's function is-to make sure that the Labor Party always wins, regardless of what the Constitution says or the people really desire, by having a bit of a fiddle with, among other things, the Commonwealth Electoral Act. That is why we have had elections one after another, and double dissolutions-for no reason other than to try to fix the numbers in this place.

This Government will keep on sending this chamber out until such time as it can fix the numbers and get a majority. That is precisely what it will be able to do if this referendum question is passed. The Constitutional Commission did not recommend this. It recommended that the terms of senators be twice as long as those of members of the House of Representatives, and that the House of Representatives be extended to four-year terms with a minimum sitting requirement of three years before an election can be called. The Government has thrown out that proposal and, instead, is suggesting that the Senate term be reduced to four years and that the Senate and the House of Representatives go to the polls at the same time. This, effectively, would castrate the Senate. At any future time a government that was having difficulty getting its legislation through the Senate would be able to call an election. So, there is every chance that elections will be called as frequently as now and each time it will be a double dissolution. If that is not usurping the rights of the Senate, I do not know what is.

The second question is: Do you approve of an Act to alter the Constitution to provide for fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia? Again the question is so framed as to induce an automatic `yes'. Here again it is false wording and it is not really telling the people what they will be voting on. Of course we want democratic elections and of course we want them to be fair. The alternative implies some sort of Third World dictatorship regime. Who could support that? That is what the average disinterested Australian will think. Those who think they know a bit about politics will say, `This is something to do with the gerrymanders; this is aimed at Queensland'.

It is interesting that every time the world `gerrymander' is used it is used in relation to Queensland. It is true that the Labor Party does need to win about 51.4 per cent of the vote to win government in Queensland. What is less well known is that in New South Wales the Liberal and National parties needed over 52 per cent of the vote to win government. Who was responsible for the electoral laws there? Who set that up in New South Wales? It was set up by the Wran Labor Government. Federally, we need to capture over 52.3 per cent of the vote Australia-wide to win an election. Who set that up?

So, if we talk of gerrymanders, we must talk of all the gerrymanders that exist in this country. There are imbalances in the system and it is likely, even inevitable, given the size of this country, that there always will be; but they will not be altered by voting `yes'. The Labor Government claims that it is intended to apply a numerical equality to the numbers of electors in the electoral divisions for the House of Representatives and either House of Parliament in the States and Territories.
