But that equality will not apply to the House of Representatives. For example, Tasmania has a small population, but under this proposal it will still have five House of Representatives seats. This proposal will affect the States in which there is an upper House. It is designed to get them also. So, let the New South Wales upper House beware. Providing for the one vote one value principle does not apply to this chamber either. Tasmania, Western Australia and Queensland will all have the same numbers of senators as the more populous States of New South Wales and Victoria. So, that representation also will not change. So, what is the point of the exercise?

The last question we are to be asked is: Do you approve of an Act to alter the Constitution to extend the right to trial by jury, to extend freedom of religion, and to ensure fair terms for persons whose property is acquired by government? Having been involved with the Land Acquisition Reform Committee in New South Wales, which has fought this Federal Government on the unfair seizure of land for Army bases and other issues and which has been campaigning for a long time to amend the present Lands Acquisition Act, I have some sympathy with the issue of opposing unfair seizure of land by governments, both State and Federal.

But, of course, there is more to this simple question, which again is misrepresenting what is behind the very simple words of the question that will be on the referendum paper. It could be described as a watered down Bill of Rights, and that has already been alluded to very clearly by Senator Harradine. It is real mother's milk stuff. When it talks about freedom of religion, trial by jury and all those other phrases associated with modern democracy, one almost feels inclined to put one's hand across the heart and repeat the question. I am not entirely sure what intention the question has hidden behind it. I would have thought that religious freedom was pretty well established in this country. After all, we have religious schools of almost every conceivable denomination. We have churches, mosques, synagogues and temples in abundant numbers around the country. I am not denying that there is prejudice and criticism of various religions around Australia, but one cannot legislate against personal prejudices.

The basic thrust of the question is already incorporated in the Constitution, so why change it? If it is changed, what are the chances of misrepresentation and interpretation? As I have said, I have sympathy for anyone trying to improve current legislation concerning compensation and the rights of government to seize land. But this proposal would not guarantee any justice; it guarantees nothing. I would hope that groups such as LARC-the Land Acquisition Reform Committee-continue to press for alterations to present legislation and are not fobbed off by this Clayton's Bill of Rights inherent in this question.

Having come to the last of the four questions, one could ask: What is the point of it all? Why are we spending $40m on staging a referendum on these questions having just spent an estimated $6m on the Constitutional Commission, the advice from which the Government chose to ignore when it did not suit it politically.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you say $40m?

—I said $40m, Senator Messner, which is the estimated cost of this referendum. Maybe the Australian people will think of this as a mid-term election charade campaign run by the Labor Government trying to bolster its position so that it might look better to the Australian people when the next election comes around. I think it is a trial run for an election that the Government will most probably want to have early next year anyway.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, it is a shame. The people of Australia are not fools; the people of Australia are thinking people and they will vote `No' to all four questions and then we can get on with the business of government in this country. As a bicentennial diversion, the referendum is a flop. Fireworks might have been more entertaining and useful, and they certainly would have been far more honest.

To finish, as this may be the last speech I will give in this Parliament House, I will quote a poem which is synonymous with saying goodbye to this place as well as to a Constitution-if it is fiddled with by the Government-that has served us well over many years. This verse was written by one of my constituents, the member for Gwydir, the Hon. Ralph Hunt. I happen to be one of his constituents. The poem is entitled `Farewell Old Provisional':
Farewell to you old Provisional
As we your spirits depart
Spirits that are but transitional
As some move on and others start.
You've endured long hours of debate
Some boring, some flamed with passion
Fire, brimstone, gnawed with hate
Others spoken in reasonable fashion
You've listened to the eccentrics
From the radical left and the right
Confident they alone know the tricks
That will solve the human plight.
Farewell to you old Provisional
As we your spirits depart
Leaving our house so traditional
Another era is about to start.
We leave you as an empty shell,
A host of memories to protect.
No longer will you ring your bell
Calling politicians to reflect
Then vote to resolve the issues.
You've listened to a million speeches
Some as thin as paper tissues
Others notable for their screeches.
Farewell to you old Provisional
As we your spirits depart
Your future is only conditional
Upon you playing your part
Storing memories, the forgotten dreams
Of those who practiced their art
Flooding the Hansards by the ream
Bearing testimonies of the wordy past.
Now Burley Griffin's ambitious dream
Stands as his monument at long last.
The memories of war and depressions
Supply Bills and legislation blocked
Fulfilled hopes and failed ambitions
History in your Chambers locked
Farewell you old Provisional
To another place our spirits depart.

In quoting that verse, I hope that in saying farewell to the provisional Parliament House the Australian people do not say farewell to a Constitution that has served them well over many years. The Constitution has ensured a future and it does not need tampering with now for matters of political expediency for a mid-term election campaign.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity of speaking in support of the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill and the Constitution Alteration (Rights and Freedoms) Bill. However, as the Minister for Local Government, I would like to take this opportunity of speaking about the importance of constitutional recognition to local government throughout Australia. It is most unfortunate that the Opposition has chosen to make this issue something of a political football. I have great sympathy with the Leader of the Opposition, Mr John Howard, who apparently originally sought to support the recognition of local government in the Constitution. Unfortunately for John Howard, he was not able to pursue that worthy goal of backing up statements he has made to local government that he was in support of constitutional recognition. Instead, he has been overruled by his Party room, and it places honourable members and senators of the Opposition in an invidious position.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said before in this place, I am well aware of honourable senators who have spoken to me of their support for constitutional recognition of local government. We are all aware that Mr Ian Wilson, the honourable member for Sturt, has gone on public record as being in support of it. The member for Kennedy, the Hon. Bob Katter, Snr, has spoken out in support of it. Even today in this chamber, Senator Brownhill said that local government ought to be recognised. Having said that, he then went on to say that he could not accept the terms under which the Government had put constitutional recognition.

It is very unfortunate that this has become a partisan issue. Clearly, the recognition of local government should be fundamentally agreed to by all parties and, indeed, by all Australians. There is absolutely nothing controversial in this proposal. It absolutely amazes me to listen to some of the trumped up arguments that poor members of the Opposition have had to dream up to support their embarrassing situation.

I would like to go into those in a few moments, but, firstly, for the record, I will quote what the Constitutional Commission has said and what it has recommended. It recommended a new section 119a to be added to the Constitution in the following terms:

Each State shall provide for the establishment and continuance of local government bodies elected in accordance with its laws and empowered to administer and to make by-laws for their respective areas in accordance with the laws of the State.
That does not sound very controversial.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does it mean?

—Let us see what this means in terms of local government. I should be surprised if Senator Michael Baume knows much about local government. In Australia local government consists of 836 individual bodies with about 8,000 elected members and approximately 170,000 employees. I wonder when Senator Michael Baume last had discussions with his local council about this issue? If he were really listening both to his local council and to the Australian Local Government Association, which represents all local government authorities throughout Australia, he would know how very disappointed local government is in members of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall quote not from a party political statement but from a Press release of 11 May 1988 by the Australian Local Government Association:
Local government leaders around Australia have expressed amazement and disappointment at the Federal Opposition's decision to oppose the local government recognition-
in the Constitution. It continues:

`Although there was strong support within the Coalition parties for the local government question, it appears that a deliberate strategy has been adopted to oppose the package of four questions regardless of their individual merits,' said Cr Peter Kyle, President of the Australian Local Government Association. `This attitude is an insult to the intelligence of the Australian voting public.'
Issued in June 1987, the Federal Liberal Party's policy made a commitment that the next Liberal Government would:
. . . examine, in conjunction with the States and local governments, appropriate constitutional recognition and protection of local government in Australia.
The Press release of the Association continues:

The National Party's policy at the same time unequivocally supported the constitutional recognition of local government. Cr Kyle challenged the National Party leader to reconcile the party's decision last night with his party's policy.
Later the same Association said that the coalition party should be considering the following issue:

There is overwhelming local government support for constitutional recognition of local government in the form proposed in the Bill. Local government rejects the charge that it is meaningless and mere tokenism.

TALK.START.PARA: —Give us the meaning. What is the meaning?

—The meaning is very clear: local government, which is older than the Federal Parliament and which is older than Federation in many parts of Australia, is entitled to be recognised and to be mentioned in the Constitution.
—So? What does that mean as far as you are concerned?
—It means recognition of the status of local government.
—What does that mean? What does it lead to? What is the next question?

—It means that Federal, State and local governments should be working together for the benefit of all Australians. What is unfortunate about the Opposition is that it has simply adopted a partisan approach because it cannot agree to anything proposed by the Labor Party. The Opposition will find that the initial news poll, which showed that up to 69 per cent of Australians support constitutional recognition of local government, will ensure that this question is approved because the people of Australia know it is a commonsense question and it requires a commonsense answer. Everyone seems to recognise that except, unfortunately, members of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it unfortunate that so many members of the Opposition secretly would like to agree with me but because of party bullying they are placed in this very invidious position. I shall not take up any more time of the chamber on this question. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not intended to start my contribution to tonight's debate by dealing with local government but having listened to the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) I can only say that all my concerns about this referendum proposal have been massively underlined. The Minister was consistently asked by way of interjections, which she heard because she responded to them, `What does recognition mean?'. The Minister had no reply. She said that it means recognition in the Constitution. The essence of the whole debate is this: is it an empty, phoney, nonsensical gesture or has it some substance? In her ludicrous 10-minute contribution, the Minister could provide us with no evidence of substance.
—It is a gesture, but one of affection rather than contempt.

—I do not know which gesture the Minister was referring to but I can think of a couple relating specifically to this legislation that one should not perform in this chamber. The Minister's 10 minute intervention lacked any substance. She was struggling to fill her 10 minutes, and that was her total contribution to this debate on whether local government should receive recognition in the Constitution. The whole issue depends on one simple matter: what does recognition in the Constitution mean both for local government and for the people of Australia? If and when the Minister for Local Government can get around to letting the people know the secret which is still locked in her heart-it did not come out here today-maybe we can have an effective debate.

SPEECH.PARA: From what the Minister has said so far, we have no explanation, no justification for spending $30m on this referendum. No understanding about what this really does has been generated in the community. The Minister has failed dismally to generate any knowledge or understanding apart from waving the Constitution around, giving us a list of how many local government bodies there are and informing us about inconsequential detail but with no substance as to what this means to local government.

TALK.START.PARA: —She is the Minister for Local Government.

—As Senator Messner said, she is the Minister for Local Government. In a sense the Minister gave the game away when, in reading out part of the referendum proposal, she said, `according to the laws of the States'. Recognising local government in the Constitution does no more than simply recognise it within the framework of the laws of the States as they affect local government. Therefore, what additional elements emerge from that recognition? Does it change the status, power or anything else of local government?
—Of course it does not change the status.

—I am only too happy for the Minister to interject to tell me how this changes the status of local government because we did not hear it in her speech. If the Minister can explain it by way of interjection, I would be overjoyed. The people of Australia are waiting to hear it; they waited for 10 minutes and did not hear a damn thing!
—It would be highly disorderly.

—I would be overjoyed to move the suspension of so much of Standing Orders as would permit the Minister to tell the chamber how the question changes the role of local government. We have not heard. This seems to the the central element to the whole discussion: how does this change local government? As the Minister said, the proposal would only recognise local government within the framework of the laws of the States.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, if the laws of the State said that a State government can dismiss local government and that once being dismissed that local government can be replaced with an administrator and that administrator need not necessarily be replaced within a reasonable time-it could last for years depending on what the law of the State said because that is what the Minister admitted-it is bunkum for the Minister or anyone else to say that. I might say that the Minister did not even make this point-she did not make any points-but some people in local government have been saying that this recognition would mean that local governments would be protected against naughty State governments which sack them.

TALK.START.PARA: —How are they going to do that?

—Exactly. They cannot because, as the Minister said in the only essential bit of information she provided, which was by reading out the referendum proposal, it is within the terms of the laws of the State.
—Why did John Howard think it was such a good idea when he rose as the member for Bennelong?

—Honourable senators will notice that the other Minister's only defence of the proposition is not to say that there is substance in it. His intervention is a typical, cheap debating trick. Why did someone else at one stage say that it would be a good idea?
—Not someone, your Leader.

—Why did our Leader say that it was a good idea? I am asking the Minister for substance and, as is inevitable, whenever I ask the Minister for substance, all I get is the typical debating point. The reality is that, in the proposal of the Minister for Local Government, it is possible to have recognition of local government which provides some substance. For example, if recognition of local government in the Constitution involved a stated obligation to fund local government, that would be a meaningful contribution. There are many alternatives where by the Government could introduce recognition of local government in a meaningful way. The way this Government is doing it is total bunkum and is self-evidently so as we have seen from the Minister for Local Government. We know for a fact that local government is already recognised in the constitutions of various States around Australia-New South Wales, Victoria, Western Australia and South Australia. It is only in Queensland and Tasmania that there is no constitutional recognition of local government. Are this Government and the Minister saying-I have not heard them saying it but I am asking them-that even though there is constitutional recognition in those States it is only a sort of second class recognition and that to get grade A recognition the States would have to have Federal approval. Is the Government saying that it has to be in the Federal Constitution because a State constitution is not quite as zappy or impressive and does not carry as much weight?
—That is very true.
—The Minister said that that is very true. Did I hear him correctly?
—That is a fair comment.

—This kind of sanctimonious nonsense that recognition constitutionally is only meaningful if it comes from the Federal Constitution I think probably reveals a set of attitudes within this Government which is clear and uncomplicated and relates to the destruction of State powers and the concentration of powers in central hands in Canberra. There is no justification otherwise unless, and maybe this is the explanation, the Government is saying, `You have to have Commonwealth recognition of local government because that is the only way you will get Tasmania and Queensland councils covered as their State governments have not done anything about having referendums to change their constitutions to get local government recognised in Queensland and Tasmania'.

SPEECH.PARA: If that is so, we have a simple response to it. In other words, this Government believes that voters in New South Wales, Victoria, Western Australia, and South Australia have a right to dictate to the residents of Queensland and Tasmania how their local governments should be run. Quite frankly, it strikes me as absolutely appalling that we have this kind of authoritarian approach, `Let the people of New South Wales vote to dictate to the people of Queensland how their local government should be run'. I find that grossly undemocratic. If this is the reason the Government wants this constitutional amendment, I do not see why it should be a matter of concern. If that is the reason I cannot see the justification for asking the people of New South Wales to adjudicate on how local government in Tasmania or Queensland should be run. If the people of those two States only want constitutional recognition let them vote to have constitutional recognition within their State bodies.

I cannot otherwise see a purpose-we certainly did not hear one from the Minister-for this proposed change. After all, it is quite clear that, within this proposal to change the Constitution, there is nothing that would prevent the wrongful dismissal of local councils, there is no proposal to prevent the abolition of local government in some part of a State and there is no proposal to prevent forced amalgamations of local government areas because, as the Minister said, it is all subject to State laws and State laws could and do provide for such situations. That is why it is extraordinary that the Government has been able, at this stage-I hope it will be put right sooner or later-to con some organisations, such as the Shires Association of New South Wales and the organisation that the Minister spoke about into believing that this is just a method of recognising local government and that this system, proposed by the Government, is meaningful and useful.

Listen to this. I have received a letter from the Shires Association of New South Wales stating that we really ought to support this referendum because it would provide security of tenure. The Shires Association either does not really know what the words in the referendum are all about or the significance of them, or it has been conned by this Government and, presumably, by this Minister. I asked the Shires Association to explain to me how these referendum proposals would provide any security of tenure for any selected third sphere of government. I asked the Shires Association whether it has been conned-and, if so, by whom-into believing that the widely condemned dismissal of the elected Council of the City of Sydney on 26 March 1987 would have been impossible had such a section been in place. That is simply not so and the Minister obviously knows that that is not so. The proposal does not do anything of the sort, yet the Minister reads at great length-it was probably the substance of her speech-from letters from local government organisations condemning the Opposition's position. She knows perfectly well that those letters are based on a simple misunderstanding, as I have just demonstrated.

TALK.START.PARA: —She is going to be laughed off the platforms when she tries to explain the position.

—I hope that she is not laughed off the platforms as I have a personal regard for her and I hope that she is not embarrassed in that way. But she is risking being laughed off the platform if the sort of defence she presents at such meetings is the set of statements she made here tonight in what I understood to be an attempt to defend the referendum proposals.
—Come with me.

—The Minister has extended to me an invitation which is too good to refuse. If she were to allow me to share platforms with her throughout Australia on this issue I would be overjoyed to accept her kind invitation. I am grateful to the Minister. I will make myself available to be with her and, apart from the fact that I would enjoy her company, I would particularly enjoy being able to explain to the people of Australia just what utter bunkum the Minister has been spouting and what an utter lack of substance is involved. I have demonstrated that the two points so far made by the Shires Association in this letter are of no merit whatsoever. They are simply not true. Let us consider another point. The letter states that the section would add `an important degree of security' for local government which until now has been `conspicuously absent'. I would be most grateful if someone would tell me what is the added degree of security it would give to local government. Perhaps the Minister, when we are talking around Australia or having a cup of tea or coffee before or after our periods of verbal intercourse, could explain to me what this important degree of security would be. I am unaware of it, and so far the people of Australia are unaware of it.

SPEECH.PARA: The next point the Shires Association makes is that constitutional recognition would mean a significant enhancement of local government in the eyes of the community. In other words, once we kiss local government on the forehead it will suddenly bloom, and blossom. This is arrant nonsense. Did recognition of local government in the constitutions of the States of New South Wales, Victoria, Western Australian and South Australia provide significant enhancement of local government in the eyes of the community? Not on your nelly! In New South Wales, shortly after local government had been recognised, the Council of the City of Sydney was sacked. Recognition of local government does not bring any increased enhancement of local government in the eyes of the community, and certainly not necessarily in the eyes of the State governments. It is wishful thinking. There is no doubt in my mind that much of the response to this issue has been emotional and ridiculous. I have a high regard for the good work the Shires Association has done in non-political areas. But when its members venture into this sort of emotional suggestion, which is not backed by fact, they should go away and do their homework. The letter goes on that if local government received constitutional recognition:
Local elected members would feel entitled to a greater degree of consultation from Federal and State politicians and administrators.

I have heard of the politics of the warm inner glow. That verse comes frequently from the left wing of the Australian Labor Party to disrupt the plans of Senator Evans when he has those few lucid and rational moments in which he does things that fit in with Liberal Party policy. But the politics of the warm inner glow seem to me to be a little stretched when, in defence of changing the Constitution of 87 years, the reason given is that it would make aldermen feel better. I hope that they feel good anyway, because they are all doing a good job. But, in response to the suggestion that we should change the Constitution to make some aldermen feel better about their status and expect a greater degree of consultation, all I say to them is: Do they have a greater degree of consultation with their State colleagues as a result of local government being recognised in the constitutions of most States?

The Shires Association says in its letter that constitutional recognition of local government would create new opportunities for local government to work in a genuine partnership with the Commonwealth and States. How? It is a simple, uncomplicated question. If the Shires Association of New South Wales and the Federal Government believe that these are sound reasons for the people of Australia to change their Constitution after 87 years they should tell us how it does those things, what the substance is. As I said, we did not get anything from this Minister. The letter goes on:
It would ensure--
This I just cannot follow. I cannot follow most of it, I must admit, but this is even worse. The letter states that constitutional recognition would ensure:
that government programs were streamlined and more cost-effective-

I do not know how that is to happen. Recognition simply means, as I said, within the context of the State laws. I have no idea how constitutional recognition would ensure that government programs were streamlined and more cost-effective. I do not know in what way it would suddenly, magically, open the way for tripartite agreements. There are already tripartite agreements. The situation would not be altered, affected or influenced in any way. The letter says:
If a council were to be dismissed under State legislation, fresh elections would be called with a reasonable period of time-

That is arguable. I doubt whether that would be so. If State legislation specifically outlines a procedure to be followed, Federal recognition simply acknowledges the relationship of local government to the State law. So, on the one hand, we have from the Government a whole lot of baloney from a Minister who cannot explain the substance and, on the other, we have from the Shires Association a lack of understanding of the need to provide substance if its case is to be carried, if $30m is to be properly spent on this matter.

Senator Alston has prepared a most interesting paper on the case against constitutional recognition of local government. He quotes from a submission by the Federal Department of Local Government and Administrative Services to the Constitutional Commission Advisory Committee on Distribution of Powers in March 1987. This departmental submission, I believe, as Senator Alston does, is a damning indictment of the case for making a change to the Constitution. The Department says:
By our advocacy of the constitutional recognition of local government we do not propose extending the powers or entitlements of local government . . .
That is the Federal Government speaking. The submission continues:

We do not favour any enumeration of local government powers in an amended Constitution, for this would tamper with States rights, cause tension in intergovernmental relations, create rigidity rather than flexibility in the nation's system of public administration. Nor do we favour conferring general competence powers upon local government through the Australian Constitution because any such statement of powers would be rendered otiose by the limitations determined by State or Territory legislatures. We suggest merely a form of constitutional recognition which would be authorising and enabling in its effect.
I repeat that the submission states:
We do not propose extending the powers or entitlements of local government in this referendum proposal.

That is absolutely damning. The Federal Department itself is revealing that this referendum proposal is a total sham-it does nothing. Otherwise, it says, it would tamper with States rights. We have heard so far during this debate plenty of reasons why we should not alter the Constitution to provide constitutional recognition of local government, why there should be no recognition in the Constitution of local government along these lines, because there is no quid pro quo, no requirement of the Federal Government to do anything to provide substance to it, and we have heard absolutely nothing from the Government to justify this procedure at all. It seems to me that, if we are going to change the Constitution, it should be a cardinal rule, as it should be with all new laws, that the changes should not be introduced unless there is a requirement to meet a significant community need or to cure an existing defect. Where is the significant community need? Where is the existing defect? No case so far has been presented on this vital issue by the Government. Madam Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 7.30 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement entitled `Economic Statement May 1988' and to move to take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table four documents: Economic Statement May 1988; the 1988 Business Tax Reform; Taxation of Foreign Source Income; and Reform of the Taxation of Superannuation.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, tonight the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is announcing in the House of Representatives far reaching economic reforms that will take our nation into the twenty-first century. It is my privilege to outline these economic reforms to the Senate.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I know the Opposition would rather take us back to the nineteenth century.

SPEECH.PARA: Once again, cutbacks in government spending are a key element of these changes, paving the way for a Budget surplus next financial year in excess of $3000 million.
This surplus is the culmination of all the hard work done in reforming the tax system and cutting back the size of the public sector.
As we make further progress in restructuring the Australian economy it will form the basis of genuine, ``paid for'' reductions in personal income tax.
But this statement is about much more than our success in transforming the Budget.
Tonight the Treasurer is announcing another comprehensive range of fundamental economic reforms.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. Do we have copies of the Minister's statement?
—No copies have been supplied and there is no point of order.
—They rival anything this Government has undertaken before and easily surpass anything attempted by our predecessors-which would not be hard.

SPEECH.PARA: They include a huge cut in one stroke to the company tax rate, from 49 cents to 39 cents, putting Australian companies at the leading edge of world business.
At the same time we will further close the net on companies that have been better at exploiting tax breaks than at earning real profits.
The Government's landmark imputation system of company tax, which ended the double taxation of dividends is to be extended to all Australian investors.
The taxation of superannuation benefits is to be radically yet sympathetically changed, putting it on a more logical long term basis without reducing lump sum and pension entitlements.
There are to be big cuts to industry protection through tariff reductions, which will lower costs and further encourage our manufacturers to look beyond Australian for market opportunities.
Similarly, the high levels of government assistance provided to some pockets of primary industry will also be reduced.

Public sector business enterprises are to be put on a more commercial footing and many day to day bureaucratic controls lifted. Mr President, shortly I will provide more details on these reforms and my ministerial colleagues will explain them fully in supplementary statements.
But at the outset I want to make it clear why they are necessary.
This Government is committed to getting all aspects of the economy right.
For obvious reasons, our economic policy has had to focus on the broad issues, like the Budget deficit and Australia's balance of payments problems.
The float of the dollar, the elimination of the huge budget deficits and the repair of the wage system had to be the founding elements of our strategy.

But to develop and prosper in the long term we must harness these vast economy-wise changes and carry their benefits into the economic heart of the nation-to where individual firms and business operate.
That is, the impetus for change must be transmitted to managements and workers who make the crucial decisions about where and when to invest, and how to go about their work.
If we cannot get these things right, we will never really get the big picture right.
This is why the Government has adopted such a complete and comprehensive strategy; big brush economic changes reinforced by sweeping strokes going to the micro or industry level.
What we have been after is a full picture-not something half finished.
GOVERNMENT SPENDING
Mr President, I said at the outset that next financial year the Commonwealth Government will budget for a surplus in excess of $3000 million.
In other words, we will be repaying debt, rather than adding to it.
This is crucial to our future.
Just as any individual might borrow money to get over a bad patch, the Australian nation has been borrowing heavily over the past decade.
Now we have the opportunity, we must pay some of it back.
If we do not, another commodity price collapse could cripple our economy.
Government saving through surpluses helps our external accounts in three ways.
First, it means the Commonwealth can repay some of its own foreign debt.
Second, more private funds are available for investment in export and import competing industries without borrowing from abroad.
And third, curbing government spending will help to hold down domestic demand and import growth while the new industrial capacity is given time to improve our trade balance.
These are the reasons why the Commonwealth had to impose further substantial cuts in State grants and borrowings at the Premiers' Conference two weeks ago.
Mr President, next financial year's strong budget surplus will be underpinned by the third consecutive annual cut in real spending by the Commonwealth Government.
This outcome, unprecedented in Australia, has not been matched by any other industrial country.
In the 1988-89 Budget, real outlays are expected to fall by 1.5 per cent, adding to cuts totalling more than 3 per cent in the previous two years.
As a result, Commonwealth outlays as a share of the Australian economy will have fallen from 30 per cent to less than 26 per cent in just three Budgets.
Again, this cannot be matched by any major industrial country.
This third consecutive reduction in real outlays has been made possible by gross spending cuts of more than $1350 million.
These decisions include cuts to defence, roads, pharmaceuticals, fertiliser subsidies, payments to the States and other changes detailed in the supporting documents.
Once again we have made spending changes which build in their impact in later years to deliver a fourth consecutive cut in real outlays in 1989-90.
TAXATION
Mr President, the tax reforms the Treasurer is announcing tonight are as significant as those implemented by the Government in 1985.
I remind you, that at that time, reforms like the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and the abolition of business deductions for entertainment were the subject of much dispute.
But this Government saw to it that those changes were successfully implemented.
Now they are permanent features of the tax system, playing a proper role in funding lower tax rates and lower interest rates for all Australians.
Tonight's changes represent a second major wave of reform.
The Government is to cut the corporate tax rate in one step, from 49 cents to 39 cents, to give Australian companies a tax structure more than competitive with the rest of the world.
The lower rate will first apply for the 1988-89 income year.

In determining the appropriate company tax regime, the Government takes the view that when a potential investment is examined, the overall return should govern the decision, not the availability or timing of tax concessions.
Accordingly, the Government has decided to lower the company tax rate by removing some tax concessions.
That is, lowering the company tax rate by broadening the company tax base.
So instead of tax breaks only being available to select businesses, with others shouldering the burden, all companies will now enjoy a lower tax rate.
In other words, a better and fairer company tax system.
The largest tax concession to be reduced is the accelerated depreciation system which allows companies to write off equipment over three or five years, even if its actual life is much longer.
In future, deductions will be based on the effective life of the equipment, but with the bonus of a 20 per cent loading to stimulate new investment in all areas.
Thus the tax system will no longer misallocate scarce national resources to projects which are tax driven by an artificial depreciation rate.
From 1 July 1991 the special 150 per cent deduction for research and development expenditure will be reduced to 100 per cent and the Management and Investment Company Scheme will be discontinued.
The unique position of gold mining as the only industry in Australia which does not pay income tax cannot be justified.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the promise?
—Well I wonder why the Queensland Government taxes gold mining!

SPEECH.PARA: In fully honouring the Government's 1987 commitments, that exemption will end from 1 January 1991.
Reflecting the reduction in the company tax rate, tax concessions currently available to life offices will also be removed.
The consessional tax rate applying to friendly societies will be increased from 20 to 30 per cent.
Our landmark dividend imputation system of company tax credits is also to be extended to those institutions.

Concessions available to the livestock producing industries will be reduced, but to assist primary producers subject to erratic fluctuations in incomes, the tax link to income equalisation deposits is to be re-established from 1 July 1989-although, I interpolate on a different basis of course from the rorted system which prevailed in the Fraser-Howard years.
The existing 10BA film tax concession is to be replaced with a more effective, less costly and more visible budget outlay administered by a Film Finance Corporation.
Funding of $70 million is to be provided in 1988-89.
Tonight's statement also provides for assistance to employee share schemes.
This will facilitate the legitimate interest of employees in getting a stake in the companies they work for.
A range of measures are to be taken to prevent unjustified tax minimisation.
These include the requirement that private companies pay tax on dividends where no company tax has been paid.
The inter-corporate dividend rebate is also to be denied to dividends paid by tax exempt authorities, thereby closing off an opportunity for State governments to indulge in tax minimisation schemes.
The standard rate of deduction under the prescribed payments system is to rise from 15 to 20 per cent to clamp down on evasion.
Like most individual Australians, the great majority of our corporate citizens are honest taxpayers.
But this Government will not tolerate any action by companies which rip-off the rest of the community.
To that end, the Australian Tax Office is to be provided with more resources to investigate complex corporate tax affairs.
The Commissioner of Taxation believes that these measures could return upwards of $800 million over the next five years.
At the same time we will crack down on the use of international tax havens.

A much more rigorous tax system is to be applied from 1 July 1989 to companies and individuals who used any of up to 60 designated overseas tax havens-that is, places like Bermuda, Monaco and the Cayman Islands.
But at the same time we are providing a substantial benefit for genuine trading companies with the ambition to seek out new markets and opportunities abroad.
Slicing 10 cents from the company tax rate enables a substantial modification of the Foreign Tax Credit System.
From July 1989, dividends received by Australian companies from non tax haven countries will be exempt from Australian company tax.
The Tax Office has been given the go ahead to develop a system for making greater use of tax file numbers in its normal administration, the same as it does now for the prescribed payments system.
There will be no identity card and at no time will people be required to produce a tax file number as a form of personal identification.
The only purpose of the file number will be to make it easier for the Tax Office to match information it receives about money earned and interest payments.
This system is for the exclusive and limited use of the Tax Office-it will simply allow the better use of information the Tax Office already receives.
PERSONAL TAX CUTS
Mr President, as I indicated at the outset, the Government is committed to providing all Australians with personal income tax cuts in 1989-90.
However, for the immediate future the full force of the nation's fiscal resources must be devoted to keeping domestic demand in check and dealing with our external debt problem.
This task has been made all the more urgent by the recent evidence that demand has been running too strongly.
Australia has made huge strides in recent years in cutting back our balance of payments deficit.
After all this hard work, the very last thing we can afford now is to let excessive demand cause imports to run away from us.
On top of that, the legacy of the massive commodity price collapse we have endured is an external debt burden which is far too big.
Next financial year the Government must use its budget surplus to help prevent that debt burden mounting.
To do otherwise would be to neglect our responsibilities to the nation.
That is why personal income tax cuts cannot responsibly be afforded until 1989-90.
It should also be understood that with company tax lagging income by one year, the company tax cuts I announced tonight will not impact on the Commonwealth's budget until July 1989.
In other words, the personal and company tax cuts will be paid from the Budget in the same financial year.
Until then revenue from both companies and personal income taxpayers must be devoted to combating our trade problem.
A firm budget policy is only part of the answer to our balance of payments problem.
Our overriding objective must also be to keep wages growth as close as possible to our trading partners so that we remain competitive on world markets.
After the hard work and sacrifice of recent years, and with inflation now heading towards 5 per cent or lower, this objective is consistent with the overall maintenance of real wages in 1988-89.
The personal tax cuts we have foreshadowed will provide Australia with a unique opportunity to bring our wages growth further into line with our trading partners.
However, the size and timing of those cuts will depend upon the size and timing of future wage rises.
That is, the Government is prepared to provide substantial tax cuts provided there is an acceptable wages outcome in 1988-89 and an appropriate wages/tax trade-off in 1989-90.
The Government will stress this point in its discussions with the ACTU over the next twelve months.
I am confident that an acceptable basis can be established for a sustainable rise in real after tax incomes.
SUPERANNUATION AND RETIREMENT INCOMES
This Government is the first since Federation to recognise the right of all Australian workers to superannuation.
When we came to office in 1983, only four employees in ten received any form of superannuation benefit.
By the end of this parliamentary term that level of coverage will have doubled due to our support for superannuation, and particularly for its spread through industry based schemes.
We are totally committed to superannuation having a special and secure place in the Australian savings and retirement income system.
It will continue to be supported by generous tax concessions.
Tonight's announcements will enhance the integrity of the superannuation system without disturbing the end-benefits of contributors, other than those on exceptionally high incomes.
In other words, the value of existing and future lump sums and pensions will not be reduced by these changes.
The particular problem we are addressing is the exclusion of superannuation funds from receiving tax credits under the dividend imputation system of company tax.
This means that they cannot fully share in the profits of Australia's major corporations.
It also means that our public companies are denied the full investment support of our superannuation funds and their many contributors.
This distortion has the harmful side effect of encouraging elaborate tax minimisation schemes.
The Government has therefore decided to bring superannuation funds within the full ambit of the imputation system, giving them access to dividend tax credits.
To achieve this a tax of 15 per cent will apply to fund earnings.
But this 15 per cent tax can be neutralised or offset by the receipt of dividend tax credits.
For most superannuation funds this will mean in practice no tax at all on investment earnings.
For others the rate will be minimal, and can readily be adjusted to zero by including more Australian company shares in their investment portfolios.
This will ensure no detriment to any lump sum or pension end-benefit.
The second measure which the Treasurer is announcing tonight shifts the timing of the taxation of employer contributions for superannuation.
Under the current arrangements, tax is paid by the employee on such benefits when they are taken out of a fund.
The new system will mean that the tax is paid instead by the fund itself as contributions are made by employers.
This change will not reduce the related end-benefits but will align the structure of superannuation taxation with other forms of savings.
For most fund members, the lump-sum tax will be abolished completely.
It also has the effect of bringing forward revenue to the Government that would otherwise have been collected many years in the future.
That is, it will allow the Government to bring forward nearly $1 billion of its own tax money-now lying in superannuation funds-without diminishing any personal end-benefit by one cent.
This money will contribute towards funding the personal tax cuts which we will make next year.

As a further encouragement for people to provide for their retirement, the limit on tax deductions for contributions to small business and related superannuation funds will be doubled to $3,000 a year.
Finally, we have acted to prevent these generous tax concessions being exploited by the very well-off through massive end-benefits.
This tightening of the maximum benefit limits will diminish the tax advantages of excessive benefits for people on very high incomes.
It will make the whole system more progressive.
Together these changes complete the Government's review of superannuation tax arrangements.
People can therefore plan for their retirement with complete certainty and confidence.
PENSIONERS

Mr President, during the last five years this Government has increased the real value of the pension by more than eight per cent and increased the amount pensioners can earn without losing part of their benefit.
They will be further assisted by our decision to increase the pensioner tax rebate from $250 a year to $430.
This means a single pensioner will now be able to earn over $10 per week free of tax, compared with $3.70 per week previously.
Further, in a new measure, any pensioner in receipt of any part of the pensioner tax rebate will be exempt from paying provisional tax.
These changes will release 255,000 pensioners from provisional taxation.
STRUCTURAL REFORM
Mr President, I described earlier how our economic reforms must extend to every business and workplace in the economy.
In the past many of the so-called industry assistance arrangements introduced by successive governments have been anything but of assistance.
Their legacy is a less flexible economy, too reliant on protection and regulation.
The way forward for Australia is not to be closeted and sheltered, but to be open and dynamic, trading aggressively in the world.
Only this kind of economy can provide the employment and rising living standards that Australians aspire to.
This is the very point of the measures contained in this economic statement.
Accordingly, the Government will peel away more of this protection.
From 1 July tariffs in excess of 15 per cent will be progressively reduced to that level, while tariffs between 10 and 15 per cent will be reduced to 10 per cent.
The changes will be phased in over a four year period.
They are equivalent to a cut of around 20 per cent in average protection levels in manufacturing industry.
The Government will be monitoring the impact of these measures, but I am confident that this gradual change can be absorbed without major disruption.
Substantial reductions under the passenger motor vehicle plan have already been announced and further adjustments will be made to accelerate the textiles, clothing and footwear plan.
The Government will also remove the two per cent revenue duty on imports, saving industry and consumers $240 million a year.
Mr President, it is well known that our primary producers as a group do not receive nearly the same level of assistance as some of our manufacturers, but there are a few exceptions.
Existing schemes which artificially prop up the domestic prices of farm products such as butter, sugar, tobacco and some fruit are to be phased down.
Consumers stand to benefit by up to $100 million per annum when these changes are fully implemented.
Competition in grain storage and transport is also to be increased.
Some of the gains from reducing primary industry assistance are to be directed to funding for crucial soil conservation and disease eradication programs.
The Government has also taken major steps to reform its business enterprises and to put them on a more commercial and efficient footing.

Enterprises such as Qantas, Australian Airlines, Telecom and Australia Post have a key role to play in the development of this nation and it is absolutely essential that their performance be guided by commercial considerations.
To this end they will be freed of many of their present day to day bureaucratic controls.
They will be held more accountable for their own performance and their managements will be required to measure up.
More competitive pressure will also be applied to the operations of Telecom and the Overseas Telecommunications Commission to provide better and cheaper services to business and consumers.
CONCLUSION
Mr President, the measures I have just outlined represent another milestone in the transformation of the Australian economy and another chapter in the proud economic history of this Government.
No Australian government has ever presented such a comprehensive program of change in a single package.
Spending cuts to deliver the largest budget surplus in our history.
Tax changes to put our companies at the cutting edge of world commerce.
Changes to industry protection to promote competitiveness and efficiency.
And, at the same time, setting the stage for major personal tax cuts without diminishing the essential programs which provide much of the fairness in our society.
Mr President, these policies are designed to further free up the dynamic forces within this economy, forces which if properly directed and harnessed will power our economy towards the 21st century.
It is this strength which will sustain the aspirations of our people and secure their future.
I move:
That the Senate take note of the statement.
Debate (on motion by Senator Chaney) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Victoria-Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)-I seek leave to make a statement entitled `May Economic Statement, Supplementary Statement and Industry Measures' and to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
Earlier this evening the Treasurer announced as part of a comprehensive program of micro-economic reforms a number of changes affecting industry, including a phased program of tariff reductions.

The decisions announced tonight follow the strategy adopted by this government since 1983. This strategy has been directed at developing an internationally competitive, export oriented industrial structure through attitudinal change in industry and the community, revitalisation of mature industries and creating the conditions conducive to the growth of new industries.

In 1983 we inherited a weak manufacturing sector. Many of Australia's largest industries were sacking workers and reducing output. Years of sheltering behind protective barriers had taken their toll on the productivity and dynamism of Australian industry. This, combined with an over-valued exchange rate had led to a dramatic slump in manufacturing output and employment in the early 1980s. In addition, Australia's performance in the newer high technology sectors was well below that of comparable countries. Other economies were adapting their industrial structures and supporting infrastructure to the realities of new products and activities while Australia was lagging behind.

The tasks confronting the Government were threefold. First, the environment within which industry operated needed to be improved. Second, the government needed to take action to improve the performance of our existing industries to arrest Australia's industrial decline. Third, the government needed to set a framework for the growth of more efficient and vital industry in the longer term.

The Treasurer has outlined the macro-economic achievements of this government. These have been a pre-requisite for improved industry performance. Industry competitiveness has also been improved by regulatory reform, including the deregulation of the financial sector.

In relation to the second aspect industry plans were formulated for the steel, passenger motor vehicles, ship building, heavy engineering, and the textiles, clothing and footwear industries. They are transitional mechanisms through which critical problems specific to these sectors are addressed. They provide a stable environment to allow revitalisation and restructuring to take place. An important component is the phased reduction in government support, particularly through reductions in tariffs, and greater concentration on the underlying determinants of competitiveness.

These plans have been successful. For example, in the steel industry, investment over the life of the plan has exceeded $1.5 billion, well above the $800 million originally planned by BHP. BHP is now one of the lowest cost producers of primary steel in the world, and is well placed to capitalise on Australia's natural resources.

Last month I outlined the enormous progress that has been made under the passenger motor vehicle plan. This progress made possible the removal of quotas and significant further reductions in protection accorded this industry.

Individual reviews were also conducted into assistance arrangements for many other industry sectors. These included chemicals and plastics, pulp, paper and paper products, glass and glassware, medical and scientific equipment, computer hardware and software and communications equipment.

One result of this process of review was the `tops-down' reduction of protective barriers, through phased tariff reductions, to tariff rate ceilings of 15 per cent. Anomalies and distortions in assistance arrangements were also removed. The decisions announced tonight extend these established principles to those industries which were due for review in the near future.

Having put in place a consistent and phased approach to tariff reductions industry was better able to concentrate on areas vital to the building of long term international competitive advantage. These areas include quality, design, marketing, and research and development. There has been a fundamental change in industry approach away from government assistance towards firms themselves addressing those factors so crucial to their success.
Government policy has also concentrated on providing the conditions within which Australian industries generally can prosper and tap into the fastest growing areas of world activity.

To this end initiatives aimed at improving research and development and industrial innovation, upgrading the internal efficiency of firms, increasing the availability of development finance and venture capital, strengthening international collaboration and cooperation, and promoting our products in the international market place have been introduced.

One aspect of our policies to link Australian industry into the world economy is the civil offsets program. This program has undergone significant changes in scope and direction in recent years. The emphasis is now progressively shifting from the short-term and fragmented approach of the past, towards an approach based on long term collaborative opportunities by linking local and transnational companies. Offsets are now seen as a potent industry policy mechanism capable of catalysing export-oriented, competitive, high technology, industrial activity where opportunities had previously existed but remained dormant.

Following the review of government business enterprises (GBE) it has been decided that offsets will continue to apply to Qantas purchases. In respect of purchases by other airlines the continued application of the policy will be reviewed. For other GBE's the continued application of the offsets policy to those aspects of their activities which directly compete with the private sector also will be reviewed.

In addition, the Government has harnessed our considerable technological, research, education and training resources to the task of creating a world class manufacturing sector. Government funded research institutions, and particularly the CSIRO, are providing a better environment for commercial innovation and are seeking linkages with industry.

All these initiatives have been designed to build on areas of underlying competitive strengths and have been framed to encourage innovation and self reliance within industry. Programs generally are designed to operate for set periods of time to avoid the risk of replacing one form of dependency by another.

In developing its policies the Government has fostered a greater dialogue and recognition of mutual goals between the Government, industry and the unions. The Australian Manufacturing Council has been an important component of this dialogue.
The Government has recently reviewed the AMC and the industry councils, and has decided to retain the industry councils system but with a reduced number of councils and more effective structure.
This will enable the councils to continue with their work and will provide them with the flexibility and capacity to deal with the major issues concerning industry.

The Government's policies have achieved significant success. For example manufacturing output has grown steadily since 1983 and most significantly, total employment in manufacturing has increased over this period. This reverses a long term decline in manufacturing employment.

Our balance of payments difficulties highlighted the need for our manufacturing and traded services industries to make a greater contribution if our standards of living were to be maintained into the future. Under our policies manufacturing has responded. The value of exports of elaborately transformed manufactures has more than doubled since 1982-83.

The success of the research and development programs is already manifest. In the early 1980's Australian industry's research and development performance was little short of abysmal. However, the latest information shows that research and development in Australian business in 1986-87 exceeded $1 billion and has increased in real terms by 85 per cent over the level of 1981-82. Business research and development as a percentage of GDP has risen from 0.24 per cent to 0.42 per cent.
Despite this success more needs to be done to link our industry firmly into the world economy.

The depreciation of the Australian dollar provided industry with a large boost to its competitiveness and has provided a springboard for many firms to enter the international market. Some people had argued for an immediate cut in protection following the depreciation. The Government, though, was concerned to allow industry time to reassess opportunities in the light of this new outlook and to build up productive capacity.

It is now appropriate that we increase the pace of tariff reductions, but in a manner consistent with our past policies and in a way that will provide a predictable and stable environment into the future. This will ensure that we lock in the gains in competitiveness flowing from the depreciation. In addition we have taken other decisions to improve the environment within which industry operates.
Industry Assistance

Generally, tariff rates above 15 per cent are to be reduced to 15 per cent in five equal steps over the next 4 years. The first reduction will take place on 1 July 1988, and subsequent cuts will take effect on 1 July 1989, 1 July 1990, 1 July 1991 and 1 July 1992. Tariffs currently greater than 10 but not greater than 15 per cent will be reduced to 10 per cent over the same period.

These changes will not affect tariff arrangements in the passenger motor vehicle industry, where the government has recently announced substantially reduced protection, or in the chemicals and plastics industry. In this industry tariffs are phasing to a ceiling of 15 per cent and changes now would recreate the anomalies corrected by the Government in its recent decision on assistance for that industry.

The decision will not affect items which are currently phasing to 15 per cent or below. This covers the bulk of items in the pulp, paper and printing, medical and scientific equipment, and glass and glassware industries. Items in the communications industry, which are currently phasing to 20 per cent will now reach 15 per cent over the four year program.

In the textile, clothing and footwear (TCF) area, the Government announced a new plan for these industries in June 1987. The plan was developed in close consultation with industry and unions and is to commence fully in March 1989. The TCF industries however, will benefit from general reductions in industry assistance and from the broader economic reforms outlined by the Treasurer. Accordingly, the TCF industries have been included in the ambit of the general reductions in assistance.

The adjustments to the TCF plan have been made within the context of the plan. The changes reflect the benefits to the sector accruing from assistance and economic reform and help maintain the relativities in industry assistance between the TCF industries and manufacturing industry generally.
The main changes are:
A reduction of 5 percentage points for most of the higher tariff rates set for the new plan;
A shortening of the new TCF plan so that it concludes on 30 June 1995; and
No changes to the textile bounty arrangements except for the bounty on certain continuous filament yarn manufacture and for textile printing.

In making these changes, the Government was particularly mindful of the previous agreement it had reached with industry and unions, and sought to maintain the spirit of those deliberations. The Government maintains its strong commitment to support the restructuring and revitalisation of the TCF industries. For its part the Government continues to stand by its assurances on the industry development strategy, the Labour adjustment mechanisms and the safety net features of the new plan. The TCF Development Authority has been established to implement these programs and it will commence operations formally from 1 June.

A `tops down' approach has been adopted to general tariff reductions consistent with changes over the past few years. This approach is preferable to across the board options as it targets the most heavily protected industries and therefore reduced disparities in assistance between industries.

This decision speeds up the existing tariff review process and provides a predictable environment into the future. It is consistent with the government's sustained efforts to reduce industry's reliance on inward looking barrier protection, and to create internationally competitive industries.
As a result of the program, foreshadowed IAC inquiries into industries such as the fabricated metals, industrial machinery and whitegoods will not now be necessary for tariff review purposes.

The IAC reports on mining, construction and agricultural equipment and precious metals, gems and jewellery are due to be considered by the Government. Because these industries will be affected by the general reductions in tariffs no additional action will be taken on tariff aspects of these reports.

The Government is, however, disposed to extend concessional entry to certain items of mining, construction and agricultural equipment not manufactured in Australia, when the IAC report on these goods is considered.

Apart from the bounties on fertilisers (which are referred to in the statement by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy) and on TCF, manufacturing bounty arrangements will not be altered. Generally these bounties provide relatively low levels of assistance and expire before the end of the tariff reduction program. In addition bounties were reduced by 20 per cent in the 1986 Budget. Any extension to existing bounties will require an IAC inquiry. And at that time the tariff changes will be taken into account.

The current inquiry into the shipbuilding industry, which is assisted by bounties, will continue and the Government will make a decision on future arrangements for that industry once the IAC report has been received. Similarly the inquiry by the steel industry authority into the steel industry will continue and decisions on that industry made upon receipt of the report.

The 2 per cent revenue duty, which imposed a large cost on industry will be abolished on 1 July 1988. Over 80 per cent of the duty was paid on intermediate or capital goods and was therefore a direct tax on production in Australia, handicapping our manufacturers facing international competition. The tax itself was not inconsiderable, revenue foregone by this decision is about $240 million per annum.

The abolition of the 2 per cent revenue duty and the reduction in tariffs will reduce input costs for many industries and make them more competitive on international markets. To further improve the competitiveness of Australian industry the government has decided to simplify the duty drawback and by-law for export schemes and reduce their costs to users. By allowing relief from import duties on inputs into export production under these schemes, unwarranted costs will not be imposed on firms which compete in export markets.

For similar reasons the government will modify the Commercial Tariff Concessions System (CTCS) to more closely align its operations with the government's industry and technology policy objectives. Greater use will be made of the policy by-laws in those cases where the CTCS criteria are not met but strong grounds for concessional entry exist. Policy by-laws will, however, only be granted following formal consideration of the issues by the IAC.
Last year the Minister for Community Services and Health and I outlined new policies to encourage the development of the pharmaceutical industry.
These proposals included the establishment of an independent authority to set prices for pharmaceutical products supplied under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

The government has now agreed to the recommendation of the authority as to how Australian industry activity and development should be taken into account in the setting of prices in order to encourage industry development. The guidelines are complex and the government has recognised that the authority will need to refine them in consultation with the industry and develop them in the light of experience.
The details of the guidelines that the authority will use are spelled out in a joint statement by myself and the Minister for Community Services and Health.

In recognition of the length of time that it has taken to develop these guidelines, the government has decided to postpone the introduction of generic pricing arrangements until 1 December this year. These arrangements, which limit the price differential that can apply to alternate brands of the same drug to 20 cents, will generate some savings to partially offset the overall costs of the industry development initiatives.
The government has reviewed the Export Market Development Grants (EMDG) scheme and will introduce changes to increase the cost effectiveness of the program while maintaining support for exporters.

These changes include an increase in threshold expenditures to $10,000, retention of the maximum grant rate of 70 per cent, reduction in the maximum grant which can be claimed from the present $200,000 for recipients of more than eight grants, introduction of a group of corporations test, a requirement that new claimants submit an ``export market plan'' and tightening of the export earnings test. Expenditure on export market development in relation to New Zealand will no longer be eligible for grants.

The government recognises the need for continued progress in developing the export orientation of Australian firms. There is scope for Austrade to enhance its role as a catalyst for export development, by supporting innovative undertakings, and with this in mind an additional $5m will be made available in each of the next two years for new discretionary export market development activities. This fund will be administered by Austrade in conjunction with the EMDG scheme. There will be a major review of export assistance arrangements prior to 30 June 1990 to ensure the continuing effectiveness of this assistance.

For some time the government has been supporting Australian exporters under the Development Import Finance Facility (DIFF) within the Australian aid program. The scheme allows grant aid funds to be used in combination with commercial finance from EFIC to provide concessional finance to support Australian exporters.

However, under the current arrangements there is insufficient flexibility to fund large and unpredictable payments within the annual aid budget. The government believes that these large, `showpiece' projects can be very important in establishing the credibility of Australian manufacturing industry and has therefore decided that where a proposed project is of such a size that funds would not be available under the existing DIFF allocation, the government will examine support for these proposals on a case-by-case basis.

The tariff reductions will be phased over four years and take place at a time when Australian industry is competitive. In addition other initiatives announced tonight will improve the environment for industry. As a result the government does not anticipate that the reductions will lead to large-scale dislocation. However, the government will establish an office of labour market adjustment in the department of employment, education and training to monitor the impact of its decision on the work force.
Discussions with industry and unions prior to this decision highlighted concerns about developing country preferences and anti-dumping arrangements.

While existing tariff preference arrangements will remain unchanged at this time, the government has undertaken to keep the scheme under review as tariffs are reduced and in the light of other industrial countries' treatment of preferences.

The Government recognises the need for fair trade, particularly at a time of accelerated tariff reductions, and is committed to effective and speedy anti-dumping arrangements. An independent Anti-Dumping Authority will be established to improve the operation and timeliness of anti-dumping procedures by:
enhancing the commercial expertise and advice available to the Government on anti-dumping matters;
setting maximum statutory time limits on each stage of the process;
making provision for complaints to be made and investigations to begin before goods arrive in Australia; and
enabling groups of people, such as employees, affected by dumped goods to initiate complaints.
TAXATION CHANGES

Innovation and entrepreneurship is at the heart of positioning Australian industry in the much more competitive world in which we now find ourselves. I mentioned earlier the initiatives the Government has taken to encourage private sector research and development.

The 150 per cent taxation concession for eligible research and development expenditures will be continued until 30 June 1991. This will remove any uncertainty about this program and will enable industry to continue to lift its investment in research and development. After this date this concession will be replaced by 100 per cent tax deductibility for companies, partnerships, individuals and trusts. In addition, prior to 1991, the Government also will consider further Commonwealth expenditure support for industry research and development.

While I am encouraged at the growth that has already occurred in private sector research and development, much must still be done to develop the new and innovative products needed on export markets. These announcements will provide the stable and supportive environment within which firms can undertake longer term research and development.
The taxation concession for MIC Investments is to be extended and will now finish on 30 June 1991.

In further extending this scheme, the Government recognised the continuing relevance of the program to the establishment of a viable venture capital market in Australia, particularly given the changed circumstances following the stock market collapse last year. This scheme has been particularly helpful to the development of small high tech firms, which are beginning to make their presence felt on world markets.

The Government recognises that recent taxation rulings on wholesale sales tax on computer software have created uncertainty and anomalies. We wish to review these matters urgently with industry, and a meeting will be held in early June between industry representatives, my Department and the Treasury to examine this issue. Following that meeting the Government will consider the matter.

The Government's decision on taxation treatment of employee share ownership schemes recognises that maximising the contribution of the work force can be a very powerful source of competitive advantage for a company. Successful implementation of modern manufacturing systems, technologies and quality improvement programs depends on positive work force attitudes. Employee share ownership schemes are an important means of encouraging greater employee commitment and this change to the taxation arrangements will stimulate their adoption.
CONCLUSION

The phased program of tariff reductions is an essential part of the internationalisation of the Australian economy. Australian industry, if it is to compete successfully internationally, must operate in a competitive environment. The taxation changes announced by the Treasurer, particularly the reduction in the corporate tax rate, assist in this respect. Similarly, improved efficiency in the operation of public enterprises, the reductions in tariffs, and the removal of the 2 per cent revenue duty, will bring input costs more into line with that of our major trading partners.

Most importantly, the Government has established a predictable assistance environment for the next four years. Industry can now proceed with investment plans confident in the knowledge that their assistance levels are set for the foreseeable future.
They will also be able to concentrate on the factors essential to international competitiveness such as quality, marketing, innovation and work practices.

Real progress has already been made in manufacturing industry-some people are now starting to speak about a manufacturing renaissance. Whatever the truth of this judgment-one thing is clear. We do not have the luxury of shooting at a fixed target, therefore ongoing changes need to be made if we are to compete successfully in an increasingly competitive and integrated world economy.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.
Debate (on motion by Senator Chaney) adjourned.
