SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a paper entitled `Reshaping the Transport and Communications Government Business Enterprises' and I seek leave to make a statement relating to that paper.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The initiatives contained in the ministerial statement which I have just tabled are central to the Government's micro-economic reform agenda for the restructuring of the public sector. In the present difficult international environment, public sector efficiency is especially important because so many public business enterprises-particularly those in the Transport and Communications portfolio-produce not only final goods and services for the consumer, but intermediate inputs for the rest of the economy and thus influence the nation's overall cost structures.

SPEECH.PARA: With this in mind, the Government has undertaken a fundamental review of the eight major transport and communications government business enterprises, namely Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines, Australian National Line (ANL), Australian National Railways (AN), Telecom Australia, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC), Aussat Pty Ltd and Australia Post, and has decided on a package of reforms which are aimed at reshaping these enterprises and improving their efficiency.

The package applies, and builds on, the principles laid down in the `Policy Guidelines for Commonwealth Statutory Authorities and Government Business Enterprises' tabled by the Minister for Finance, Senator Peter Walsh, on 4 November 1987. The detailed statement which should be circulated in a moment explains in detail the consideration given by the Government to these enterprises and the decisions taken to bring about reform.

All the enterprises make an important direct contribution to the Australian economy as well as providing services to other industries and businesses. Between them they are responsible for 37.9 per cent of Commonwealth employment and 9.5 per cent of total public sector employment. In all, they account for 2.9 per cent of the Australian work force. They account for 17.5 per cent of Commonwealth revenue and 15.7 per cent of Commonwealth expenditure. Total assets at book values are almost $21 billion.

Australians have an important investment in the enterprises. As at June 1987 the Commonwealth's investment, through equity and loan, in these eight businesses, was estimated at $9,400m or $1,900 for every Australian household.

Transport and communications infrastructure forms the very fabric of our economy-without it industry could not function, our exports could not reach their markets, and we would be limited in our participation in global financial markets and the growing service industries such as tourism. It is clear, accordingly, that every improvement we can make in the way we deliver transport and communications services is economically vital. Fundamental improvement in the way the enterprises in question operate is not only desirable, but essential. The era of effortless post-war growth in a protected environment is over. World-wide trends are now towards:
greater competition;
a more hostile international trading environment;
global corporations;
more open, less regulated economies;
a more integrated and sophisticated financial world; and
massive technological development and innovation.

The transport and communications enterprises need, more than ever before, flexibility and the ability to respond rapidly to changes in the market and to take up opportunities as they present themselves. Consequently, the Government has decided on a reform package for each enterprise covering the appropriate structure for each enterprise; the relationship, between government as owner/shareholder, enterprise boards and enterprise managers; new planning and accountability mechanisms; the modification of major strategic controls and removal of controls over day to day activities. In summary the new arrangements include:

the implementation of new planning and accountability mechanisms which will include requirements for corporate plans and the setting of financial targets, and will allow the Government to focus on `bottom line' results rather than central, controls over managerial decision making;
revised corporate and financial structures for most of the enterprises, which will better reflect the new economic and commercial environment in which they are operating:
OTC and ANL are to be converted into companies incorporated under the Companies Act-100 per cent Commonwealth owned;

the Telecom and Australia Post commissions to be renamed the Australia Telecommunications Corporation and the Australian Postal Corporation respectively, with new financial structures involving the conversion in each case of a quarter of existing Commonwealth loans to equity;
ANL to be able to operate integrated transportation services for Australia overseas and domestic trades to sustain its shipping services;
AN's legislation to be amended to enable AN to expand the scope of its business activities; and
Australia Post to be allowed to undertake commercial development of its properties;
significant modification of major `strategic' controls are involved which presently exist in relation to borrowings, industrial relations coordination, superannuation and executive remuneration; and

the removal of virtually all day to day government operational controls from the enterprises, including contracts, the investment of temporary surplus funds, the establishment of bank accounts, the terms and conditions of individual borrowings, and, subject to prior advice to the Minister controls over the establishment of subsidiaries, joint ventures and share purchases.

The Government expects that all these new arrangements will improve the way in which these enterprises conduct their business and will lead to marked efficiency gains which will mean better service delivery and improved productivity.
I move:
That the Senate take note of the statement.
Debate (on motion by Senator Messner) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN TELECOMMUNICATIONS SERVICES: A NEW FRAMEWORK

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I table a paper entitled `Australian Telecommunications Services: A New Framework' and seek leave to make a statement relating to that paper.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In describing the Government's third term agenda, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has given greatest emphasis to micro-economic policy: the structural adjustment of key industries, and the relationships between them, with a view to establishing and sustaining longer term growth. The Government's goal is to ensure that the manufacturing and service sectors, in particular, become more efficient and so improve our trade competitiveness, reduce our reliance on imports and ensure the Australian economy has the versatility, adaptability and resilience necessary to take advantage of the rapid changes this nation faces in the years ahead. The Australian telecommunications services industry is well placed to make a major contribution to these goals of efficiency and trade competitiveness in the information economy, while continuing to serve the important social objectives associated with the central role of the telephone in the Australian community. With this in mind, the Government initiated a fundamental review of telecommunications policy in September 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: One lesson of the recent past has been that current industry and structural arrangements do not readily lend themselves to the satisfactory and efficient resolution of many of the problems facing the industry. The Government has decided to reform the basic structural and regulatory framework, with the objective of establishing a framework within which appropriate service and price adjustments can take place without undue government intervention, while ensuring that the fundamental objectives of efficiency and equity continue to be met within the Government's new overall policy objectives.
The policy statement, which was referred to by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his speech earlier tonight, is directed to resolving five fundamental structural questions:
the extent to which existing monopoly arrangements for the provision of the basic network need to be maintained;
how the boundary lines between monopoly and competition should be drawn in the provision of value added services;
how the boundary lines between monopoly and competition should be drawn in the supply, installation and maintenance of customer premises equipment;
the need for a new independent body to carry out necessary new economic and technical regulatory functions; and
the extent to which the telecommunications carriers should be relieved from government constraints to enable them to perform more effectively.

The detailed statement which I have just tabled explains in very great detail the consideration given by the Government to the complex set of issues involved in reshaping arrangements for the telecommunications services industry. It sets out the decisions we have taken to bring about structural reform and the reasoning behind those decisions.

The decisions taken by the Government mark the most significant change in arrangements for the telecommunications industry since those the Labor Government put in place in 1975, when it set up Telecom and separated telecommunications from postal functions. While the 1975 decisions have served Australia well, they have been overtaken by events. The decisions which have now been taken by the Government will bring much more certainty to regulatory policy and permit the continuing orderly adjustment to the dynamic pressures-and opportunities-of technological change and changing user needs. The Government has decided to restructure the regulatory environment of the telecommunications services industry to provide for:
continuing authority for the existing carriers to be the sole providers of basic network facilities and services, subject to greater commercial and external regulatory discipline;
full scope for competition in the provision and operation of value added services;

increased scope for competition in the provision and maintenance of network terminal equipment for connection within customers' premises, in particular in relation to PABX maintenance and small business systems; and

establishment of regulatory arrangements that are independent of the carriers and directed towards ensuring maintenance of minimum necessary standards, fair and efficient competition beyond the monopoly boundaries, and improved efficiency and accountability for the monopoly carriers.

A central theme of the new arrangements is ensuring that the carriers, and in particular Telecom, are efficient, customer-oriented and fully responsive to both residential and business consumer needs. In developing the new arrangements, the Government has benefited greatly from the formal submissions it has received from users, unions, industry and State governments. The Government has also had the advantage of discussions with representatives of all sections of the telecommunications services industry and community groups affected by it. Those discussions have proved to be invaluable input to the decision-making process.

This review has been carried out concurrently with the review of the major transport and communications government business enterprises, the results of which are also being announced today in the statement that I tabled earlier. Major changes have been announced in that statement relating to the managerial environment in which Telecom, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission and Aussat will operate. The Government looks forward to the telecommunications services industry responding much more rapidly in future to pressing adjustment issues within the framework outlined in my statement. I move:
That the Senate take note of the statement.
Debate (on motion by Senator Messner) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on behalf of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) relating to the May economic statement, entitled `Industrial Development Review', and seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The creation of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy last year has provided a very timely opportunity to re-assess and re-align, where necessary, the policies and patterns of assistance of the Primary Industries and Resources sector.

But the review itself does more than that. It also recognises the linkages with the economy. In particular it recognises the economic activity and Government policy in one area spread through the economy and affect the cost, the outlook and the performance of others. By doing so, it forms an important element in the Government's achievement of bringing a total perspective to its microeconomic reforms.

As evident in the report tabled tonight, my review encompasses not only policies and expenditure programs, but also relevant tax measures, the effects of protection within the sector and within manufacturing, and the dependence of the sector on Transport and Infrastructure Industries.

Before outlining the results of the review, let me say that our Rural and Mining sectors are already very efficient industries. In the face of the prolonged and continuing decline in their terms of Trade, not to mention the collapse of commodity prices, they have continued to play a crucial role in maintaining our economic well-being.

Although there are still problems in cropping industries and the Coal Industry, by and large the Primary Industries and resources sector is showing signs of recovery and parts of it are thriving. This augurs well for our ability to overcome National Economic problems.
But we cannot assume that the revival in commodity prices alone will solve our Economic problems. We must continue to improve our efficiency and thereby our trade competitiveness.
As my colleague the Treasure has described, the Government will introduce a range of measures to further improve resource allocation and efficiency across the Economy.

These include phased reductions in Industry assistance levels with a shift in emphasis away from border protection towards positive assistance to promote competitiveness and structural adjustment. They also include further improvements in the efficiency and neutrality of the tax system.

These reforms, together with those contained in the Industry Development Review, will enable our trade goods sector, including Agricultural and resource industries, to become even more efficient and to compete more effectively in an Internationally Competitive Environment.
The Industry Development review therefore reflects, at a sectoral level, the longer term objectives which are central to the Government's overall Microeconomic policy reforms.

But of course achieving these objectives is only a means to an end. The Government's Fundamental Goals are greater and more equal opportunity, substantial improvements in living standards, an enhanced quality of life for the nation as a whole and care for our environment.
In seeking greater Industry Efficiency and Competitiveness we are seeking a better standard of Living for all.
Our long-term objectives can be grouped into three categories:
Enhancing productive capacity;
Developing a more responsive industry structure; and
Influencing and responding to the external environment.

Fundamental to enhancing our productive capacity is the protection of our natural resource base. The Government aims to manage our natural resources in a way that allows conservation together with sustainable development. We will provide funding of more than $47 million over the next three years for soil conservation and salinity mitigation within a co-ordinated natural resource management policy that will also include water management and reafforestation.

A national resource information centre will be established to ensure that an adequate knowledge base on the extent, status and nature of our natural, mineral and energy resources is developed. Just as important is the development of our human resources. Additional funds will be provided to develop rural education and training initiatives and to improve the access of rural and remote communities to these services.

Over $1 million will be spent to make non-metropolitan Australians as aware as their urban counterparts of Government services and programs. rural counselling and rural women's access grants will continue to improve the provision of information and advice. Research and development will be given even higher priority than before. An additional $10 million in all will be spent in coming years on research into alternative transport fuels and on renewable energy and conservation projects.

Both government and industry contributions to rural research will be increased towards the funding goal for each of 0.5 per cent of gross value of production in agricultural industries. A further aspect of the protection of our resources is the spending of $33 million as the Government's share to see the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication program through to completion. We will seek industry support for a jointly funded exotic disease preparedness program. Quarantine policies will be reformed in the light of the Lindsay report.

Developing a more responsive industry structure-my second set of objectives-is critical to improving our national economic performance. Specific action has been taken to encourage more responsiveness in a number of primary industries which have been more highly assisted than both other primary industries and industries in other sectors.

This matches the action taken to reduce tariffs in the manufacturing sector. It is part of a fundamental shift towards a lower and more uniform pattern of industry assistance. Supplementary market support for milk will be reduced. The butter and butter oil levy rates will be phased out by 1 July 1989. The present specific duty rate on tobacco leaf imports will be converted to an ad valorem tariff of 25 per cent and reduced to 15 per cent by 1 July 1992.
The sugar embargo will be replaced by an ad valorem tariff of 25 per cent on refined sugar and 35 per cent on raw sugar, which will be reduced to 15 per cent by 1 July 1992.
Tariffs on citrus and dried vine fruit will be phased down to 15 per cent by 1 July 1992.
These assistance reductions together with those in other sectors will benefit consumers and industries which use those goods as inputs.

It is estimated that the reductions in manufacturing protection will increase returns in the agricultural sector by about $350 million, and by about the same amount in the mining and minerals processing sector.

To further reduce costs on input prices the Government is disposed to grant duty-free entry on agricultural and mining equipment and parts not made in Australia. It will finalise its decision after the Industries Assistance Commission completes its report on this issue on 30 June 1988.

While every effort is made to minimise input prices it is inconsistent with our broad economic approach to do this through subsidies, which distort a range of investment and production decisions. The agricultural fertiliser subsidies will therefore be abolished on 30 June 1988.
The pricing of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) is now being reviewed and a decision is expected to be taken in July this year.

The agricultural price underwriting schemes for certain commodities can delay adjustment to market changes at considerable cost. Existing schemes will be reformed to ensure that the underwritten price deals only with extraordinary downwards price movements and that the industry concerned assumes increasing responsibility for meeting the costs of reducing price uncertainty.
The net effect of all these changes will be primary industries which are considerably more responsive to market changes.
As well as the benefits this will generate for these industries themselves, enhanced price responsiveness will open up a whole range of new opportunities throughout the economy.

New activities and new investments will appear where previously they were not worthwhile. This is likely to generate new opportunities in value-adding to our primary commodities in particular, thereby improving the links between the primary industry and manufacturing sectors.
A tax-linked income equalisation deposits scheme will be introduced from 1 July 1989. This subsidy is to encourage farmers to provide for income fluctuations.

Implicit in these initiatives is considerable change. The Government is sensitive to the costs associated with change and is acting to ensure that the burden of change does not become unduly high for those who are most affected.
A chief device for both encouraging change and ensuring that its cost is shared equitably in agriculture is the Rural Adjustment Scheme (RAS).
The RAS will be reformed to improve its effectiveness in structural adjustment. Its objectives will be more precisely defined and the range of policy instruments available will be widened.
Further, increased funding will be provided for RAS, including means tested rehabilitation grants of up to $28,000 to farmers leaving agriculture.
Similarly, action is being taken to assist the coal industry which presently is also subject to very considerable adjustment pressures.

$20 million is being provided on a dollar-for-dollar basis with the New South Wales government for reduced coal freight rates to assist in bringing forward rail freight reductions in the coal industry.
Retraining and re-establishment grants are being provided for retrenched coal miners under the Relocation Assistance Scheme and the labour adjustment training arrangements.

A long-term coal industry strategy announced on 5 May 1988 includes strengthened administration of export controls, contributions to coal promotion and establishment of an Australian coal industry development council.

My final set of objectives relate to the external marketing and trading environment. We will continue our efforts to bring home to overseas countries the damage their domestic policies do to us and to themselves when they subsidise their industries and limit market access.
Australia has a high profile in world forums-partly but not only through its prominent role in the Cairns group of agricultural fair traders.

A successful outcome to the Uruguay round of multilateral trade negotiations is vital to the continued growth and prosperity of the world economy. For this to occur it will be necessary for all participants to be prepared to review and reform their domestic industry policies.
In implementing the measures I have just outlined, Australia will show its bona fides in the negotiations.

Early results from the negotiations can be achieved in December this year if sufficient will exists. The measures we will implement will be a significant contribution to the agricultural liberalisation package which we wish to see agreed in December this year.

To provide positive assistance, the Government will fund a $5 million series of courses in international primary industry marketing skills, and introduce a coal marketing program. Wool promotion funding will continue but at a reduced level of $25 million over each of the next three years.

The government also contributes to our marketing effort through its provision of export inspection services. Since industry is the main beneficiary of these services, the Government will reduce its contribution from 50 per cent to 40 per cent. At the same time, however, it is improving efficiency and reducing costs through initiatives such as fee-for-service charging and approved quality assurance arrangements.

Perhaps most importantly, the government believes that industries' marketing and export efforts will be improved by the development of more dynamic and outward looking attitudes within those industries themselves.

The Government will work in partnership with industry, determined to be lean and flexible, to be ready for future opportunities as they arise, and to contribute more than ever to the welfare of all Australians. I move:

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.
Debate (on motion by Senator Lewis) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 May, on motion by Senator Tate:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is now debating the Cash Transaction Reports Bill 1987. Honourable senators will recall that it was referred to a committee of the Senate for consideration and report. That report has now been put down and the Government is now proceeding with the Bill. The primary object of the Bill is to facilitate the administration and enforcement of taxation laws. It is further intended to counter the underground cash economy and money laundering. The Bill obliges financial institutions and other bodies to report most transactions involving cash in excess of $10,000 and establishes the Cash Transaction Reports Agency. Moreover, transactions involving the transfer of large amounts of currency either into or out of Australia will also need to be reported. The proposed legislation reflects the concerns of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and other royal commissions about current difficulties in `following the money trail' generated by the profits of crime and is modelled on the United States Bank Secrecy Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill is a refinement of an earlier Bill that passed through the House of Representatives shortly before Parliament was dissolved for the 1987 general election. The Bill establishes the Cash Transaction Reports Agency with functions to receive and monitor reports, to ensure compliance with legislation and to provide advice and assistance to the Commissioner of Taxation in relation to cash transaction reports information.

The major reporting requirements are as follows: `Cash dealers' are required to report cash transactions involving the transfer of currency in excess of $10,000. `Cash dealers' are defined to include financial institutions, insurers, securities dealers, futures brokers, unit trusts, dealers in traveller's cheques and bullion, bookmakers and casino operators. Provision is also made for such transactions, when related to normal business activities, to be exempted.

Persons involved with transfer of currency in excess of $5,000 into or out of Australia are required to report the transaction. There are exemptions for commercial carriers such as airlines and shipping lines. Cash dealers are required to report suspect transactions relating to: tax evasion; investigation of crime; and enforcement of the Proceeds of Crime Act. Dealers are given immunity from defamation proceedings and protection against prosecution for money laundering.

The other major provision is the requirement for verification of the identity of persons with access to accounts over $1,000 and safety deposit boxes. The onus of verification is on the client-not the financial institution. Unverified accounts are blocked with the consequence that funds cannot be withdrawn and are liable to forfeiture after three months notice. There are elaborate provisions to ensure privacy and secrecy of information contained in reports with rights of access limited to the taxation officers and law enforcement agencies. Differences from the earlier Bill are: no requirement for verification of pre-existing accounts; a revised system for verification of accounts; small accounts are exempted; the creation of an offence of opening or operating an account in a false name; and the requirement to report suspect transactions.

The coalition parties have had widespread discussions with the Australian Bankers Association, the Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies and the Australian Federation of Credit Unions. In each case they support the Bill in principle as an anti-crime measure. However, there has been widespread concern within the community about the burden of costs that the Bill might impose and some disquiet about privacy. Because of these concerns, on 15 December I moved, and the Senate resolved, that the Bill be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for inquiry and report. That report was tabled on 28 April and recommended that:

the operation of the . . . Bill . . . be reviewed after a suitable period of time, preferably not longer than 3 years, and that the review include the economic, taxation, privacy and law enforcement implications of the Bill.
It also recommended that certain technical amendments be made. The Committee also referred to the concerns of firms engaged in armoured vehicle cash carrying operations.

I am pleased to note that the Government intends to accept the recommendations of the Committee and address the problem of cash carrying operations in the committee stage of the Bill. The report of the Committee vindicates the coalition decision to refer the Bill to a committee and reveals a number of problems that had not been previously properly explored. The Committee received over 50 submissions, and I am pleased that the Government acknowledges that its consideration of the Bill has been greatly enhanced by the views put to the Committee. This Government should learn a valuable lesson from this exercise; that is, that it is essential that there is adequate consultation and time for debate before the introduction of such complex legislation, and the Government should learn not to attempt to push through such legislation in the dying days of a parliamentary session. That lesson is clearly to be well learned at this stage of this parliamentary session. Even with this extensive consultation it is clear that it is not possible to determine the full financial impact and cost effectiveness of these proposals, and quite properly this is reflected in the Committee's recommendation that the operation of the Bill be reviewed in three years to assess the economic, privacy and law enforcement implications.

The area of organised crime and its financing were highlighted by both the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking and the Costigan Royal Commission. Mr Costigan in delivering the Sir John Barry Memorial Lecture on 13 October, 1983 stated, `the most successful method of identifying and ultimately convicting major organised criminals is to follow the money trail'. That is the main purpose of this Bill. The Committee heard extensive evidence about the burdens of compliance costs but concluded that the extra costs associated with implementing the provisions of the Bill are not likely to be substantial. This conclusion was reached on the basis of the estimates supported by quantitative analysis that have been presented to it. I think that there are people with concerns about this Bill who forget that it deals with cash transactions and I ask them: When was the last time they had a transaction involving $10,000 or more in cash? I cannot recall one for myself, but those sorts of transactions will have to be reported under this Bill.

The Opposition is not opposing the Bill because, however imperfect and uncertain the legislation may be, it does attempt to address the difficulties in tracing funds through a number of companies, banks and merchant banks, solicitors' trust accounts, property investment, overseas institutions and other methods used to disguise the illicit source of funds, or in the contemporary terms, the laundering of money and the underground cash economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Cash Transaction Reports Bill has been described by the Government as a major weapon against tax avoidance and organised crime. In view of the growing problem of crime in this country it is something which I am plainly aware of as a member of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority-this has to be seen as a very important and worthy objective. It is certainly an objective which is fully supported by the Australian Democrats, as we have shown time and time again by our support for legislative measures introduced by this Government. In particular the Democrats are very much aware of the types of points raised by Senator Lewis, the problems posed by money laundering and the urgent need where possible to follow the money trail. This method has been supported by a number of authorities as an extremely important way of combating organised crime. It is, therefore, very disappointing that the Government has introduced a Bill which will fail to meet the objectives stated for it. In addition, it will give rise to serious concerns in other areas.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to look at the Bill itself. Let me deal with the main purposes of the legislation. The first is to require the reporting of certain domestic currency transactions in excess of $10,000 to the Cash Transaction Reports Agency (CTRA). The second is to establish a Cash Transaction Reports Agency to collect, retain, compile analyse and disseminate information relating to cash transactions reports (CTR), suspect transactions, accounts with cash dealers and to perform other functions set out under the legislation. The reporting to the CTRA of certain currency transfers to and from Australia in excess of $5,000 is required. That is the third purpose. Fourthly, it requires cash dealers to report suspect transactions. Fifthly, it imposes obligations on cash dealers in relation to the verification of identification of persons seeking to open accounts and to block withdrawals by unverified signatories to accounts which exceed certain credit or deposit limits. Lastly, it creates an offence of opening or operating a bank account with a cash dealer in a false name.

As honourable senators are well aware, this Bill is a revised version of an earlier Bill by the same title which was withdrawn after strong opposition from a variety of sources, including financial institutions. The financial institutions were concerned in their submissions about the reporting and administrative burden which the bank's submission, for example, claimed to be some $180m in start-up costs and a further $75m a year.

The major change between the two Bills centres on the shift in the administrative burden in executing the reporting functions of the Bill. Under the original Bill, the banks were required to bear responsibility for ensuring the identity of all of their account holders and to report all transactions in excess of $10,000 to the Cash Transaction Reports Agency which, in turn, would then supply that information to the Australian Taxation Office, the Australian Customs Service, the National Crime Authority and the Federal and State police. Under the new Bill, all customers who establish accounts after the Bill is proclaimed and whose cash balances exceed the limits set above must, within 24 hours, present proof of identity or they will not be able to withdraw money from their accounts. Cash dealers commit an offence if they have not made:
reasonable efforts on or before that day to obtain a verification statement from the unverified signatory.

Exactly what constitutes a reasonable effort is not defined in the legislation. The verification process involves the custom of providing to a cash dealer a reference from someone who specifies that he has known the person, and that reference must, in turn, be verified by a justice of the peace under the Statutory Declarations Act. The Cash Transaction Reports Bill will, of course, not be restricted to banking transactions in excess of $10,000 and involving banks and corporations; it will go beyond that to brokers, bookmakers, unit trust managers, bullion dealers and so on. A very large group of people deal in that way. It will apply to all accounts opened before and after the proclamation of the Bill with regard to those exercises. However, under clause 14, cash dealers who suspect account holders of engaging in illegal activities can report those transactions to the CTRA, even though they fall below the $10,000 limit.

The Cash Transaction Reports Bill provides for the Agency to furnish information of transactions to the Taxation Office, the Australian Customs Service and so on. Exemptions will be granted to businesses that engage in frequent large cash transactions for payroll purposes, for example. Those firms will be listed in an exempt register which can be inspected by the CTRA. In addition to that, the Government has introduced amendments designed to meet concerns raised by cash carriers, and those items will be dealt with in the committee stage. I do not intend going into them at the moment.

When one looks at the new Bill structure and compares it to the Bill referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for examination, it is very difficult to see any major improvements. The wide range of exempt transactions still apply and provide ample scope for criminal avoidance. The fact that no existing accounts will be affected also undermines the stated purpose of the Bill. The provision requiring new account holders to furnish a reference is absurd and will create major problems for the less capable in our society. It is entirely open to manipulation. The Government, of course, has not retreated from its decision to refuse citizens the right to redress against administrative malpractice under the judicial review. I wish to take up that matter in the committee stage because it is an extraordinary proposition.

It is an outrageous proposition that, yet again, we are asked by the Government to have no review in those areas where administrative malpractice can be massively damaging to the individual. It has been expressly written out of the Act. When the committee stage is reached, I want to look at a number of those clauses, particularly with regard to the Director of the CTRA and others. Why this Government persists in writing out references with regard to administrative malpractice I have no idea, but the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has to draw this to the attention of the Senate time and again. Unfortunately, the Senate has acquiesced far too often in allowing the Government to run roughshod over this area time and again, as is done in this Bill.

In cases where some bank branches have been more or less happy to accept cash deposits from clients who they suspect are engaging in questionable or probably criminal activity in order to generate additional cash balances, the Bill will probably be effective. However, beyond fines, there is no provision for the Government to ensure that the banks are complying. If one looks at the fines, one realises that there should not be much problem for the banks one way or the other. It is reasonable to anticipate that the most likely response of criminal figures will be to use the array of exemption categories that exists under the Bill in combination with the continued use of false identities to gain access to financial institutions.

I do not want to detail one system detailed to me, but there are relatively simple ways of driving right through this Bill. In some ways it probably mirrors the notion in some avenues of government that crime and criminals remain stupid. I hoped that that attitude had disappeared a long time ago but, obviously, it has not. Another way is to move more money laundering operations into fringe money institutions that will not respect the reporting operations and will be very difficult to track down, even under this complicated and expensive arrangement. An important factor is that false identities remain a major problem, and that has not been addressed by this Bill.

An additional concern of the Australian Democrats is that the threshold is only $10,000 which, because it is not indexed against inflation, means that within a number of years it will be virtually impossible to make even a relatively small transaction without that transaction being reported to the CTRA and relayed to the additional authorities. I can give an example of this: in five years, assuming the present inflation level of 8 per cent per annum, inflation would have reduced the effective or real threshold of the present limit to $6,061 and in 8 years to $4,719. As honourable senators know, the ability of this chamber to update any of those is woeful, and they are likely to remain. The Australian Bankers Association (ABA) is reported to have expressed concern that the United States Administration will possibly move the United States threshold which is currently $10,000 to $3,000. As demonstrated above, it is not necessary for the Australian Government to formally lower the limit. Yet again, without any fuss or bother, inflation will accomplish this particular objective over time. This is an interesting example of the bureaucracy again snowing the Government, because here the bureaucracy has the built-in incentive to gain more and more access to more and more transactions of individuals in this country, individuals who are not connected with crime and whose affairs are effectively scrutinised by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO).

The ABA has estimated that about 200,000 transactions will be affected by the threshold of $10,000, and one can reasonably expect that this figure will increase considerably as future movements in the consumer price index drag more and more transactions across that threshold. This has been seen in the area of tax and so many areas of government. It is relatively simple to avoid, but the Government chooses deliberately not to introduce that inflation mechanism with regard to the amount. The reason is simple and clear.

On 12 June 1986 the Assistant Secretary of the United States Treasury Enforcement Task Force, Francis Keating, testified before a United States Senate Committee that the American equivalent of the CTRA, had in the space of three years, enabled the United States Treasury to initiate legal proceedings against 8,649 individuals. Keating also testified that of those 8,649 individuals, 4.971, or about 60 per cent, were not convicted. Therefore, it is possible that a sizeable number of those who were not convicted were innocent of any wrongdoing. In this respect I wish to be realistic because obviously a proportion of that 60 per cent could well have escaped conviction through the process of legal technicalities. Nevertheless, well over half of the people were harried by the Government because they carried out a number of apparently legal transactions which, when superimposed upon additional financial data, triggered investigation and indictment.

For some of those reasons the Democrats are extremely unhappy about the establishment of this authority, the main objective of which is to keep tabs on how people earn and spend their money. Although the ATO has the power to carry out investigations that enable it to reconstruct people's transactions and their habits of spending, this sort of investigation is usually not initiated until a reasonable ground for suspicion exists. This Bill completely reverses this situation: no suspicion is required for this type of investigation to proceed in this country, and we have now heard that the Opposition will be supporting this exercise.

If one reads the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, one discovers that in all of the matters that I have raised, the Committee's report is inconclusive. If the evidence on fighting crime is inconclusive, this legislation should not be passed. Rather than passing a clearly defective piece of legislation and giving it a three-year trial run, the legislation should be opposed and the Government should be asked to return with a re-written Bill that does not suffer from the types of defects that I have been outlining.

In conclusion, I should like to say a few words about how the Government should address the problems of money laundering and tax avoidance. Obviously, the first involves the issue of the tax file number. I do not intend to canvas that subject too much tonight. Earlier tonight the Government made a statement about the tax file number. In the elements of the economic statement there was no discussion about raising the integrity of the tax file number. Let us hope in future discussions and amplifications of the Government's statement tonight, the integrity of the tax file number will be debated rather than what the Government discussed tonight concerning merely the extended use of the tax file number.

I wish to deal with bank transactions and the tax file number. Obviously, one large area of tax avoidance in transactions between individuals and banks is that of interest earned on accounts. This can be dealt with relatively simply; that is, upon opening an account all problems of civil liberties can be avoided if an obligation is placed on the person who opens the account to notify the Tax Office. In other words, it should go the other way around. The Government and the Opposition are happy for the banks to know a person's tax file number now and presumably they will go down the line with the banks on a whole range of items. But there are other ways. Another way it ought to go is that an obligation should be placed on an individual to inform the Tax Office that he or she is opening an account and the number of the account, rather than the bank being notified of the person's tax file number. This mechanism can then be linked to a further mechanism.

The Democrats would strongly support the notion of a withholding tax on interest paid on all accounts. That matter is relatively simple and has extremely low administrative costs according to the discussions we have had with the Australian Bankers Association. Essentially it would work on the basis of the maximum level of personal income tax, which is currently set at 49c in the dollar of interest earned. That would be withheld and remitted to the Tax Office unless an individual had an exemption. If an individual had an exemption, he would have received it from the Tax Office-on the basis of what? Clearly, on the basis of the fact that in the past that person has had a good record of declaring interest earned on accounts, or that the person is a child, or is starting to earn money, or has a good taxation record and, for example, is a retiree living on interest as income. The proposition is relatively simple: automatically 49c in every dollar of interest earned would go.

What would happen then? If both items I have spoken about were in operation, every bank account would be linked to a tax account held by the Tax Office. But a group of accounts would be left over that are not linked to anything. That would be the first place that a tax task force would start investigations. A whole list of accounts would not attach to anyone paying tax and would not attach to anyone known to the Tax Office. One would do two things with that combination of items. Firstly, one would collect every dollar that should have been paid on interest, and more-because one would pick up every account that one did not know about-in other words, all the people who operate two, three, or four accounts in two, three or four different names who hold two, three or four jobs of which only one operates within the tax framework and the others are outside the tax framework. That means that every other taxpayer in the community must pay more. That is easily overcome.

I refer honourable senators to the fact that the withholding tax, which was first passed by the Fraser Administration in relation to the building industry and which was upgraded by the Hawke Government, has been one of the most effective taxes applied in recent years in overcoming fraud, and in overcoming the problem of who in the income earning system is operating outside the tax system. We believe that, in those situations where a whole series of accounts are not connected to any tax file if, upon reasonable inquiry, nothing turns up all those accounts should be frozen. I believe that they should be frozen until the people who actually hold them are able to show why it is that they are outside the tax system, why it is that they have failed to declare previous interest earned and why it is that they have been avoiding their legal obligations to the community.

We further believe that the National Crime Authority should certainly have the power to search tax files. At the moment, of course, it has power under its Act to go into tax files with regard to specific exercises. The Australian Taxation Office itself has the ability to engage in fishing expeditions. We would be happy to extend the range of operations of the National Crime Authority with regard to this area of tax.

When we take all these things together we find ourselves in a very difficult situation. The last time the Government introduced legislation with regard to an identification card it also brought in a couple of other Bills. One related to privacy legislation and a Data Protection Agency. What do we see in this Bill? Absolutely nothing. The Government has abandoned entirely the notion of protecting privacy and the data that it collects. However, we find again in the economic statement tonight that the Government will extend the use of the tax file number. Again, there was absolutely no comment about the reintroduction of privacy legislation or data protection.

So we have here the first step-the Opposition has expressed its willingness to support it-without any privacy or data protection. Yet last time round we heard loud cries from the Opposition. We have here an excessively flawed Bill, a Bill unaccompanied by any protections with regard to the information about to be collected, a Bill that will provide the basis for the extension of the identity card system, a Bill that will not work and upon which no evidence has been produced.

The Committee which looked at it said that it was inconclusive in combating crime within the community. Fairly obviously, this legislation does not provide us with any reason to want to trust bureaucracies with that extensive amount of information. We could be induced to do that if the Government had been genuine about the protection of privacy and had brought back a privacy Bill in conjunction with this piece of legislation, if the Government had improved the integrity of the tax file number or if the Government had been able to produce some evidence that these types of excessively costly and intrusive arrangements into individuals' operations in the community would be successful in inhibiting crime and, hopefully, bringing criminals who operate in this area to justice.

None of that has been presented to the chamber and none of that was presented to the Committee. We are operating with a complete leap of faith and the Government is saying, `Just follow us with regard to all these things. This is perfectly all right. Nothing will happen. Let us give it a trial'. I remind honourable senators that the idea of giving it a trial is one which really does not have a great deal of force.

The reasons, fairly obviously, are that once these things are established and operating they become self-fulfilling prophesies, they have a reason to extend their own lives and they are able to present a rationale as to why they should extend their own lives. Anybody who has any notion of these types of organisations would know that after three years they just do not go out of existence. In fact, it would be a very bold Opposition that, at that stage, would seek to destroy these types of organisations because, fairly obviously, as in the United States of America, a government would be able to present a whole range of convictions. Of course, it would not know whether they were new or old convictions or convictions that would have been obtained in any event through the operation of the Tax Office, the National Crime Authority or any of the other agencies that had the power to operate upon this information. There will be a backup; the old boys network will be operating. Chums do not trust chums as we learned this week from Yes, Minister, and undoubtedly it will operate again in this area.

Quite frankly, the notion of a trial period is absurd. Let me be very clear about the fact that, when we pass this legislation, it will be entrenched. We are not giving it a trial; in fact, we are establishing it and it will be around in this Parliament and in successive parliaments. It would be a nice thought if we went into the exercise of trialling things. I do not see this chamber, and certainly not the other place, giving any indication that they want to go down the track of a trialling operation in any genuine way. Indeed, later tonight, if we manage to get to other legislation, we can see this operating in another area. The upshot of all this is that the Government has failed to deal adequately with one of the most serious problems facing this country and the Democrats have no option other than to oppose this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Cash Transaction Reports Bill 1987 has already had a tortuous passage through the Parliament and I think it was quite properly referred by this chamber to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. That Committee took the opportunity to consider it carefully, to call a body of evidence and to attempt as best it could to analyse the likely ramifications of it. I find it very difficult in many spheres to make judgments about the future. I think one could say in this instance that the best that one could do is weigh up the matter on the balance of probabilities.

SPEECH.PARA: One simply cannot make bald statements that somehow all cash transactions will be significantly reduced, that the underground economy will largely evaporate and that organised crime will simply go offshore. But one can have a measured degree of confidence that this type of legislation will make it harder for those who have prospered to date to continue to undertake very large cash transactions. I find that a healthy approach. I always have suspicions when I see or hear of people who carry very fat wallets. I recall one instance where $10,000 was carried in the boot of a car of a supposedly prominent Melbourne solicitor not so many years ago. I would have thought that, in a situation like that--

TALK.START.PARA: —A prominent racing identity.

—That is right. It is always a matter of just having driven back from the racecourse. I think in this instance the gentleman in question was just on his way back from the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, where he had been representing some luminary. I would have thought that, in situations like that, there was a burden of proof to be discharged by persons who chose to carry around bags full of dollars.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it passing strange, therefore, that with that sort of charitable inclination towards attempting to stamp out the cash economy and the methods of organised crime in dealing with large sums of ill gotten gains, the Australian Democrats should take the stance that they have. Their first argument essentially seemed to be that it is just more bureaucracy and we cannot be sure of the result. That is a small government ethos which a number of us in this chamber regard as perfectly proper but it is not one that we often hear fall from the lips of the Democrats. Their second principal objection seemed to be that it would offend notions of privacy, that somehow it was in breach of civil liberties and that this was all thoroughly undesirable. It is of interest to note that Senator Powell, who was on the Committee in question, is not listed to speak in this debate; whereas Senator Macklin, who was not on the Committee and did not have the opportunity to listen to some of the vacuous nonsense that was served up by some of the proponents of privacy, is prepared to get up and make the sorts of sweeping statements that he has made.

To couple that with a suggestion that the National Crime Authority (NCA) should have limited fishing rights, presumably to go off and start investigating anyone who looks as though he has managed to obtain a fairly substantial degree of wealth over a short time, strikes me as a very chilling prospect. No doubt, if one took the money trail at its face value one could very easily mount a case that almost all of those in the top 100 listed in the Business Review Weekly should be automatically investigated on an annual basis and that surely the NCA would not be doing its job if it was not knocking on Mr Bond's door or Mr Packer's back garage and wanting to know where they got all the funds from. That is a thoroughly undesirable approach to take. If one has any concerns for civil liberties, the last thing one should do is give licence to roam to any outfit-not, in particular, the NCA, but a whole range of bodies that would be anxious to garner such broad-ranging powers.

Therefore, I think it is rather odd when we look at the charitable approach that is being taken by the Government and the Opposition to this legislation and set it against the rather mean-spirited approach taken by the Democrats. One can only assume that somehow they see some political mileage in being able to claim that this could not possibly work, that it is not really going to achieve anything and that it is not worth giving it the benefit of the doubt. It is fair to say that we have all agonised honourably over the merits and demerits of this legislation. But the fact remains that there is a mischief that can be identified. There is a possible solution that can be adopted. I believe that the structure of the Bill has more benefits than defects.

Admittedly, the United States experience is about the only precedent that one has to go on, but I do not find it disheartening to look at the statistics that are regularly paraded in support of the establishment of a similar regime in this country. Mr Keating, whom Senator Macklin referred to and who was the then Assistant Secretary of the Treasury enforcement section, said that the Bank Secrecy Act has proved beyond all doubt its effectiveness as a law enforcement tool against drug trafficking, organised crime and the illicit financial activity that supports it. They are all honourable motives. We would be delighted if we could say at the end of the day that the Cash Transaction Reports Agency had had similar success. The figures that he cited were that in approximately three years of full operation these task forces have initiated 1,350 cases and resulted in the indictment of 8,649 individuals, 3,678 of whom have been convicted.

I do not find those results particularly disappointing. I recall Mick Miller, who is a very well regarded former Chief Commissioner of Police in Victoria, saying that he had some doubts about whether we should maintain the system of jury trials in this country because somehow the police were able to achieve only a 50 per cent success rate. I think that is a fairly healthy hit rate. It does not mean that juries regarded all of the other 50 per cent as thoroughly innocent and undeserving of ever having been prosecuted and able to make claims for malicious prosecution. It simply means that convictions are secured against only approximately half those on trial.

Similarly, here I would have thought that even those who were acquitted, who may well have had a decent case to answer, serve a very valuable demonstration purpose to the rest of the community. As long as they are not frivolous prosecutions-and I assume good faith on the part of the law enforcement agency in the United States, as I would make similar assumptions here-those sorts of prosecutions and pursuits play a very valuable role in undermining the community view that a person should not be entitled to engage in illegal activities, to launder large sums of cash and money with impugnity. I hope that the Cash Transaction Reports Agency will be as diligent as the United States agency seems to have been.

So, I think one can say that the motives of those who support this legislation are honourable, that there are some real causes for concern in the wider community and that, even if the net effect is simply to make these current transactions more difficult, less visible and more risky for those who participate in them, that is a worthwhile achievement in itself. Convictions are a rather blunt instrument for measuring success rates. I think we can say that the objects of the Bill are laudable.

When it comes to the scheme, there are two distinct reporting schemes in relation to which certain obligations will be imposed on cash dealers. Under the first scheme, cash dealers will be required to report certain cash transactions in excess of a specified sum. Sure, in the United States the figure is about $US10,000, which is obviously somewhat higher than it is here, but marginally so. The comment that somehow in 10 years time the value will be less in real terms if there is no indexing is a rather trite point at best. It is not particularly valid. It ignores the recommendation of the Senate Committee that there be a three-year review. It ignores the overwhelming likelihood that members of a government intent on maintaining its credibility in the area would not simply--

TALK.START.PARA: —They have never done so in other legislation; you know that.
—Be it upon their heads if they do not. If they are stupid enough to allow such legislation to fall into disuse--
—This chamber is supposed to review legislation, not the Government.

—If the honourable senator wants to proceed on the basis that everyone has the same obtuse approach to this legislation as he does, if he wants to ignore the recommendation of the Committee, which included a colleague of his, that there should be a review in three years time, and if he wants to assume that somehow the Government is intent on a window-dressing exercise that will, over a period, become progressively less effective, then he can make those assumptions; but they seem to me to be not rationally based. They are designed to fit his preconceived prejudices that somehow this is a massive intrusion into civil liberties--
—What about inflation? That is what you are talking about.

—Precisely. It is not very difficult to keep pace with inflation if one is minded to do so. It is certainly not a very difficult task simply to increase the limit after a period of three years, as we would assume would follow from any significant review.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not have any difficulty with $10,000 as a limit. I do not come across too many people carrying around those sums of money as things stand at present. Senator Macklin may well have many friends who he thinks deserve to be protected from the consequences of that sort of behaviour, but it seems to me that people in that situation should have to justify themselves. That is what the Bill sets out to do. The Bill sets out a regime for requiring reporting, for requiring monitoring and for the reporting of suspect transactions on the part of financial institutions and other authorities. I regard that as desirable, just as I regard the verification procedures for new accounts as thoroughly desirable, although the limit of $1,000 may be a little on the low side. Nonetheless, I think none of us rejoiced when we saw how easy it was for Norm Gallagher to open up accounts with impugnity. Certainly, there is a good case to be made for making it more difficult for people who choose to open a variety of accounts in different names for no good reason. There may well be explanations for that sort of behaviour; but, by and large, it is normally done for tax avoidance and evasion purposes.

One matter I found of particular interest was an appearance before the Committee by the Law Council of Australia. It probably has got Senator Macklin in because its members worked themselves into a lather about the requirement that a cash dealer who has reasonable grounds to suspect that information the cash dealer has concerning the transaction may be relevant to investigation of an evasion or an attempted evasion, or to an investigation or prosecution, or may be of assistance to the enforcement of the Proceeds of Crime Act, should report as soon as practicable after forming the suspicion. The Council trotted out the line that somehow one could never be sure whether one had reasonable grounds for suspicion, as though Donoghue v. Stevenson had never been decided, as though the notion of reasonableness was alien to the common law and as though somehow every right-thinking citizen was going to be agonising over whether he fell on the right side of the reasonable doubt line. I regarded that as a load of nonsense. I was particularly unimpressed by the feeble efforts to prosecute the argument before the Committee. It may well be that it has appealed to the Australian Democrats. I do not see any legitimate basis for that type of concern.

The burden of compliance costs is another grey area. It is very difficult to make any sensible judgment. It is regrettable that the Business Regulation Review Unit was not asked to do some sensible work in the area and, as a result, we got a vast range of fairly back-of-the-envelope estimates by a number of institutions-banks, building societies and the like. At the end of the day I think the most important factor was that banks and others did not particularly object-obviously because they will pass on the cost, but also because they regarded it as a safety measure for their own protection. In other words, they do not like the publicity accusing them of being in league with tax cheats and those other propagators of the underground economy. They often find it difficult to justify the need for verification procedures to little old ladies who might have found $1,000 in the gutter and who want to open a new account. It is much easier for them to say that the law henceforth requires it. I think that is a perfectly legitimate approach for the banks to take. It does not seem that the costs will be inordinate. We are probably talking about $2m or $3m a year. If we are not, in due course no doubt the squeals will be heard and that can be taken into account when the review takes place. Whilst the evidence on compliance costs was fairly fuzzy, ultimately if one attempts to make a social cost benefit analysis one can say that the benefits outweigh the detriments.

There are several other matters of concern. One matter of particular concern to me was the likelihood of wholesale exemptions, or, alternatively, wholesale recording. In other words, there is an option as to whether a financial institution should seek the consent of the other party to the transaction who is then required to assert, by way of statutory declaration, that the matter is worthy of exemption. Those matters can then be entered on the financial institution's register and ultimately communicated to the Agency. Because that is optional it leaves open the prospect of financial institutions simply saying that it is not worth the effort, that they will simply report every transaction that comes within the limits and about which they believe there might be reasonable grounds for suspicion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that is a problem.

—Yes. One has to assume an element of bad faith on the part of the institutions. I do not presently see that emerging, because there was not a great reluctance on the part of banks and others to embrace the legislation. Therefore, it is unlikely that they would want to sabotage it in that manner. It is one of those risks that one has to take. I would be interested to hear the explanation of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) as to why there were not more mandatory requirements in the area. Certainly, the Committee found it difficult to understand why there was such a large element of discretion.

SPEECH.PARA: In the United States there have been a number of complaints of excess reporting-blanket reporting, as it is called. Again, that is a matter that will have to be very carefully reviewed at the expiration of the three-year period. There was also concern that the transactions of greatest interest would be those most likely to be built within class exemptions and therefore difficult to identify. There is also the possibility of the capture of presently legitimate organisations-building societies, credit unions and the like-by organised crime and undesirable elements so that they were then able to manipulate the legislation to, in effect, fiddle the books and to not report those matters which they were clearly aware were otherwise properly characterised as illegal transactions. Again, that is a bit of a scare scenario. It is certainly a possibility, but it is highly unlikely. There are a number of prudential and other safeguards that operate on building societies and credit unions that would make such capture very difficult. Nonetheless, I think the authorities would need to be vigilant to ensure that that sort of behaviour did not take place.

The National Crime Authority is also worried about loopholes-in particular, `smurfing', which we all found a cute way of describing those transactions which individually would be just below the limit but collectively would exceed it. It was judged that clause 29 hopefully would be sufficient to meet those concerns. That clause makes it an offence to structure or conduct transactions in such a way as to avoid the reporting requirements. The most likely way of such a stratagem coming to light would be as a result of an investigation by the Australian Taxation Office which could then go over the transactions with a fine toothcomb. Reference to bank statements and the like would mean that it would not be too difficult a task to demonstrate that this has been a calculated scheme to ensure that each of the transactions was singularly below the limit.

I have covered my areas of concern. I repeat that there is an element of a leap of faith in all of this. We do have legitimate worries. They are ones that hopefully can be better resolved after we have been prepared to give it a fair go. All in all, I support any moves that are aimed at and have a legitimate prospect of achieving a reduction in the growth of organised crime and the spread of illegal transactions. This legislation goes a considerable way to making life more difficult for those who are intent on those sorts of activities. With those caveats, as a member of the Committee, I am prepared to give it a go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I speak on the Cash Transaction Reports Bill 1987 I make the confession that I am a director of a major financial organisation. Financial organisations are substantially affected by this Bill. I hasten to say that nothing that I am putting forward today will have any direct personal financial effect on me. One must face up to the fact that we have serious problems with money handling, organised crime and tax evasion. Our present arrangements are not adequately dealing with them. Whether this Bill will effectively deal with them remains to be seen. As other senators have said, the only precedence we have is the rather ambiguous one from the United States. Nevertheless, the problems are so serious that we must try any reasonable measures to deal with them. This Bill seems to me-with some exceptions that I will come to in a moment-to be a reasonable way to tackle the problem. It is important that it should be kept under review. If it is not working properly it must be amended, or if it does not work at all it must be repealed. I am prepared, as other Opposition senators are, to give this new measure a fair trial.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of points to be made about the Bill. The first is that it was not referred to the Business Regulation Review Unit (BRRU). The reason given for that was rather bizarre. The Attorney-General's Department advised the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs that the Bill was essentially a taxation and law enforcement measure and not within the provisions under which the Government would normally seek a report from the BRRU before Cabinet consideration. That may be the way in which the reference instructions are written; if so, they are very foolish instructions. This has major implications for financial institutions and in my view it most certainly should have been considered by the Business Regulation Review Unit before it was put into force. If it had been considered by that organisation I am sure substantial changes would have been made.

The real problem with this Bill is that it is a legal and law enforcement Bill and has paid very little attention to the problems of the financial institutions which are directly affected by it. I am sure that with a little more cooperation, commonsense and involvement by the financial institutions in the drafting of the Bill we would have been able to get a Bill of equal effectiveness with greatly reduced onerous provisions for the financial institutions.

There are very real problems for financial institutions. I would like to focus on one in particular; that is, the account opening procedures. This Bill was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I think it would be fair to say that that Committee has little financial institution expertise. In its report it said:
On the evidence before it-
that is, the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee-

it appears to the Committee that the identification procedures set out in the Bill are adequate. At the same time, the Committee is concerned that those procedures will be onerous for both cash dealers and their customers.
The Committee has concluded that at this time the identification procedures can be left in place but it draws attention to its recommendations for review . . .

Although the Committee recommended a review, that might be a review in not less than three years and by that stage some very great difficulties might have appeared for financial institutions. To give an example, I have a letter which I have received on the subject from the Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies. It says that the main concerns are the proposed account opening procedures. It goes on to say:

These procedures will expand the time taken for account openings and cause customer inconvenience and costs not currently incurred. The legislation introduces a bureaucratic reporting process to and from the Director of the Cash Transaction Reports Agency and an inflexible framework for the format of data storage which will be costly for all cash dealers to implement.
It goes on to state:

The whole financial system of Australia favours an alternative approach to account opening which gives flexibility and efficiency. We recommend that the legislation provide for the Director of the proposed Cash Transaction Reports Agency to determine by regulation, if need be, a `code of practice' for account openings to be followed by all cash dealers.

It recommends-and I agree with it-that instead of the provisions for identification being inflexibly put in the proposed Act, it should be done by regulation and be made more flexible and altered more easily. I wish the Senate Committee had examined that more carefully than it appears to have done because I think it has very real merits.

Despite that, one cannot deny that there are real problems in identification procedures at the moment. The $750,000 deposited perfectly legally by Mr Luigi Locarno on behalf of the Builders Labourers Federation is an example. One hears anecdotal tales-one I have bothered to verify-of accounts being opened with no difficulty at all by people in the name of Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck. Banks accept savings bank deposits in such accounts with no identification required. I will not name the banks but I could if challenged. Quite clearly, that has to be tackled. The question is whether the inflexible procedures of putting identification requirements in the Act is the right way to handle what is, by common consent, novel legislation. I believe that it should have been done by regulation, which can be modified much more quickly than an Act can be amended. The Committee also recommended that there be a review of the legislation. In its report it stated:

The Committee is of the opinion that the operation of legislation of this type-that is, novel legislation-should be reviewed after a suitable period of time. What is a suitable period of time will depend on the circumstances of each case . . .
In the case of the Cash Transaction Reports Bill, if it is enacted the Committee considers three years from its commencement to be a suitable period of time.

That might be appropriate for the basic thrust of the Bill because its effect on crime prevention and its effect on tax evasion will definitely not be clear for three years. But the problems which financial institutions have over identification and the costs involved will become clearer much earlier. I would like an assurance from the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) that if a report is given within six months or so of problems being encountered by financial institutions in dealing with this part of the Act and there are constructive suggestions on how the Act might be modified to make it as effective but less onerous on financial institutions, the Government will give sympathetic consideration to an early amendment to the Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Senate is debating the Cash Transaction Reports Bill 1987. As has been said, the Opposition supports the Bill. It is fair to say that it is a support not without some misgivings. As I said on the presentation of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs report on this Bill some little time ago, it is a difficult task to evaluate the benefits as against the deficits. It is very hard to weigh the benefits with any certainty and it is very difficult to weigh the costs. I will commence by trying to put this Bill in some historical context. I remind the Senate of a previous report some four years ago of the then Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs after an examination of the Government's proposed National Crime Authority Bill. The Committee made specific reference in that report to the lack of legislative tools in the fight against organised crime. A lack of appropriate offences existed at that time as well as an incapacity to effectively follow the money trail and insufficient capacity to seize proceeds of crime.

SPEECH.PARA: We were not the only ones to point out these legislative shortcomings. A number of royal commissioners had called for stronger measures to deal with the abuse of the facilities of financial and other institutions in relation to tax evasion and money laundering. With the assistance of the submission of the Attorney-General's Department to the Senate Committee inquiring into this Bill, I remind honourable senators that the Williams Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs in 1980 recommended that law enforcement agencies should pay increased attention to the financial aspect of the illegal importation, production and trafficking in drugs.
