I further remind honourable senators that the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking echoed the Williams Royal Commission's recommendation for laws aimed at confiscating the proceeds of crime. The Stewart Royal Commission and the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and special prosecutors Giles and Redlich all recommended that there be legislation preserving financial records so that law enforcement investigators could follow the money trail.

Even more recently, the National Crime Authority has highlighted the ease with which funds can be secreted by the use of false names. By and large, I think that it is fair to say that the Government has gone down the path of giving law enforcement bodies the capacity in legislative form to at least become competitive with organised crime. In our opinion it may not have been so generous in the provision of resources but at least there are now a number of Acts which have been passed by the Parliament and which give these bodies greater resources to meet the scourge of organised crime. Briefly, this is really the fourth of a series-the first being the Telecommunications Interception (Amendment) Act which extended existing interception powers which relate to certain narcotic offences to a wider range of serious offences and enable certain other law enforcement agencies in addition to the Australian Federal Police to seek interception warrants. There then followed the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act of 1987 which provides the legislative basis for Australia to enter into arrangements with other countries under which it can request and grant assistance relating to criminal investigation, prosecution and proceeds of crime. The third Act is the Proceeds of Crime Act. It provides for the freezing and confiscation of property used in and derived from the commission of an indictable offence. It creates a number of other offences, for example, the offence of money laundering, which is something that we have been urging for some time, and organised fraud. The Act requires financial institutions to preserve the money trail by restraining certain documents. This is something which had been specifically urged by the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and it gives police additional powers of access to such documents through production orders and search warrants. They are the three principal Bills that have been passed in recent times.

The fourth of those Bills is in fact the one that is before the Senate tonight-the Cash Transaction Reports Bill. This is another Bill which has as its principal responsibility providing greater capacity for enforcement agencies to combat organised crime. It does so through a number of means. First, it requires the reporting of certain domestic currency transactions in excess of $10,000 to the Cash Transaction Reports Agency. Secondly, it requires the reporting of certain currency transactions in excess of $5,000 to and from Australia. I remind you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that when I spoke a few days ago on the report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs I made specific mention of the fact that the Government's changes in allowing ease of transfer of funds to and from Australia have, in fact, facilitated organised crime, as has been evidenced in a number of recent reports. This, to some extent, will answer that concern.

This Bill, thirdly, requires cash dealers to report suspect transactions. This is something that we would prefer not to have been included in legislative form; but, as I will demonstrate in a few moments, it is something that seems, regrettably, to have become necessary. Fourthly, the legislation establishes a Cash Transaction Reports Agency to collect, retain, compile, analyse and disseminate information relating to cash transaction reports. The enforcement bodies have stressed in their submissions on this Bill that the whole effectiveness of this arrangement will depend on just how efficiently and promptly returns are in fact analysed and the information therefrom disseminated.

Fifthly, the Bill imposes obligations on cash dealers in relation to the verification of identity of persons seeking to open accounts. I concede what Senator Macklin said-the legislation relates to future accounts and not to existing accounts. One might say that that is a shortcoming. But in all these matters, one has to try to find a balance. We on this side believe that to be a fair balance. Lastly, the legislation will create an offence of opening or operating a bank account or similar account with a cash dealer in a false name. As has been demonstrated by my colleague, Senator Hamer, when he spoke on this matter, that has happened all too often. Now there will be a disincentive to engage in such a course of action, which amounts to an offence.

This Bill follows down much the same path as the United States Bank Secrecy Act. I also concede that there are differing views as to how successful that Act has been. Those in the United States who have the task of enforcing that legislation claim that it has been successful. But there are others in the financial industry who argue to the contrary. By accepting the compulsory concept, it then follows that we have rejected the United Kingdom and Canadian model of the provision of voluntary information. Certainly, on my analysis, it does not seem that the schemes in those countries have worked particularly well.

There is no doubt that this Bill infringes upon one's financial privacy. There is no doubt also that the legislation will impose a financial cost on the total community. I say `the total community' because we will all financially bear the cost. The cost to financial institutions and banks will, in fact, be passed on to us. There is a deficit side to this Bill and, therefore, it is important that the Bill not be enacted without careful consideration being given to it. In those circumstances, the Senate, in its wisdom, referred the Bill to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee for evaluation and report. As I indicated, the Senate Committee found that to be a difficult task, particularly on the cost side as evidenced by the number of conflicting submissions as to the likely financial and administrative costs. On balance, nevertheless, the Committee recommended that the Bill be enacted with the caution that it be reviewed preferably in three years time at the latest. The Committee reached that conclusion largely on the basis that it would only be after a period of practice that any accurate assessment could be made in respect of costs and deficits. The Committee, therefore, made that recommendation.

The Committee recommended that there should be a wide review-a review that would include the economic, taxation, privacy and law enforcement implications of the Bill. I hope that the Government has accepted the Committee's recommendation in that regard. I do not seem to have seen a Government reply to the Committee's report. I hope that when the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) winds up the second reading debate, he will be able to indicate that the Government has in fact accepted the Committee's recommendation. Certainly, as I indicated, on that basis my Party is prepared to accept the Committee's recommendation.

When one had the task of trying to balance both sides of this equation, I suppose that three examples that were put before the Committee weighed most heavily in my mind and forced me to come down on the side of this legislation being a necessary tool for law enforcement bodies. Two of those examples were put to the Committee by the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) and the other was put by the National Crime Authority. Briefly, I want to being them to the Senate's attention because I think they demonstrate in a very vivid way the abuses that have taken place within our community by the use of cash dealings in organised crime. The first one was a matter that concerned an officer of a travel service company who notified the Australian Federal Police that United States travellers cheques to the value of $100,000 had been purchased by two persons using cash. The amount had made him suspicious. The Australian Federal Police conducted an investigation and discovered that a syndicate had imported a large consignment of drugs and was planning a further large importation. A number of people were arrested and charged under the Customs Act and assets worth well in excess of $1m were seized and secured. During the investigation-and this is the important part-it was discovered that the syndicate had, in a number of previous cash dealings involving several banks, purchased bank cheques to a total of $720,718. These transactions had not been reported.

The second example was a case that was under investigation at the time that the submission was lodged. Australian Federal Police officers discovered that over a period of three months over $6m in cash was deposited in a bank and, within a short time, transferred to various overseas destinations as part of a money laundering scheme. The largest single deposit was more than $1.5m in $50, $20 and $10 notes. A further cause for suspicion was that on one occasion the money deposited had horse chaff and hay mixed with it. But notwithstanding these highly unusual aspects, the bank concerned-one of our respected banks-had not regarded this transaction of a sufficiently unusual nature to refer it to the Australian Federal Police. Of course, under this legislation it would have to do so.

The last example I want to cite is one that was put to us by the National Crime Authority. This case followed from the well-known Operation Silo investigation, which the Authority claimed showed the difficulties involved in identifying cash laundered through the financial system. Cornwell and Bull, who were major targets in the investigation, received large amounts of cash from drug sales. They managed to transfer the proceeds overseas at little or no risk to themselves. They brought cash in amounts of $200,000 at a time to two branches of a particular bank. The cash was used to purchase telegraphic transfers to Swiss bank accounts controlled by Cornwell. A total of at least $1.2m was remitted to Switzerland in June 1985 by this method; in other words, buying bank transfers with huge sums of cash. In each case the transfers were purchased in false names-to reinforce Senator Hamer's point-by persons who had no legitimate accounts with the bank and who produced no identification.

Furthermore, a large number of cash deposits of less than $10,000 were made at various banks in false names and the proceeds remitted to a bank account in England. Finally, on at least two occasions in 1985 associates of Cornwell and Bull purchased gold bars from a particular gold bullion dealer in Sydney for cash amounting to approximately $240,000 on each occasion. At a later time another associate resold 20 gold bars to the same bullion dealer in exchange for a cheque for $477,000. The cheque was used to purchase a bank draft for $US316,000, deposited in a Swiss bank account.

Under legislation existing in 1985, these transactions were not brought to the attention of the authority by the relevant financial institutions. Had it not been for the chance discovery of documentation on an associate of Cornwell's arrested overseas, this evidence would not have become available and the confiscation of a large portion of the abovementioned funds would not have been possible.

Those three examples were certainly sufficient in my mind, where the costs of the Bill had been difficult to assess and upon which there had been conflicting evidence, to determine that the Government should have this piece of legislation and that the law enforcement authorities which supported it-the National Crime Authority, the DPP and the Attorney-General's office-should be given this extra resource in law enforcement.

I will briefly tell you, Madam Acting Deputy President, of the assessment of the NCA of the importance of following the money trail in combating organised crime because it does indicate how broad the scope of this matter becomes. It is the NCA's view that it is a valuable tool to deter persons from criminal activity, including money laundering; it is valuable in assisting the detection and investigation of a crime; it is useful to identify assets acquired as a result of that crime in order to enable forfeiture or pecuniary penalty and civil remedies proceedings to be undertaken; and it is helpful in identifying large amounts of undisclosed income or individuals involved in taxation evasion. As the NCA reminds us, more generally the existence of large amounts of black cash in society undermines the values and legitimate sources of power in that society. It facilitates corruption and undermines the safeguards that are so important to our way of life.

I was persuaded, therefore, that this Bill was worth while. At the very least it would make life for the criminal more difficult. How to launder illegally obtained money is one major challenge that faces a criminal because the head of organised crime wants to get the criminally obtained funds to himself through some legitimate avenue. As the NCA reminds us, often it is just as easy to detect the criminal in his attempt to launder the funds as it is in relation to detecting the original crime. Finally, as the NCA reminds us, the most successful and common method of laundering illegally obtained cash is through legitimate financial institutions, particularly banks. As we all know, cash leaves little record of its movement or, indeed, of its very existence.

In conclusion, in supporting the Bill those of us on this side of the House are, nevertheless, very conscious of our responsibility to ensure that legislation of this type does not go beyond that which is necessary; in other words, as much as possible to protect the financial privacy of the individual. We have seen the responsibility that has been placed on us in recent times, as honourable senators would be aware, in regard to this Government's ID card Bill where it was necessary to answer the Government's unnecessary intrusion upon personal liberties. There is no doubt that this Bill, although it does include some safeguards, is a further erosion of those personal liberties. That is one reason why in the Committee we believed that it was important that it be reassessed after only three years, but it also reminds us of the importance for broad-based privacy legislation in this country to ensure that governments and administrative bodies of government are not abusing their responsibility.

I join with the comments that were made by Senator Macklin. I am disturbed that the Government's privacy Bill seems to have disappeared in the reference to the extended tax file numbers and methods in tonight's economic statement. I assure the Senate that the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs that I mentioned earlier has a reference that includes the question of privacy in looking at what the Government intended in the ID card Bill. We are certainly going to look at the importance of national broad-based privacy legislation, even if the Government is not going to go on with it, in order that we can properly inform the Senate and hopefully the Senate can then make wise decisions that will protect the privacy of Australians to every extent that is reasonably possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating the Cash Transaction Reports Bill 1987. I wish to state quite clearly right at the beginning that the Opposition has always taken the attitude that we favour any action that will attack, curtail or prevent organised crime and its money laundering and also support any initiative that will make sure that people pay their just taxes. While it is alleged that that is exactly what this Bill is designed to do, I briefly wish to express some reservations.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill presupposes that all the big time crooks, drug dealers and so forth are going to have a colossal net thrown over their heads and that they will continue to deal in the ways in which they have supposedly dealt in the past. I really question that because I do not think that anyone who is cognisant of this type of legislation would continue to deal in the way in which he has in the past. Nonetheless, while this notion would be wonderful if it were true, there are a number of considerations that should be taken into account.

This Bill seeks that all cash transactions exceeding $10,000 be reported to the Cash Transaction Reports Agency; that persons transferring more than $5,000 worth of foreign currency in or out of Australia are reported, and of course there are limited exceptions with that clause; and financial institutions will be obliged to verify all signatories of present and future accounts. In that respect there is an element of retrospectivity which many financial institutions are concerned about from the point of view that the retrospective element of getting people in to verify their accounts is going to not only to be time consuming but also very costly. The information reported to the Agency will then be made available to the Australian Taxation Office on an unrestricted basis. I suppose that is really where I have one of my major concerns. More reporting by agencies to government departments-in other words, an exchange of information-does worry me. In the knowledge that this Hawke Government would have had us all tagged with an ID card by now if it had its way, anyone would really need to be concerned about further exchanges of information from department to department. But there is an automatic presumption of guilt should anyone dare to withdraw $10,000 in cash from his account and that all cash transactions are illicit. I think that that automatic presumption of guilt is something that we must make sure is not a way of life. There are obviously many areas where cash is transferred in such amounts legally. I recognise that there are a few people who deal in such large amounts of cash. Nonetheless, the Bill creates an expanded bureaucracy that will have expanded surveillance powers. The concerns about the expanded bureaucracy and the expanded surveillance powers that this Bill creates are similar to the concerns that people had about the identity card and the surveillance powers that were going to be attached to that. I, too, share the concerns of my colleague Senator Robert Hill, who just mentioned the privacy legislation, which has somehow disappeared, in terms of making sure that there is absolute and utter privacy.

It has been quite clearly stated that this Bill is modelled on the 1970 United States Bank Secrecy Act. Some people have said that this Act was highly successful, but the information I have received is that doubts have emerged as to the effectiveness of this Act. A report to Congress some 10 years after it was actually brought in suggested that law enforcement agencies were making little use of the reports. If the Act is that successful, why are they not making more use of those reports? Furthermore, some 16 years later the United States Treasury had not officially determined the effectiveness of the legislation. There were further problems of great backlogs, and the Customs and tax departments made greater use of the Act than the law enforcement agencies.

I realise that this Bill is in fact a two-pronged attack and should be seen as such. But if it is being modelled on the US experience, why has not the US experience been better and more highly recommended than it has thus far? Whilst it is desirable to close off the flourishing top end of the cash economy and to ensure that people pay their taxes, it is to me equally vital that criminals be brought to justice and it will be only the lunatic criminal who will be caught by this legislation, as I mentioned before, as identities can be manufactured in a multitude of ways. The Bill also fails to recognise that dirty money will continue to be laundered through a variety of separate accounts, possibly using smaller amounts of money. They are all things that have to be considered. I do not think the Bill addresses those issues properly. It will be the people with the least resources who will be interrogated and nailed to the wall, because the big time criminal will have all the resources in the world. I think that is where we will be looking down the barrel as we will be creating a flourishing world of people designing new ways to get round the system. It worries me that this legislation will make criminals more creative and innovative and that it will actually increase the underground cash economy, not prevent it. If that does not eventuate, so be it. That would be desirable. But I do not see this Bill as really covering those basic areas of concern.

To me the best way of locating criminals is to target them specifically. At best, the US Bank Secrecy Act provides corroborative rather than primary evidence. The obligation under this Bill is on the institutions, not on the users. Clause 24 of the Bill gives the police and/or Customs officers powers of confiscation and seizure based on suspicion rather than proof. To me this Bill should have corroborative evidence provisions rather than those of suspicion. There are, of course, concerns that under this legislation visitors could be heavily penalised if they are unaware of the provisions.

Another area of concern is the largely unknown cost of compliance and whether those costs will be passed on to the consumer. I suppose we could bet London to a brick that they will. What will be the size and cost of the expanded bureaucracy and the cost of the ongoing reporting? It goes without saying that the business community needs less regulation, not more. There are many people in both the business community and the community in general who are very worried about the implications of this Bill. While the costs mentioned in this Bill include computer installation and the staffing of the Cash Transaction Reports Agency, the Government does not give any consideration to the costs borne by the administering banks and institutions, which have been estimated to be between $60m and $100m.

While we are debating this Bill tonight, we must be aware that it applies only to cash transactions over $10,000. But who is to say that this Government, which was hell-bent, and I believe still is, on having a dossier collection for every citizen, will not attempt at a later date to decrease the amount, have it apply to cheques or extend the dossier collection generally. Many Australians are concerned about that.

In summary, if this legislation achieves its goals, it may be commendable. However, if it is simply putting in place a strategy for inquiring into the cash transactions of any person at any time, there is cause for real concern. I am, however, relieved at the recommendation of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs about reviewing this legislation within three years. I note that in the report the Committee emphasises that the important thing is to establish the authority-this is, of course, in terms of reviewing it-with the correct type of data that will give the information sought. We would want to know about the flow of things, the existence of the information responsible for picking up the money laundering that was going on, how many transactions it actually produced and whether it was merely corroborative evidence-in other words, what weight could be given to its value? The Committee recommends that the operations of this Bill be reviewed after a suitable period, preferably not longer than three years, and that the review include the economic, taxation, privacy and law enforcement implications of the Bill. I guess that the only reason why I have a little bit of confidence that it may be able to do what it is setting out to do is that that review period will be set in place. If it did not have a review period, I would be most concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are tonight addressing the Cash Transaction Reports Bill. This Bill has had, as I think others have observed, a rather chequered history. It was originally introduced in the other place in May of last year by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). After the intervention of the general election it was revised, after consultation in particular with the Australian Bankers Association and with other financial institutions, particularly in respect of the verification procedures which are laid down in the Bill concerning so-called cash dealers. The revised Bill, the present one, was introduced into the Senate late last year by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) and was referred, I think because of some doubts expressed on this side of the chamber, to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on 15 December last year. That Committee, of which I am a member, reported last month.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is fair to say that the Committee's report, which is a substantial document in terms of length and so on, is less substantial when it comes to its recommendations, which I think it is fair to say are relatively minor. There are only two recommendations and the only one which one could describe as possibly other than minor is the recommendation that the working of the Bill, if enacted-as it undoubtedly will be-should be reviewed within a period of roughly three years of its coming into force. Both of those recommendations have been accepted by the Government, and naturally I welcome that.
The purpose of the Bill was set out by the Minister for Justice in his second reading speech in the Senate last year, when he said:
This Bill will give law enforcement agencies the ability to monitor the movement of large amounts of cash, and thus to identify the recipients of proceeds of crime.

It is, of course, those elements of society-namely, tax evaders and recipients of the proceeds of crime-against whom the provisions of the Bill are meant to be directed. Having sat through the evidence and through the proceedings of the Senate Committee and later, to some degree, over the preparation of its reports, I have to say that I think the claim on the Minister's part at that time is a considerable overstatement.

The Bill will not give law enforcement agencies the ability to monitor the movement of large amounts of cash for reasons which I think are probably fairly obvious if one thinks about it for any length of time and which have already been referred to in the Senate tonight by some of the preceding speakers. As they have pointed out the very enactment of the Bill is undoubtedly going to produce a change in behaviour on the part of both criminal elements and tax evaders in the society. Much though we may wish otherwise, that is the reality, and we are blinkered in our vision if we do not understand that.

It follows from that that it is unlikely that the Bill will be successful in identifying major-I underline that word-tax evaders and the recipients of the proceeds of major crime. I will have something more to say about that when I come to consider what in specific terms the Committee had to say in regard to the effectiveness of the Bill, if enacted. I want to underline that the real question that is being increasingly asked in my own mind and that of some others about the Bill is whether the purpose, as stated by the Minister in his second reading speech and as quoted a moment ago, is likely to be achieved.

If one reads the Minister's second reading speech-and this is of course six months later-one has to confess to a feeling that a number of the claims in it are a bit overblown. Senator Macklin, I think, suggested earlier this evening that the Government, including the Minister, had been once again snowed by its public servants. I do not know whether that is true, but I must say that, having sat through all the hearings of the Senate Committee and listened, in particular, to witnesses from the Attorney-General's Department, I confess to some continuing personal unease along the same lines as Senator Macklin. Of course, part of that unease does stem from the magnitude of the claims made by the Minister last year. For example, he said, and I am quoting again from the second reading speech:
This Bill represents one of the most significant initiatives to counter the underground cash economy, tax evasion and money laundering.

I suppose, if one takes that statement literally, it may very well be true in so far as there have not been perhaps many other initiatives directed at those totally desirable objectives. I suppose, if one takes it literally, as I say, one could say, therefore, that this is one of the most significant of such initiatives. However, I think that there is a certain amount of rodomontade in that claim which, again, I have to say I think does not quite live up to specification when it comes to looking at how the Bill is likely to work in practice. Later the Minister in his speech went on to say:
The Bill provides comprehensive measures for the control of the cash economy.

That is a very large claim and I have to say that I do not think it is at all sustainable for reasons, again, which I hope to address briefly at a later stage in my remarks. The Minister went on to say, again at a later stage in his speech:
The reporting and verification-
that is to say, those procedures of the Bill-

will be of great value in following the money trial in relation to proceeds of all criminal activities, including tax evasion, and in detecting financiers of criminal activity, such as drug trafficking.

I only wish that were true because all of us in this place would share the view that, to achieve such objectives would be highly desirable. Again, I have to say that I think the claims are overstated and not inconsiderably overstated. One of the reasons perhaps which underlay the last claim of the Minister which I have just quoted-or perhaps that of whoever it was who may have drafted those passages of his speech for him-was the statement which followed immediately in his speech:
The thrust of the scheme is broadly similar to the successful scheme in operation in the United States.

That of course raised the question, which was a question that the Committee sought to address, not very successfully, namely, how successful has that United States legislation been. It is fair to say that the evidence on that matter was conflicting at best and I might go further and say disappointing at worst. Paragraph 8.10 of the concluding chapter of the report is where the Committee very much in summary form concluded:
The United States of America is the only country to have enacted comparable measures-
that is comparable to those now proposed in the Bill-
The evidence of the American experience is inconsistent.

For those who want to find further elaboration of that conclusion, they will, of course, find it in the Hansard transcripts of the evidence given before the Committee. I stress that there is probably no difference I suspect between any senator in this place when it comes to the desirability of the objectives of defeating organised crime in this country and cracking down on tax evasion. Where the doubts arise, therefore, is not in relation to those universally accepted objectives but in the attempt to weigh the costs of doing so, the cost which this Bill seems likely to impose. I am not speaking of financial costs. There will be some financial costs and they are addressed in the Committee's report. They need no further elaboration from me.

I am speaking in terms of the cost which has underlaid the real concerns expressed by many people on being informed about this Bill, that is the cost in terms of possible intrusion into people's privacy. Those are the chief costs which have to be weighed against the asserted-and I underline that word-but as yet, as I think the Minister would agree, unproven benefits. The Committee did its best-it may not have been a very effective best-to assess such evidence as it could bring before it on that question of the effectiveness or the benefits from this legislation if enacted. Perhaps the passages of the report to which attention needs to be particularly directed in that respect are paragraphs 3.19 to 3.21 appearing at page 19 of the report. They address the whole topic of money laundering, which is what the Bill is concerned to deal with. It may be worth while quoting the three short paragraphs in question. Paragraph 3.19 of the report states:

Money may be laundered in a variety of ways. Increasing resort to the unlawful cash economy in order to avoid dealing with the regular financial institutions is one simple and obvious technique of avoiding the provisions of the Bill.

All that paragraph is saying is that in this area, as in some others, the act of enacting this legislation will itself almost certainly be bound to produce a change in the behaviour of those whom the Bill seeks to survey.

A well-known law in the area of monetary economics is Goodhart's law, which says that any measure of the money supply which you seek to control immediately becomes useless as a control measure because it immediately changes once people know that you are seeking to control it. There is an obvious parallel in the area that we are talking about. I see the Minister nodding his head; I am glad to have his assent because it is a commonsense conclusion and no more than that.
In paragraph 3.20 the Committee said:
The Committee is concerned that the exemption provisions-
that is, the exemption provisions of the Bill-

may provide a means of avoiding the reporting provisions of the Bill. The exemption provisions leave it open to a person interested in laundering cash to `perhaps consider buying a retail business or one of those businesses which by its very nature, under this legislation is designed not to attract the attention of the authorities'.

That is a passage from the evidence given before the Committee. Again, it is no more than a commonsense conclusion. We all know from our knowledge of the activities of criminal elements, particularly major and well-organised criminal elements in other societies and no doubt in this one as well-we may be less knowledgeable about it here, at least publicly less so-that such major criminal elements are very well-organised and perfectly capable of equipping themselves with businesses which, to quote the Committee, by their very nature, under this legislation, are designed not to attract the attention of the authorities. Finally, paragraph 3.21 of the report stated:
The Committee considers also that under the provisions of the Bill it might be possible to take control of a cash dealer-
that is, `cash dealer' as defined for the purposes of the Bill-
such as a building society or credit union. The Committee notes the evidence that building societies are `co-operative organisations and are not for sale'-
that is obviously true-
but considers that control of a building society, as opposed to its purchase, may nevertheless be possible. The same could perhaps be true of a credit union.

They were three key paragraphs in which the Committee sought to set down for the information of the Senate its doubts as to the possibilities which not a prolonged period of thought opens up to anyone who has thought about how one might go about evading the effective provisions of the Bill after it has been enacted. No doubt if one had one's livelihood at stake, so to speak, if one were personally involved in the matter, one could find a good many other possible such loopholes to exploit. The Committee concluded on this aspect, at paragraph 8.8 of its conclusions chapter:
The Committee has formed the view that the Bill, if enacted, will, as part of a law enforcement package-
it is important to emphasise that because the Government has made much of that point and it is perfectly fair and valid to emphasise it-

probably yield additional information to law enforcement agencies. This information could be expected to concern, in the main, relatively unsophisticated operations designed to evade tax or launder money.

I think the Committee is saying there, in perhaps less formal language, that the Bill, if enacted, is likely to provide the law enforcement authorities and taxation authorities with some information about what one might call the Mr Littles in society but is unlikely-I would say totally unlikely-to provide them with such information about the activities of the Mr Bigs, about whom we should be principally concerned.

It is perfectly arguable that even to catch up with or to get further information about the Mr Littles is not an undesirable objective-and I would be the first to agree with that-but if we could know, as distinct from hypothesising or assuming, that is all the Bill is likely to achieve, one might have one's doubts rather strongly reinforced about whether the other costs of the legislation relating to intrusion of privacy and so on could really be justified. Paragraph 8.9 of the conclusions chapter of the report states:

The Committee foresees a change in behaviour as criminal elements or tax evaders are forced to operate outside the regular financial system. It would expect an increase in the unlawful cash economy consequent upon the enactment of the Bill. The Bill needs to be evaluated in this context.

I interpolate that at one point in the Committee's proceedings one member of the Committee was heard to remark that what the Government was really about in this piece of legislation was to produce a safe-led recovery with all our criminal elements buying safes in which they can hold large amounts of cash to conduct their future dealings. I do not proceed with that no doubt frivolous interpolation.
In paragraph 8.10 the Committee was finally forced into concluding, the only conclusion that it could almost by definition arrive at or by hypothesis arrive at:
The evidence available to the Committee was insufficient to enable it to reach a firm view on the effectiveness of the Bill, were it to become law.

That conclusion is somewhat depressing in that in the almost totally unchartered waters of this kind it would have been wrong of the Committee to say flatly one way or the other, `Yes, the Bill will be very effective', or alternatively `totally ineffective'. The Committee has expressed the conclusion that it will probably be somewhat effective but almost certainly that effectiveness will be confined to dealing with the Mr Littles.

Before concluding I wish to make only one other point. One of the aspects of the Bill that has attracted some attention relates to the verification procedures. We were told by both representatives of the banks and the building societies that the verification procedures that are to be laid down in the legislation do not now differ vastly, although perhaps in some of the mechanics they do, from those in respect of new accounts that both banks and building societies are now themselves insisting upon before they accept new accounts from customers. That differs from past practice in the case of both sets of financial institutions but both have realised in the light of some experience over recent years that their past somewhat cavalier procedures were not really good enough in circumstances of today and perhaps the changed society of today.

In connection with the verification procedures I noted only this evening what the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has had to say in his economic statement, which he brought down at 7.30 tonight, about the new tax file number. In the time available to us this evening to try to assimilate this enormous mass of paper which the Government has produced, I will not pretend that I have fully absorbed all the government said on this matter. It strikes me that at least in some respects the Government's proposal for the tax file number may be in effect a kind of braces to the belt it is already applying through the cash transactions reporting procedures under this Bill. I simply leave that comment there without attempting to pursue it this evening. Perhaps at some stage the Government may want to look at the question of whether there is not a degree of double provision, so to speak, being made.

Some of my colleagues have emphasised that when all is said both sides of the chamber have to arrive at judgments about this matter. It is fair to say that some of the more extreme alarms that have been raised about this Bill are unjustified in the sense that the Bill does not, for the most part, deal with what one normally thinks of as transactions; that is to say, dealing in cheques and matters of that kind but only with, at least in the major part of the Bill, cash transactions, that is, currency, notes of the realm or some other realm. As some other speakers have said, it is not normal, for many of us at least, to have as much as $10,000 in our hands in notes of the realm or notes of some other country. In that sense we are unlikely to find any of our transactions coming under the surveillance procedures of the Cash Transaction Reports Agency which is proposed to be set up under the Bill.

However, I should say that there is one exception to that, and that is the so-called suspect transactions provisions of the Bill in clause 14. I think it might be better to reserve what I have to say on that until the committee stage because that is a provision of a very different kind from the Bill as a whole. It is almost as though it is a separate Bill built into the Cash Transaction Reports Bill because it deals with transactions of all kinds-not only in cash but also all other forms of exchange-and it also has to do with transactions of any magnitude, not necessarily magnitudes in excess of $10,000, or $5,000 in the case of overseas transactions.

All that having been said, on balance a judgment has to be made about this Bill. The judgment that the Opposition has reached has been that it would not be possible for us to state with certainty that the costs of the legislation are excessive in terms of the benefits that it is asserted that it will bring, even though we may have doubts about the latter point. Therefore, the Opposition has decided not to oppose the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank all honourable senators who have contributed to the second reading debate on the Cash Transaction Reports Bill 1987, particularly those who sat on the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, whose deliberations I believe were useful and demonstrated, once again, the benefits that can be derived from Senate committee consideration of legislation-however irritating it was at the time to the Government that the Bill be sent off. But I believe that the report was valuable and it helped to allay many of the fears and misgivings which were abroad in the community concerning the possible impact of this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, I think I can do almost no better in my summing up than to adopt most of what fell from the lips of Senator Alston, who I thought gave a very fine speech-except for the section where he said of Senator Macklin that he was surrounded by friends who carried large amounts of cash in brown paper bags. I am sure that that is not the case. Apart from that, I think Senator Alston's robust defence of the work of his Committee and of the Bill itself is something that I can certainly adopt. In that respect, I think what Senator Alston said probably characterises most of the debate this evening; that is, that what could be endorsed of this Bill could be put on the balance of probabilities. I think Senator Alston spoke of a measured degree of confidence in the operation of the Bill fulfilling its objectives, and I think that the objectives might be stated or achieved in a more modest way than was perhaps first thought.

But I do not accept for a moment that the Government-including, certainly, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen)-has been swamped or snowed by bureaucrats in relation to this piece of legislation. Madam Acting Deputy President, it may be of interest to you to learn that the Attorney-General went to the United States of America and saw for himself and inquired for himself about the operation of the legislation upon which this Bill is modelled. It was his conviction that it was working in the United States, which gave him confidence in putting forward this measure as one part of a package of measures dealing with the assault on organised crime in this country. In that respect, I do not think any government could claim to have shown such an innovative approach to the legislative apparatus of government sanctioned by this Parliament which should be part of the armoury of any society in trying to defend itself against the depredations and the corruption of society which flow from the operations of organised criminal activity.

I give to Senator Hamer, who has returned to the chamber, the assurance he sought in his remarks. The Committee thought that a substantial and comprehensive review of the legislation might be undertaken in some three years from the commencement of its operation. It would be only sensible. I give the assurance that should some particular difficulty arise in relation to the two matters which Senator Hamer raised-namely, the process of the opening of new accounts, the verification of identity process, and in relation to the burdens that might be put on the cash dealers concerned-the Government will undertake to review any such difficulty that emerges of a substantial kind which may warrant amendment.

In relation to Senator Stone and Goodhart's law, which he mentioned in relation to some analogy with economics, I believe that this Bill will change the behaviour of those who, at the moment, are trying to evade tax or hide the ill-gotten gains of organised criminal activity by dealing in large amounts of cash-$10,000 or more. Obviously, they will seek other methods of laundering their funds, including the simple one of resorting to cash transactions of a lesser amount. But, of course, as with telephone interception, that leads to an environment of greater difficulty for criminals. They have to choose means other than simply the ones presently available to deal with the cash that is generated by their nefarious enterprises. In that situation their activities become more difficult to control, more complex and more easily detectable. So I think the analogy with what happens when criminals become aware that their telephones might be tapped and they have to resort to physical face to face meetings and so on, deals with Senator Stone's quite valid point.

As I have said, I thank those honourable senators who have contributed to the debate. I believe that this legislation is extremely important. I accept the good faith of the Australian Democrats in their constant support of this Government, up to the point of this Bill, in combating organised crime, particularly in Senator Macklin's case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Gee, thanks!
—Senator Macklin, of course, was very good on the Joint Statutory Committee on the National Crime Authority.
—I was on the Committee.

—Senator Haines, as a predecessor, was most distinguished. But in this case I think they have failed to listen sufficiently closely to the experience of their colleague Senator Powell on the committee dealing with the Cash Transaction Reports Agency, whose hearings were conducted under the aegis of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. Had they done so, they would have been joining the rest of the chamber-which I hope will be demonstrated in less than 20 seconds-in passing the second reading stage of this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

`` `approved cash carrier' means a cash dealer declared by the Director to be an approved cash carrier under section 7a;''.
(2) Page 9, clause 7, at the end of subclause (1) add the following word and paragraph:

Approved cash carriers

Director to have access to certain records

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills produced over time a number of reports with regard to this Bill, one on 27 May 1987, another on 9 December 1987 and the latest one after the Committee had delivered its report. The first item I wish to raise is subclause 3 (1), that is, the definition of `unit trust' where the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has pointed to inappropriate delegation of legislative power. I quote from the Committee's report:

SPEECH.PARA: The entire content of such definitions is thus left to be formulated by the Minister and is to be declared by the Minister by notice in the Gazette only and not prescribed by regulation which would be subject to tabling and disallowance.

On occasions in the past when these items have arisen we have had Opposition support to do something about them. There has been an indication that such support will not be forthcoming in terms of making sure that the Minister does not have this type of unfettered power. The response of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) to the Committee's report was:

It should be borne in mind that once an arrangement falls outside the prescription cash transactions conducted through the trust fall outside the reporting requirements and the trust can thus become an immediate and effective vehicle for money laundering.

Certainly that proposition is accepted. However, it does not go to the heart of the point. The Committee, in its report, says the same, that is, that it is inappropriate that such matters be notified in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette instead of by regulation. Is the Minister able to give any further explanation as to why the Government has pressed on with this, despite the fact that it was willing to pick other amendments recommended by other committees? Quite deliberately it has ignored the recommendations of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, which unfortunately it is increasingly becoming accustomed to doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not the intention of the Government simply to ignore the report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. It was thought in this instance that the explanation given by the Minister was appropriate. Indeed, the Committee did see merit in the Attorney's explanation as to why this provision was provided in the legislation. The provision that it be declared by the Minister only in the Australian Government Gazette is one that I understand might raise some queries from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I believe that the Government's reasoning can be accepted by the chamber.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! it being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Chairman do leave the Chair and report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The next item I wish to raise with regard to the report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills is one of the worst aspects that we have seen the Government becoming accustomed to including in its legislation. I refer to non-reviewable decisions. The Committee, in that part of its report relating to clause 10 (3), stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Director may direct an institution to delete or amend such an entry in its exemption register.
No provision has been made for the review of the Director's decision on its merits and clause 33-
that is now clause 40-

expressly excludes decisions under the Act from the application of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977. A decision of the Director under subclause 10 (3) would therefore only be subject to review by the courts by way of the actions available at common law prior to the enactment of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977. As a decision of the Director under subclause 10 (3) may impose quite onerous reporting requirements on financial institutions the Committee drew the subclause to the attention of Senators in that it may be considered to make rights, liberties and/or obligations unduly dependent upon non-reviewable decisions.
The response of the Attorney to this proposition was as follows:
. . . the principal purpose of the Bill is to facilitate the administrative of taxation laws. All agency functions must be performed in consultation with the Commissioner . . .
However, the Committee's report continues:
The Committee believes that, bearing these considerations in mind, there should at least be provision for review of Director's decisions under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act.

In other words, it has noted the comments of the Attorney and has decided that it still wishes to press the point. I wonder whether the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) may have any more information as to why the Government chose to ignore the Committee's report. Despite all the Attorney's blandishments of the committee, it still saw that the point that it made had merit and, indeed, what the Government was attempting to do was to take away rights of people to seek review for these types of administrative decisions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important that administrative decisions be subject to review. In general, this Government would try to implement that principle. But there are occasions when it could lead to very unfortunate effects. In relation to various decisions taken by the Director, some matters which have been raised in debate are subject to the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act-for example, the blocking mechanism in relation to accounts which can lead to the confiscation of a person's moneys. Those decisions are subject to review under the AD(JR) Act. It think that is very important because obviously one is dealing with the confiscation of a person's moneys that are held in an account.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the decision about access to and decisions about the use of the exemption register, being subject to review. The fact is that under section 13 of the AD(JR) Act, as Senator Macklin will know, what becomes reviewable in this case are the reasons for the decision of the Director. In that situation one might create a situation where the Director would be required to give reasons which he has formed on the basis of intelligence made available to him from law enforcement agencies. He would exercise his discretion in relation to access to the register and whether persons or classes of transactions should be on it in light of intelligence from taxation of law enforcement bodies. For him to be required to disclose the evidence rather than the material or the reasons could require the disclosure of the information received from those law enforcement bodies. I believe that the disclosure of the intelligence in those cases would be unfortunate and, indeed, would prejudice not only the investigation but also, I suppose, the standing of that customer. The fact is that in giving those reasons, intelligence from taxation or law enforcement agencies would have to be revealed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the point made by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) with regard to the taxation case, although it seems to me to be a rather extra- ordinary proposition that it is perfectly all right to establish a principle whereby individuals can have their rights taken away because other problems may occur if one does not take away their rights. It seems to me that that was the substance of the Minister's response. Let us put aside the point he has just made with regard to those items. Why is it that clause 40 is all encompassing in terms of the decisions? It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 does not apply to decisions under this Act, other than a decision by the Director under subsection 17 (2) or (3).

All other decisions are excluded. Why is this the case? Can the Minister give some examples of some of the other types of decisions not affecting those that he wishes to exclude? If that is not the case, why was clause 40 drafted in such a way as to exclude specifically the item that the Minister has just raised-in other words, it puts the onus in the other direction-and simply leave open the other types of decisions of the Director?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe, as is evident from the report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, that it is the decisions of the Director which are of concern and the ones which would normally attract the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act provisions. As I have already indicated, the Bill is drawn on the basis that whilst some decisions of the Director are reviewable, and properly so, because they involve the confiscation of the assets of persons in Australia, these decisions which are themselves the subject of review by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee concerning the register are, for the reasons I have outlined, not to be subject to such review. It is really the Director's powers which are the key ones in this area of concern in the Bill. That is the scope of clause 40.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments.
Adoption of Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for its indulgence in going beyond the usual adjournment time. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the report be adopted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the annual report of the Aboriginal Development Commission for 1986-87 was tabled. Unfortunately, as so many people wished to speak on the report we ran out of time in the debate on it. The Chairman of the Aboriginal Development Commission, Mrs Shirley McPherson of Geraldton, Western Australia, was formally appointed Chairman in a full time capacity on 29 July 1986 after serving as a part time Chairman since 7 March 1984. In her introduction to this report-in the circumstances I really must quote verbatim parts of it-she stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Aboriginal Development Commission Act 1980 which established the ADC in 1980 is a unique piece of legislation, visionary in outlook and clearly recognising Aboriginal needs. It was only enacted after extensive consultation with the Aboriginal people and with the bi-partisan support of Parliament.

The Act is greatly valued by the Aboriginal people because it reflects their wishes and aspirations for genuine self-management, financial self-sufficiency and permits the Commission to promote these with a very real degree of autonomy for its Aboriginal Board.

My fellow Commissioners and I have worked hard and responsibly to ensure that the trust placed in us by both the Aboriginal people and the Parliament is fully justified. Evidence of our success is provided by this Report and by our published Corporate Plan.

Mrs McPherson also referred in her introduction to some of the results of decentralisation of some of the functions of the Commission. It is rather ironic that she said that one of the results of decentralisation is:
a new structure offering staff an enhanced career path and better prospects for promotion.
She went on to say:

The Aboriginal Development Commission Act is the only piece of legislation which embodies in it legal recognition of prior Aboriginal ownership, dispossession from their land and traditional rights, their dispersal, and, as part of the communities' responsibility for a just settlement with the Aboriginal people, their right to be compensated.
She concludes:

1986-87 has been my first year as full-time Chairman, a role both demanding and challenging, and one which will remain devoted to promoting the economic independence, self-determination and self-management of the Aboriginal people. The Commission will continue to provide leadership, particularly in the areas of economic and social development, through implementation of its policies and by voicing the concerns of Aboriginals. Over the past year, the Commission has made impressive advances both in terms of its program delivery and in gaining access for Aboriginals to the resources of other agencies and lending institutions. It has increased, and will continue to increase, its effectiveness with improvement to and refining of its Corporate Plan, strategies and programs so as to better meet its objectives.

It is therefore ironic, this report having been tabled today, that yesterday Senator Coulter's urgency motion was agreed to. It proposed at least another six months of consideration of the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) legislation to allow for more consultation with the various Aboriginal communities. The motion also proposed the reinstatement of the Aboriginal Development Commission as it was constituted before the recent dismissal of commissioners. As stated by several speakers in yesterday's debate, opinion certainly is divided amongst the Aboriginal peoples.

In my visit to the Kimberleys early this year I met with a number of communities. Some communities and individuals certainly were in favour of the new commission, ATSIC. Some were certainly against it but the majority felt absolutely rushed. They felt that they had not had time to consider properly the implications. It is true that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, visited several communities. The visits have been classed by him as true consultations. I do not doubt the Minister's sincerity. However, people who have met with Aboriginal groups, Aboriginal elders and their council members know that the Aboriginal people prefer to take time to make their considerations. They conduct business in a rather different way and time certainly is needed by them to consider properly the implications of the proposed new Commission. The changes suggested may not necessarily be bad but it is important from the Government's point of view that the Aboriginal people really understand the proposed changes, if they are to take place, and that they do not feel that these changes are imposed upon them. The Aboriginal community has been served well by the present Commission and there is no need at all for any indecent haste.

The Kimberleys communities that I visited are well on the way to total self-management. They have reached the stage of resenting visits by politicians and departmental bureaucrats, be they white or Aboriginal. They feel that these people speak at them and tell them what is good for them. This by no means can be regarded as true consultation. Yesterday, I received a telex from Laurel Winder, the chairperson of the Aboriginal and Islander Women's Congress of Western Australia. This is part of the telex:

We would . . . appreciate your support in opposing the legislation to establish the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission in order to provide the Aboriginal and Islander women of this country with the opportunity to examine in depth the details and the implications of all that is proposed in the Government's `Foundations for the Future' package in which the Commission is proposed.

The undue haste and speed in which the Minister is attempting to impose the Government's package on the Aboriginal community is highlighted by his failure to provide the Aboriginal community with the opportunity, adequate resources and the time necessary to examine and comment on whether or not the Government's package is appropriate or adequate to service and meet the needs of the Aboriginal community.

That strikes me, as I am sure it strikes the honourable senators present, as being a request that is both sensible and sensitive. The hour is late but I would very briefly like to refer to the pages in the report which refer specifically to Western Australia to show that the work done by the present Aboriginal Development Commission in Western Australia has been applauded. As far as housing is concerned, a net total of 114 new dwellings were completed. As well, 250 emergency shelters were distributed to the most needy people in the remote locations through resource agencies. The region continued to support Aboriginal building teams and encourage Aboriginal employment wherever possible. While the continued development and support of sub-regional Aboriginal housing organisations in the south-west of the State involved a small intrusion of recurrent funding into the program, the benefits of wider Aboriginal representation, cost-effective administration and increased Aboriginal self-management were apparent. There is a similar situation as far as land and land enterprises are concerned. The report states:
A total of sixteen pastoral and three farm loans and/or grants were disbursed.

The Region has been successful in broadening its commercial enterprise assistance beyond the establishment of community stores. Of sixteen commercial loans and/or grants dispersed, three were for community stores, four for tourist developments and eight for a broad range of other businesses. The Region has identified a need for greater emphasis to be placed on commercial enterprise development to benefit a significant number of Aboriginal people who live in cities and towns.

Specifically mentioned in the report is the fact that Cape Leveque was purchased under the land acquisition program for development as a tourist enterprise. I did visit Cape Leveque and I can assure the Senate that that development is a very sensitive tourist development. It by no means exploits the environment. Also, the development will make use of the resources that are provided by the local Aboriginal community who will show tourists how to fish in the Aboriginal way and how to make arts and crafts in the Aboriginal way. They will be given a taste of something that is entirely different and unique.

The report of the Aboriginal Development Commission is dated April 1988. Between the finalising of the report and its tabling in the Parliament yesterday commissioners were sacked from their jobs and others were set up in their place. This certainly is a very heavy-handed way to deal with commissioners who had only a few weeks of their appointments left to run. After the airing of these matters, it is to be hoped that the Government will now deal with greater commonsense and sensitivity with any necessary consultations and changes in procedures that may need to take place.

In conclusion, I point out that the May mini-Budget which was brought down this evening contains a section headed `Establish Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission'. The way in which this section is worded, one would presume that the legislation will go through without any alteration. The section states:

The Government has decided, following extensive consultations with Aboriginal communities to establish an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) which will assume the existing functions of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and incorporate a new Office of Torres Strait Islander Affairs and a new Aboriginal Economic Development Corporation.
Over the page this very interesting statement is made:

Under the aegis of the new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission the Government has decided to establish an Aboriginal Economic Development Corporation (AEDC). The AEDC is to undertake commercial activities of benefit to Aboriginals with the aim of furthering Aboriginal participation in enterprises operating on Aboriginal land or in areas which will have a significant impact on Aboriginal Communities. The AEDC will have a capital base, including existing assets, of $60 million of which $20 million new capital is to be injected in 1988-89 . . .

What is interesting about that statement is that that capital fund has not to date received any further money since the last Budget of the Fraser Government in 1982-83. I feel that this whole aspect needs to be looked at further when one thinks of what has happened over recent weeks as far as the Aboriginal Development Commission is concerned. I commend this report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.53 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 16 February 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Commonwealth Government provide any concessional rail travel for pensioners; if so, what are the details.
(2) Does the Commonwealth Government provide any financial assistance to any State or Territory towards concessional rail travel for pensioners; if so, what are the details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commonwealth Government provides concessional rail travel to pensioners on railway services operated by the Australian National Railways Commission (AN) on South Australian lines, and extending to Kalgoorlie, Alice Springs and Broken Hill. Totally and Permanently Disabled Soldiers (TPIs) and their attendants, World War One (WWI) veterans and their wives and widows are also eligible for concessional rail travel by AN.

The concessions depend to some extent on where the pensioner resides. All pensioners are eligible for half fare travel north of Port Pirie and on inter-system services. Pensioners residing in South Australia and Northern Territory are eligible for half fare travel on former South Australian Railways lines and either one free return journey or two single journeys a year. Pensioners residing in Broken Hill and Menindee also receive rail travel concessions over some AN lines. War pensioners and their eligible dependants are generally entitled to free travel on all AN lines.
Concessions, however, do not extend to sleeping berths (except for incapacitated ex-service personnel) and meals, which must be paid for at the ordinary tariffs.
(2) The Commonwealth Government does not provide any financial assistance to any State or Territory towards concessional rail travel for pensioners.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 15 March 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the current pricing policy of Telecom concerning the leasing of Telex units.
(2) Does Telecom offer a service to sell leased Telex units.
(3) What does Telecom do with Telex machines that have been leased and the service cancelled by customers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Customers leasing teleprinters may do so through Telecom's leasing arrangements with Custom Credit or another finance company of their choice. Telex customers also have the options to purchase outright or rent teleprinters from Telecom.
(2) No. Leased teleprinters are the property of the leasing company until the residual is paid at the end of the contracted period, when ownership passes to the customer.
(3) Telecom has no interest in the teleprinter in such circumstances. It is a matter between the customer and the finance company.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 15 March 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which Federal Government departments occupy the Wellington Street, Perth, telephone exchange building apart from Telecom and for what purpose are they there.
(2) Does the roof of the Wellington Street building contain satellite communication equipment; if so, is this equipment in any way related to data collection.

(3) Is the Wellington Street building equipped with emergency stocks of food and stores for its staff which would enable them to survive a period of confinement; if so, what is the duration of this period.
(4) What computer hardware is located within the building, what did it cost and who were the suppliers of the equipment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from Telecom Australia, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) None.

(2) There is a single satellite earth station on the roof of the Wellington building comprising a dish antenna and associated communication equipment. The station provides direct communication links to other capital city earth stations in Australia via the AUSSAT satellite. These links are provided for Telecom's customers and are not related to data collection.

(4) The Wellington building houses significant quantities of computer equipment which is either integrated into switching and transmission hardware; provided as peripheral facilities to help operate, manage and support the network; or in the form of personal computers used by operations and maintenance staff.
Computer equipment has been supplied and installed in the Wellington building over a period of a number of years by numerous companies. These include:
Altos, AWA, CASE, CMS, Digital Equipment Corporation, Ericsson, Hewlett Packard, Honeywell, IBM, ITT, MICA, NEC, Nova, Olivetti, Sanyo, SESA, Siemens, WICAT.

The estimated cost of personal computers, computer terminals, mini computers and mainframes is $2.5 million. No cost figure is available for computer equipment which forms an integral part of network transmission and switching equipment. However, this could be in the order of several million dollars.
